Since (4) \Rightarrow (b), the proof is complete.

sec.title: Koehler’s and Boyle’s Theorems

def.p: An R-module M is faithful iff R\hookrightarrow M^{\alpha } for some product of \alpha copies of M (Cf. my Algebra I, sup.3.24, p.143).
M is said to be compactly faithful (also cofaithful) provided that R\hookrightarrow M^{n} for a finite cardinal n. Any quasi-injective (Cf. 3. 7A) cofaithful module is injective by Baer’s criterion.

Any injective R-module E is \prod -injective in the sense that any product E^{\alpha } is injective for any cardinal number \alpha . A quasi-injective module M is \prod -quasi-injective iff M is an injective R/\mathrm{ann}_{R}M module (Fuller [69b]).
If N=R\oplus M is a quasi-injective right R-module, then by (2), N is injective, hence so are both R_{R} and M_{R}.

statement.label: 3.9A.
statement.p: Koehler’s ([70]). If every quasi-injective right R-module is injective (=R is a right QI ring), then R is right Noetherian.

sec.p: A ring R is right (semi) hereditary if every (f\cdot g) right ideal is projective. A ring R is a right \mathbf{V}-ring if every simple right R-module is injective. (See 3.19A below.) Trivially, any right QI-ring is a right \mathrm{V}-ring.

statement.label: 3.9B.
statement.p: Boyle’s ([73]). A ring R is a right and left QI ring iff R is right and left hereditary Noetherian V-ring.

statement.label: 3.9C.
statement.p: Boyle’s Conjecture. Every right QI ring R is right hereditary.

sec.p: Boyle’s conjecture was verified for Noetherian rings of Krull dimension 1 by Michler and Villamayor [73] (Cf. Faith [76a] and [86a] and Rosier [82]). See 7.40ff.

sec.title: Quasi-injective Hulls
sec.p: See Theorems 3.2D and E for the background to the next theorem.

statement.label: 3.9D. Theorem
statement.p: If M is a quasi-injective R-module, then

def.p: Any complement submodule S of M is a direct summand, and is quasi-injective;
Any maximal essential extension S_{0} in M of a submodule S of M is a minimal quasi-injective submodule of M containing S;
Any minimal quasi-injective submodule S_{0} of M containing S is an essential extension, and any two such minimal quasi-injective submodules of M\supseteq S are isomorphic.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See op.cit.

sec.p: Cf. Miyashita [64,65]

sec.title: The Teply-Miller Theorem

statement.p: Teply-Miller Theorem ([79]). If E is an injective R-module, then the dcc in \mathcal{A}_{r}(E,R) implies the acc in \mathcal{A}_{r}(E,R), hence E is then \Sigma -injective.

sec.p: This theorem was motivated by the Hopkins-Levitzki theorem (see §2).

statement.label: 3.10A. Remark.
statement.p: The condition on E in 3.10 is called \Delta -injective by the author in [82a], Part I. Thus, \Delta -injective modules are \Sigma -injective. Cf. Nastasescu [80], Masaike [84].

sec.title: Semilocal and Semiprimary Rings
sec.p: A ring R is semilocal if R/\mathrm{rad}\,R is semisimple. A ring R is semiprimary if R is semilocal, and rad R is nilpotent. Any semiprimary ring satisfies the dcc on f\cdot g one-sided ideals (left or right) (cf. e.g. Bass[60]). (See 3.31 and Björk’s theorem following.)

Let E be a right R-module. By writing endomorphisms a\in A=\mathrm{End}E_{R} on the left, say a(x)=ax\quad \forall x\in E, then E is a canonical left A-module, and mutatis mutandis, E is canonically a right module over the biendomorphism (= bicentralizer) ring R^{\prime \prime }=\mathrm{End}_{A}E. See my Algebra [72a], pp. 119–120 for a discussion of the “homomorphisms opposite scalars” convention.

statement.label: 3.11A.
statement.p: Hansen’s ([74]). In theorem 3.10, the double centralizer (= biendomorphism) ring R^{\prime \prime } of E is a semiprimary ring.

statement.label: 3.11B.
statement.p: Converse of the Teply-Miller-Hansen (Faith [67, 82a]). If E is a \Sigma injective right R-module with semiprimary biendomorphism ring R^{\prime \prime }, then E is \Delta -injective.

statement.label: 3.12A. Remark.
statement.p: For sufficient conditions for when \Delta -injective implies that R^{\prime \prime } is right Artinian, see Theorem 7.45.

statement.label: 3.12B. Remark.
statement.p: The Cartan-Eilenberg-Bass theorem can be obtained as a consequence of 3.7 since, by 3.8C, any right ideal of R is the annihilator of any injective cogenerator E of mod-R, so \Sigma -injectivity of E implies R is right Noetherian. Moreover, if E is any faithful module, then any right annihilator I of R is the right annihilator of EL, where L is the left annihilator in R of I, hence \Sigma -injectivity of a faithful injective module E implies ace on right annihilators of R(=\,\mathrm{acc}\,\perp ). Cf. Goursaud and Valette [75], who prove that any ring R with a faithful \Sigma -injective right R-module has ace on direct sums of right ideals. See finite Goldie dimension below.

sec.title: Regular Elements and Ore Rings
sec.p: An element x of a ring R is regular if x^{\perp }=0 and ^{\perp }x=0. We let R^{\star } denote the set of regular elements of R. If R is commutative then R has a classical quotient ring

in which every b\in R has an inverse b^{-1}=1/b (see below). When R is a domain, then Q is the quotient field of R. A ring R satisfies the right Ore condition if, for each a,b\in R, with b regular, there exists c,d\in R with d regular so that ad=bc Mnemonic: b^{-1}a=cd^{-1}. In this case we say R is a right Ore ring.
Let Q denote the set of equivalence classes a/b with equality a/b=c/d holding iff the implication below holds: if x,y belongs to the set R^{\star } of regular elements, then
Addition and multiplication in Q are defined in the standard manner. See my Algebra I, p.390–91 for details, or Jacobson [43].

In this case, Q is a ring, called the classical right quotient ring Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) of R. Q contains R as subring via the embedding r\mapsto r/1\ \forall r\in R, every regular element of R is a unit of Q, and

sec.title: Finite Goldie Dimension and Goldie’s Theorem
sec.p: A right R-module M has infinite Goldie dimension if there is an infinite independent set \{M_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty } of nonzero submodules. Otherwise, M has finite Goldie dimension, equivalently, M satisfies the ace on direct sums of submodules (=\,\mathrm{acc}\,\oplus ). An R-module has finite Goldie dimension iff E(M) is a finite direct sum of indecomposable modules (cf. §8 and 16.9B). A module is quotient finite dimensional (q.f.d.) if every factor module is finite dimensional.

def.p: Shock [72] proved that a polynomial ring R[x] in any finite or infinite number of variables over R has the same finite right Goldie dimension as R;
Wilkerson [75] proved the same result for the twisted polynomial ring R[x,\alpha ] for an automorphism \alpha of R;
Wilkerson [73] proved for a finite, or free Abelian, or f\cdot g abelian group G that the group ring RG has finite right Goldie dimension iff R does.
For some pathology on the Goldie dimension of a sum of two modules, see Camillo [78b], Camillo and Zelmanowitz [78], and Valle [94].

sec.p: A ring R is right Goldie provided that R satisfies both acc\perp and acc\oplus .

statement.label: 3.13. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R has a semisimple right quotient ring Q=Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) iff R is semiprime right Goldie.

sec.p: Also see 3.55.

Small [66] generalized Goldie’s theorem to Artinian Q (see 3.55B), and in [68] showed then the polynomial ring and power series rings have right Artinian quotient rings. Shock [72], Theorem 3.6, extended Small’s theorem to infinite polynomial rings. Pillay [84] extended Small’s theorem to rings with perfect or QF quotient rings and to infinite polynomial rings (see 3.6A). Lesieur-Croisot [59] proved 3.13 independently. For Theorem 3.13 for rings with involution see Domokos [94].

sec.title: The Wedderburn-Artin Theorem Revisited
sec.p: We recast the Wedderburn-Artin Theorems 2.1 and 2.2.

statement.label: 3.13A.
statement.p: Wedderburn-Artin Theorem. (1) A ring R is semiprime right Artinian iff R is semisimple, that is, a finite product of full matrix rings over skew fields. (See Theorem 2.1)
(2) A ring R is a prime right Artinian ring iff R is a full n\times n matrix ring D_{n} over a skew field D. In this case R is a simple ring, and left Artinian (See Theorem 2.2.)

sec.title: The Faith-Utumi Theorem
sec.p: We next state a theorem that gives a graphic description of prime right Goldie rings, which can be used to describe all semiprime right Goldie rings.

statement.label: 3.13B.
statement.p: Faith-Utumi Theorem. A ring R is a prime right Goldie ring iff R contains a ring of all n\times n matrices F_{n} over a right Ore domain F (not necessarily having an identity element) with right quotient skew field D such that Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R)=D_{n} is the classical right quotient ring of R. (See Theorem 7.6A.)

statement.label: 3.13C. Remark.
statement.p: In its fullest form the Faith-Utumi states that if (as above) a ring R has a right quotient ring D_{n}, then there exists a right Ore domain F with right quotient skew field D such that after a possible change of matrix units in D_{n} then R contains the full n\times n matrix ring F_{n} over F. In other words, every prime right Goldie ring R is sandwiched between F_{n} and its right quotient ring D_{n}. See Theorem 7.6B for a much more general theorem.

sec.title: Goldie’s Principal Ideal Ring Theorem
sec.p: In case R is a prime or semiprime right ideal ring, Goldie proved a decisive result.

statement.label: 3.13D.
statement.p: Goldie’s Principal Right Ideal Theorem [62].
(1) If R is a semiprime principal right ideal ring, then R is a finite product of full n\times n matrix rings for various n over right Ore domains.
(2) Furthermore, if R is prime then R is a full n\times n matrix ring over a right Ore domain F.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) The domain F need not be a principal right ideal ring, by an example of Swan [62]. (2) See Theorems 7B and 7C for generalizations of Theorem 13D.

sec.title: Cailleau’s Theorem

statement.label: 3.14. Theorem
statement.p: An injective module E is \Sigma -injective iff E is a direct sum of indecomposable \Sigma -injective modules (Cf. 3.15C).

sec.p: It follows that any f\cdot g submodule S of E has injective hull E(S) which is a finite direct sum of indecomposable injectives, and hence that S contains an essential finite direct sum V_{1}\oplus \cdots \oplus V_{n} of uniform submodules \{V_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, i.e., S has finite Goldie dimension.

Moreover, from the stated results on \Sigma -injective modules, it follows that any ring R with \Sigma -injective injective hull E(R) is a Goldie ring (Goursaud and Valette [75]). Moreover, if, in addition, R is semiprime then Q=Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) exists, is semisimple, and furthermore E(R)=Q. As an example, when R is a domain, then E(R) is \Sigma -injective iff R is a right Ore domain (= has a field of right quotients Q=E(R). Cf. 6.26ff and 6.36B(2).

sec.title: Local Rings and Chain Rings
sec.p: If the set of non-units of a ring R is an ideal, equivalently R has a unique maximal right ideal m, then R is said to be a local ring. In this case, R/m is a sfield and m is the radical of R. A local ring R has no idempotents except 0 and 1. Moreover, for any prime ideal P of a commutative ring R, the complement S=R\backslash P is multiplicatively closed, and there is a local ring R_{P} consisting of all symbols a/s with a\in R,s\in S and equality defined by: a/s=b/t\Leftrightarrow (at-bs)s^{\prime }=0 for some s^{\prime }\in S. Addition and multiplication are defined in the same way as ordinary rational numbers. Thus, R_{P} is the local ring at P, and the unique maximal ideal is the set \{p/s|p\in P,s\in S\}, denoted PR_{P}. Moreover, R_{P} is a flat R-module. (See sup.4.A.)

A ring R is a right chain ring if the lattice of right ideals is linearly ordered. A right chain ring is a local ring, and a commutative chain ring is called a valuation ring. For example, for any prime number p we have a prime ideal P=(p) of \mathbb{Z}, and the local ring \mathbb{Z}_{(p)} is a valuation ring. Similarly, if k is a field, and R=k[x] the polynomial ring, any irreducible polynomial p(x) generates a prime ideal (p(x)) and the local ring R_{(p(x))} at (p(x)) is a valuation ring.

statement.label: 3.14A.
statement.p: Proposition and Definition. An R-module M is uniform if M\neq 0 and satisfies the equivalent conditions:

def.p: M has Goldie dimension =1.
E(M) is indecomposable.

A\cap B
eq 0 for any two submodules A
eq 0 and B
eq 0.
M has no complement submodules except 0 and M.
End\, E(M)_{R} is a local ring.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This goes back to Matlis [58], Papp [59], and Goldie [58, 60]. See 8.A and 16.9B.

statement.label: 3.14B. Corollary.
statement.p: If U is a uniform submodule of M, then any complement K of U in M is a maximal complement; and conversely, if K is a maximal proper complement submodule of M, then any complement U of K is uniform.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Straightforward application of 13.14A and 3.2E.

statement.label: 3.14C. Remark.
statement.p: Any proper maximal complement submodule K of M is an irreducible submodule in the sense that M/K is an irreducible module.

sec.title: Beck’s Theorems
sec.p: Let R be a commutative ring, and \mathcal{P} a nonempty set of prime ideals. Then R is said to be \mathcal{P}-Noetherian provided that for every ascending chain of ideals I_{1}\subseteq I_{2}\subseteq \cdots \subseteq I_{n}\subseteq \cdots there is an integer k so that \forall P\in \mathcal{P}
where R_{P} is the local ring at P.

statement.label: 3.15A.
statement.p: Beck’s Theorem [72a]. A ring R is \mathcal{P}-Noetherian iff
is \Sigma -injective.

sec.p: A prime ideal P is said to be Noetherian if R_{P} is Noetherian.
This is Theorem 1.11 of Beck [72a].

statement.label: 3.15B. Corollary.
statement.p: If P is a prime ideal, then E(R/P) is \Sigma -injective iff P is Noetherian. In this case E(R/P) is an injective R_{P}-module.

sec.p: Regarding 3.15B, see Dade’s Theorems 3.17A,B below.
We also note a corollary of 3.15B and Cailleau’s theorem [69]:

statement.label: 3.15C. Corollary.
statement.p: An injective R-module E is \Sigma -injective iff there exists a set of Noetherian primes \mathcal{P} so that E=\oplus _{P\in \mathcal{P}}E(R/P).

statement.label: 3.15D. Remark.
statement.p: Matlis [58] proved that any injective module E over a Noetherian commutative ring R had this structure and that there is a 1-1 correspondence between prime ideals P and indecomposable injectives E(R/P). Cf. Theorem 3.4C above. Also see Goodearl-Warfield [89], Theorem 4.24, p. 79.

statement.label: 3.16A. Theorem
statement.p: If M is a flat R-module and if E is a \Sigma -injective R-module then E\otimes _{R}M is \Sigma -injective.

sec.p: The proof uses the Govorov-Lazard Theorem 4A.

statement.label: 3.16B. Corollary.
statement.p: If E is a \Sigma -injective R-module, then for any multiplicative closed subset S of R,ES^{-1} is an injective RS^{-1} module.

sec.p: Corollary 3.16B follows, since, as Beck and also Dade [81] observed, an RS^{-1}-module, e.g. E\otimes RS^{-1}\approx ES^{-1}, is injective as an RS^{-1}-module iff it is injective as an R-module. Thus, injectives localize to injectives for Noetherian rings. (This is in Kaplansky’s book [74],pp.162–163.) However, Dade showed that in general an injective R-module E does not “localize” to an injective module. (See 3.17B.) However: E(R/P) is an injective R_{P}-module. (See 16.12.)
See Faith [72b], Facchini-Puninski [95], and Puninski-Wisbauer [96] for additional results on \Sigma -injective modules. Cf.7.32s

A prime P of a commutative ring R is an associated prime provided that P=x^{\perp } for some 0\neq x\in R. Then \mathbf{Ass\,R} denotes the set of all such prime ideals. (See 6.39s and 1.11 (2).) Ass R is called the assassinator of R.

statement.label: 3.16C. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a commutative ring R:

def.p: There exists a finite family \mathcal{P} of Noetherian prime ideals so that the canonical map R\rightarrow \prod _{P\in \mathcal{P}}R_{P} is an embedding.
The set Ass R is a finite set of Noetherian primes whose union is the set of zero divisors of R.
There is a flat embedding of R into a Noetherian ring T.
R has Noetherian quotient ring Q(R).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Item 4 is Beck’s Corollary 3.10. We come back to these ideas in 16.33.

sec.title: Dade’s Theorem
sec.p: The next theorem gives a sufficient condition e.g. R Noetherian, for localization to preserve injective modules.

statement.label: 3.17A.
statement.p: Dade’s Theorem. If (1) R is a coherent ring (see 6.6 below), (2) every ideal of R is countably generated, and (3) S is a multiplicatively closed subset such that for all finitely generated ideals I, any chain of ideals
terminates for any s\in S, where (I:s)=\{r\in R\,|\,sr\in I\}, then ES^{-1} is injective (both as R and RS^{-1} modules) for any injective R-module E.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Note that requiring the acc \perp on annihilators in R/I suffices for (3) of 3.17A. Cf. Mori domains 9.4s.

sec.p: The next theorem shows that in general injective modules are not preserved under localization.

statement.label: 3.17B. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a commutative Noetherian ring, then the polynomial ring R=A[X] satisfies
when X is a countable set of commuting variables but not if X is uncountable. Moreover, (LI) fails for a factor ring of A[X] when X is countable.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Matlis [83] gave other examples based on an example of Vasconcelos.

sec.title: When Cyclic Modules Are Injective
sec.p: A ring R is right PCI if all proper cyclic modules (= cyclic modules \not \approx R) are injective. If all simple right modules are injective then R is a right V-ring, Cf. 3.17A. A right PCI ring is a right V-ring,

statement.label: 3.18A.
statement.p: Osofsky’s Theorem ([64]) If all cyclic right R-modules are injective, then R is semisimple Artinian.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Cf. Theorem 13.14A.

sec.p: A ring R is right (semi-) hereditary if every (f\cdot g) right ideal is projective, e.g. semisimple rings, and PID’s are hereditary, and valuation domains are semihereditary.
Osofsky’s theorem was the inspiration for the following:

statement.label: 3.18B.
statement.p: Boyle’s Theorem [74]. A right and left Noetherian ring R is right PCI iff R is semisimple or a right hereditary V-domain. Moreover, R is then left PCI.

sec.p: And Boyle’s Theorem inspired:

statement.label: 3.18C.
statement.p: Damiano [79]-Faith [73] Theorem. Every right PCI ring R is either semisimple, or a right Noetherian hereditary simple domain.

sec.p: The author (loc.cit.) proved R is either semisimple or a right semihereditary simple domain. Cf. Yue Chi Ming [81], who proves this assuming proper cyclic right modules are “p-injective.”

sec.title: When Simple Modules Are Injective: V-Rings
sec.p:
The radical of a module M is the intersection rad M of its maximal submodules.⁠22
For M=R, this is just the Jacobson radical of R. See 2.6s.

statement.label: 3.19A.
statement.p: Villamayor’s Theorem. A ring R is called a right V-ring provided that the following equivalent conditions hold:

def.p: Every simple right R-module is injective,
Every right ideal I is an intersection of maximal right ideals, equivalently, rad (R/I)=0,
rad M=0 for every right R-module M.

sec.p: These rings were named in honor of Villamayor who introduced the concept (Cf. Faith [72], p.356 and Michler-Villamayor [73]). Since every simple module is quasiinjective, then every right QI-ring is a right V-ring. Menal and Faith [95] showed that R is a right V-ring iff there is a semisimple module W so that annihilation in W and back in R is 1-1 on the set of right ideals. Tsuda [00] generalized this to V-modules” presently defined.

statement.label: 3.19B.
statement.p: Kaplansky’s Theorem. A commutative ring R is a V-ring iff R is a von Neumann regular ring (see §4); equivalently R_{m} is a field for every maximal ideal m.

sec.p: For a generalization, see Max Rings Theorems following 3.32. In response to my inquiry, Professor Kaplansky [94] wrote that 3.19B “fell into the public domain”, i.e., unpublished.

A module M is a V-module provided that every proper submodule is an intersection of maximal submodules. (Cf. Hirano [81] who studied V-modules, also (von Neumann) regular modules defined by Zelmanowitz [72].)

statement.label: 3.19C. Theorem
statement.p: A module M over a commutative ring R is a V-module iff every localization M_{p} of M at a maximal ideal is semisimple.

def.p: This generalizes Kaplansky’s Theorem 3.19B.

Camillo and Yousif (ibid) also study semi-V-rings, i.e., rings R such that every nonzero factor module contains a nonzero V-module. Inter alia, they prove that a commutative ring R is a semi-F-ring iff R/J is von Neumann regular and J=\mathrm{rad} is T-nilpotent. See Remark 3.32B.

statement.p: Faith [67,72B]-Ornstein [68] Theorem. Every right Goldie right V-ring R is a finite product of simple right V-rings.

sec.p: See e.g. Faith [81], p.357.

sec.title: Cozzens’ \boldsymbol{V}-Domains
sec.p: Cozzens [70] and Koifman [70] supplied the first known examples of right V-domains that were not fields, namely, the ring R=k[y,D] of differential polynomials over a (Kolchin) universal differential field k with respect to a derivation D. This ring has a unique simple R-module, namely k, and it is injective. Other examples are localizations of the ring of twisted polynomials over an algebraic closed field (Cozzens [70], cf. Osofsky [71], Faith [72, 81], pp.361–362, Faith [86a], and Resco [87]. See Komarnitskii [97] for the solution of a problem of Cozzens–Faith.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Osofsky [72] gave the first examples of V-domains with infinitely many simple modules over fields of characteristic p>0, and Cozzens, using different methods, extended the results to characteristic 0.

sec.title: Projective Modules over Local or Semilocal Rings, or Semihereditary Rings

statement.p: Theorem Of Kaplansky ([58A]). Over a local ring R, every projective R-module is free.

sec.p: The proof uses Kaplansky’s theorem 3.1A.

statement.label: 3.22A.
statement.p: Cartan-Eilenberg Theorem [58]. R is right hereditary iff every factor module of every injective right R-module is injective and iff every submodule of a projective right R-module is projective.

statement.label: 3.22B. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right semihereditary iff each f\cdot g submodule of a projective right R-module is projective.

sec.p: Theorem 3.22B does not match up with 3.22A: what about factor modules of injectives? Gupta’s Theorem 4.2E supplies the missing link: R is right semihereditary iff every factor of every injective is weak \aleph _{0}-injective (see 4.2E).

statement.label: 3.22C. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right hereditary, then each projective module, hence each submodule of a free module, is isomorphic to a direct sum of right ideals.

statement.label: 3.23A. Theorem
statement.p: Any projective right or left R-module over a right semihereditary ring is isomorphic to a direct sum of f\cdot g one-sided ideals.

sec.p: Albrecht’s theorem was proved by Kaplansky [58a] for commutative (or hereditary) R (and conjectured by him). A ring is a right (semi)fir if every (f\cdot g) right ideal is free of unique rank. The free algebra in n non-commuting variables over a field is a fir (cf. Cohn [71b]), hence a hereditary ring.

statement.label: 3.23B. Corollary
statement.p: Over a semifir R, every projective R-module is free. (More generally see Cohn [71b], Th.0.2.9; Cohn [85], Th. 0.3.7.)

statement.label: 3.23C.
statement.p: Hinohara’s Theorem [62]. Over a commutative semilocal ring with no nontrivial idempotents, every projective module is free.

statement.label: 3.24A. Theorem
statement.p: All projective modules over the free monoid or free group \Pi over a PID are free.

statement.label: 3.24B. Theorem
statement.p: A group ring RG is a semifir iff R is a sfield and G is a locally free group (i.e., any f\cdot g subgroup is free).

sec.title: Serre’s Conjecture, the Quillen-Suslin Solution and Seshadri’s Theorem

statement.p: Serre’s conjecture on the freedom of any f\cdot g projective module P over the polynomial ring k[x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}] in n commuting variables over a field k was proved by Quillen [76], using a lemma of Horrocks, and independently by Suslin [76]. The conjecture previously was verified for n\leq 2 by Seshadri [68].

sec.title: Bass’ Theorem on When Big Projectives Are Free
sec.p: If P_{R} is projective then P is uniformly big if for every proper ideal A of R, then P/PA requires as many generators as P, i.e., if P is generated by \alpha elements then P/PA cannot be generated by fewer than \alpha elements. Any free R-module is uniformly big.

statement.p: Bass’ Theorem ([63]) If R is right Noetherian modulo its Jacobson radical, then all uniformly big projective right R-modules are free.

sec.p: A right R-module G is a generator if there exists an onto R-homomorphism G^{n}\rightarrow R, equivalently G^{n}\approx R\oplus X for some R-module X, where n\in \omega .

statement.label: 3.27. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a Noetherian commutative ring with no non-trivial idempotents, then all non-f\cdot g projectives are free.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) Cf. Hinohara’s Theorem 3.23C. (2) O’Neill [92] (Prop. 0.1, p. 272) corrected an example in Bass [63].

statement.label: 3.28. Theorem
statement.p: If P is a projective right R-module such that P/(P\,\cdot \,rad\,R) is a free right R/radR module, then P is free.

statement.label: 3.29. Theorem
statement.p: If R/rad\,R is a finite product of skew fields, and if every projective right R-module is a generator, then every projective right R-module is free.

sec.p: These all generalize Kaplansky’s theorem 3.21.

sec.title: Projective Modules over Semiperfect Rings
sec.p: R is semiperfect if every f\cdot g right R-module M has a projective cover P(M) in a sense dual to E(M). The concept is left-right symmetric:

statement.label: 3.30. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions:

def.p: R is semiperfect,
\overline{R}=R/radR is semisimple and idempotents of \overline{R} lift (to idempotents of R).
R=\oplus _{i=1}^{n}e_{i}R, where 1=e_{1}+\cdots +e_{n},e_{i}e_{j}=0\quad \forall i\neq j,e_{i} is an idempotent and e_{i}Re_{i} is a local ring, i=1,\ldots ,n,
The left right-symmetry of (SP3).

sec.p: Note: Let J=\mathrm{rad}\,R (=the Jacobson radical). Then in (SP3) V_{i}=e_{i}R/e_{i}J is a simple R-module, and the canonical map e_{i}R\rightarrow V_{i} is the projective cover of V_{i},i=1,\ldots ,n.

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: A principal indecomposable right R-module is one \approx e_{i}R for some i in 3.30, a right prindec, or principal cyclic module.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: R is called a lift/rad ring if idempotents of R/\mathrm{rad}\ R lift. Jacobson’s SBI-rings in his book [56,64], p. 53, are lift/rad rings. Any ring R with nil radical is classically known to be a lift/rad ring (loc.cit.). Cf. 3.54f.

sec.title: Bass’ Perfect Rings
sec.p: A ring R is left perfect if every left R-module has a projective cover P(M).

statement.label: 3.31. Theorem
statement.p: A left perfect ring R is characterized by the equivalent conditions:

def.p: R has the dcc on principal right ideals.

R/rad\ R is semisimple and rad R is right vanishing (=\mathbf{left}\ T\mathbf{{-}nilpotent} in Bass [60]) in the sense that any infinite sequence \{x_{1}x_{2}\ldots x_{n}\}_{n=1}^{\infty } of products of elements of rad R terminates in zeros.
Every flat left R-module is projective.
R is semilocal, and rad R is right vanishing.
R is semilocal, and every nonzero left module has a maximal submodule (=R is left max).
Every left R-module has a projective cover.

sec.p: Regarding (P3), we have anticipated the definition of a flat module introduced in §4. By Govorov-Lazard Theorem 4.A:
(P3)\Leftrightarrow (P3^{\prime }) Every direct limit of projective left modules is projective.

statement.label: 3.32. Corollary
statement.p: When R is (semi)perfect, every (f\cdot g) projective right (left) R-module P is isomorphic to a direct sum of principal indecomposable R-modules each of which is isomorphic to e_{i}R (resp. Re_{i}) for some i,i=1,\ldots ,n.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Mueller [70b] showed that any projective module P over a semiperfect ring has the structure stated in 3.32; (2) Brauer’s theory of blocks can be generalized to perfect rings (from Artinian). See Faith [76], p.171, 22.34; (3) Also see Mares [63] and Kasch-Mares [66] on semiperfect (resp. perfect) modules, i.e., modules such that every factor module of M (resp. of a direct sum of copies of M) has a projective cover. Cf. Nicholson [75b]; (4) See Oberst and Schneider [71] for a characterization of when every f\cdot p module has a projective cover (R/\mathrm{rad}\ R is VNR and idempotents can be lifted). Cf. Meyberg and Zimmermann-Huisgen [77]. Also see F-semiperfect rings, 6.52s.

sec.title: Theorems of Björk and Jonah
sec.p: Björk [69] showed that (P1) is equivalent to the dcc on f\cdot g right ideals, and Jonah [70] showed this is equivalent to the condition that all left R-modules satisfy the acc on cyclic submodules! Moreover Björk proved that all right R-modules over a left perfect ring have the dec on f\cdot g submodules; more precisely, if an R-module M over any ring R satisfies the dcc on cyclic submodules, then M satisfies the dcc on f\cdot g submodules.

sec.title: Max Ring Theorems of Hamsher, Koifman, and Renault
sec.p: A ring R is a right max ring if every right R-module M has a maximal submodule. Any right perfect ring is right \max (Bass [60]) (and so is any right V-ring). Hamsher [67], Koifman [70] and Renault [67] prove that a commutative ring R is \max iff R has T-nilpotent Jacobson radical J and R/J is VNR. Moreover, Faith [95a] showed that R is \max iff R_{m} is perfect for each maximal ideal m (equivalently, iff R is locally a \max ring. Cf.3.19B). Any right \max ring has left vanishing Jacobson radical J (see 3.31); and conversely if R/J is right \max (see Hamsher et al, op.cit.).

statement.label: 3.32A. Remark.
statement.p: Hamsher et al thus answered a question of Bass for commutative rings: R is perfect iff R is a \max ring with no infinite set of orthogonal idempotents. Koifman [70] and Cozzens [70] disproved Bass’ question in general: V-domains not fields are counterexamples (Cf. sup.3.21).

statement.label: 3.32B. Remark.
statement.p: The Hamsher-Koifman-Renault Max Ring Theorem stated preceding 3.32A above shows that a commutative ring R is a semi-V-ring (see 3.19D) iff R is a max ring.

statement.label: 3.32C. Theorem
statement.p: The following conditions are equivalent on a right R module M.

def.p: Every submodule N\neq 0 has a maximal submodule.
rad^{\alpha }M=0 for some ordinal \alpha ,i.e.M has transfinitely nilpotent radical.
For every ordinal \beta , either rad^{\beta }M has a maximal submodule or=0.

statement.label: 3.32D. Theorem
statement.p: For a ring R the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is a right max ring.
For each simple right R-module V every nonzero submodule of its injective hull E(V) has a maximal submodule.
Every subdirectly irreducible nonzero quasi-injective module has a maximal submodule.

sec.title: Flat Covers Exist
sec.p: Enochs [81] conjectured that every right R-module M over any ring R has a flat cover, i.e. an epimorphism f:F\rightarrow M where F is flat and \ker f is superfluous. This was verified by Bican, Bashir and Enochs [01].

sec.title: The Socle Series of a Module and Loewy Modules
sec.p: The socle of a right R-module, denoted \mathrm{soc}(M), is either 0, or the sum of all simple (or minimal) submodules. (The terminology “socle” owes to the French, probably Dieudonné [42].)
The socle series of a module M is defined inductively. The second socle is the submodule \mathrm{soc}_{2}(M)\supseteq \mathrm{soc}(M) such that

(Possibly \mathrm{soc}_{2}(M)=\mathrm{soc}(M).) By transfinite induction one may define \mathrm{soc}_{\beta }(M) for a limit ordinal \beta as the union \bigcup _{\alpha <\beta }\mathrm{soc}_{\alpha }(M), and
for every ordinal \alpha . The least ordinal \alpha such that
is called the socle length of M. If M has socle length \alpha , and if M=\mathrm{soc}_{\alpha }(M), then M is said to be a Loewy module of Loewy length \alpha .

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: The concept of a Loewy module dates back to Loewy [05] and [17]. See Fuchs [69b] and Shores [74] for a bit of history. (I summarized a bit of this on p.176 of my Algebra II.)

sec.title: Semi-Artinian Rings and Modules
sec.p: A right R-module M is semi-Artinian provided that for every submodule N\neq M,\, \mathrm{soc}(M/N)\neq 0. A ring R is right semi-Artinian provided that R is a semi-Artinian right R-module.

statement.label: 3.33A. Theorem.
statement.p: (1) A right R-module M is semi-Artinian iff M is a Loewy module; (2) A ring R is right semi-Artinian iff every right R-module is Loewy.

statement.label: 3.33B. Corollary.
statement.p: A ring R is right semi-Artinian iff every nonzero right R-module M has essential socle.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Right semi-Artinian is called “right socular” in my Algebra II, p.156, Prop.22.10.

statement.label: 3.33C. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is left perfect iff R is semiperfect and right semi-Artinian.

statement.label: 3.33D. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right semi-Artinian iff R/J is right semi-Artinian and J is right vanishing, where J=rad\,R.

statement.label: 3.33E. Corollary.
statement.p: A commutative ring R is semi-Artinian iff J is vanishing and R/J is VNR and semi-Artinian.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: If R is commutative semi-Artinian then R is a \max ring by 3.33E and the Max Ring Theorems stated above. See Remark 3.33G below.

statement.label: 3.33F. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right Loewy of Loewy length n<\infty then R is left Loewy of Loewy length \leq 2^{n}.

def.p: von Neumann regularity (= VNR) is defined in §4: Semi-Artinian VNR rings have equal right and left Loewy length, ibid.
Osofsky [74] constructs two-sided perfect rings whose left and right Loewy lengths are two arbitrary cardinals.
Fuchs (1970) constructed commutative VNR Loewy rings of length \beta +1, for any ordinal \beta . See Camillo-Fuller [74], Theorem 2.2.
Any right Loewy ring with acc on (left or right) primitive ideals is a left max ring.
Any right Loewy PI-ring is a left max ring.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: There exist two-sided Loewy VNR rings that are not max rings, ibid. p.78. By 3.33F, R is also right max in 3.33H.

sec.title: The Perlis Radical and the Jacobson Radical
sec.p: Call a one-sided ideal I of a ring R quasi-regular if (1+x)^{-1} exists for all x\in I (e.g. any nil ideal is quasi-regular). The maximal quasi-regular (q.r.) ideal P(R) exists, contains all q.r. one-sided ideals and equals J(R), the Jacobson radical of R (Jacobson [45a]). Originally P(R) was called the Perlis-Jacobson radical, after Sam Perlis (my teacher and Ph.D. advisor at Purdue University, circa 1951–5) who showed that P(R) is the maximal nilpotent ideal of a finite dimensional algebra R over a field k (Perlis [42]). Jacobson carried the theory through for arbitrary rings, and showed that P(R)=J(R) is the intersection of all primitive ideals of R.

sec.title: The Frattini Subgroup of a Group
sec.p: The concept of the radical \Phi (G) of a group G is a much older concept than that of a module. Indeed in groups, the intersection \Phi (G) of the maximal subgroups of a group G was introduced by Frattini in 1885! (Vide). Of course, for Abelian G,\Phi (G)=\mathrm{rad}G. Frattini proved that for a finite group G,\Phi (G) is a nilpotent group. Moreover, a theorem of Wielandt states that G is nilpotent iff the derived group [G,G]\subseteq \Phi (G) (see, for example, Huppert [67], pp.268–271, esp. Sätze 3.6 and 3.11).

sec.title: Krull’s Intersection Theorem and Jacobson’s Conjecture

statement.label: 3.34. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative Noetherian ring, and I is an ideal \neq R, then there exists a\in I so that
Furthermore, if R is a domain, or if I is contained in the Jacobson radical J of R, then I^{\omega }=0.

sec.p: For proofs see [Z-S], vol. I, pp.215–216. Or Kaplansky [70], Theorem 79.

statement.label: Jacobson’s Conjecture.
statement.p: If R is a 2-sided Noetherian ring, does the Krull Intersection Theorem still hold, i.e., is J^{\omega }=0?

def.p: Jategaonkar [74b] proved the conjecture for two-sided fully bounded Noetherian (= FBN) rings, and Cauchon [74] for left Noetherian right FBN rings (Cf. Krause [72]. Also see Jans’ Theorem 7.49);
Gordon [74] proved inter alia that any FBN ring embeds in an Artinian ring;
The answer was shown to be negative for one-sided Noetherian R by Herstein [65], and Jategaonkar [68] for a right PID;

It is known for any left or right Noetherian ring that J is transfinitely nilpotent in the sense that J^{\alpha }=0 for some ordinal power \alpha (Jacobson [45a], Theorem 11). (Cf. Jategaonkar [69], who shows that \alpha may be of arbitrarily large cardinal. Also see the Remark and Note preceding 13.17.)

sec.title: Nakayama’s Lemma
sec.p: A famous result first due to Azumaya [51] in a special case is:

statement.p:
Nakayama’s Lemma [51]. If M is finitely generated R-module over any ring R then MI=M implies M=0 for any right ideal I
eq 0 such that 1-a is regular for some a\in I (e.g. any ideal I
eq 0 contained in the Jacobson radical or any ideal I
eq 0 contained in an integral domain).

sec.p: Azumaya’s and Nakayama’s papers were reviewed by I. Kaplansky in Math. Reviews 12, 669g and 13,313f (reprinted in Reviews in Ring Theory, vol. 1, #8.01.001 and #2.01.007). He also reviewed Azumaya [48] and [50].

Nakayama’s lemma is ubiquitous in module and ring theory, attaining a status something like Zorn’s lemma. (Seriously.) It is at the basis of parts of many proofs in ring theory, e.g. it can be used in the proof of the Krull Intersection Theorem.

sec.title: The Jacobson Radical and Jacobson-Hilbert Rings
sec.p: Krull [50] pointed out the relationship between Hilbert’s Nullstellensatz and the Jacobson radical. It hinges on the question: when is the Jacobson radical of a finitely generated algebra over a field a nil ideal? This holds true for commutative algebras (Krull [51], Goldman [51]), algebras over nondenumerable fields (Amitsur [56]), and algebras satisfying a polynomial identity (Amitsur [57]). The latter theorem is related to a non-commutative Hilbert Nullstellensatz, and many of the foregoing results on Jacobson and Hilbert rings are generalized by Amitsur and Procesi [66] and Procesi [67].
A commutative ring R is a Jacobson-Hilbert ring if R satisfies the equivalent conditions:

def.p: Every factor ring R/I has nil Jacobson radical.
Every prime ideal is an intersection of maximal ideals.
Every maximal ideal of the polynomial ring R[x] contracts to a maximal ideal of R.
Every maximal ideal of R[x] contains a monic polynomial.
If the quotient field Q(R/P) of a prime ideal is finitely generated over R/P, then P is maximal.

sec.p: Note: Krull [51] called these rings Jacobson rings, and Goldman [51] called them Hilbert rings. (H4) is a combination of an exercise in Kaplansky [74], and an observation of Faith [89a], i.e., a maximal ideal M of R[x] is monic iff M contracts to a maximal ideal of R.

statement.label: 3.36. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is Jacobson-Hilbert iff the polynomial ring R[x] is Jacobson-Hilbert.

sec.p: Note: The power series ring R[[x]] over any ring R is never Hilbert. Cf. 9.25B.
A ring R is Jacobson-Hilbert if for every prime ideal P,R/P is semiprimitive. This agrees with the above definition for commutative R.

statement.label: 3.36B. Generalized or Weak Nullstellensatz
statement.title: (Goldman [51], Krull [51]).
statement.p: If R is a Jacobson-Hilbert ring, then any f\cdot g R-algebra A is also, and the contraction P=M\cap R of a maximal ideal M of A is a maximal ideal of R. Moreover, A/M is a finite dimensional field extension of R/P.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Eisenbud [96], p.132, Theorem 4.19.

statement.label: 3.36C. Remark.
statement.p: See 11.13 and the following 3.36D for another “weak Null-stellensatz.”

statement.label: 3.36D. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a simple Artinian ring, any simple module V over the polynomial ring R[x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}] in n variables has finite length over R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Goodearl and Warfield [89], p.270, Theorem 5.6.

sec.title: Fully Bounded and FBN Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right fully bounded (= \mathbf{right}\,\mathbf{FB}) if for every prime ideal P, every essential right ideal of R/P contains an nonzero ideal of R/P (see sup.5.SE.) A ring R is right FBN if R is right FB and right Noetherian. An FBN ring is one which is right and left FBN.

statement.label: 3.36E. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a fully bounded Noetherian Jacobson ring, then any simple right module M over the polynomial ring R[x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}] in n variables is annihilated by a maximal ideal of R, and M is semisimple of finite length as an R-module.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Goodearl-Warfield [89], p.276, Corollary 15.11.

statement.label: 3.36F. Theorem
statement.p: Let K and L be field extensions of a field F and suppose
Then R=K\otimes _{F}L is a Hilbert ring in which every maximal ideal has rank n.

statement.label: 3.36G. Remark.
statement.p: The proof of this depends on Vámos’ Proposition 4, ibid., p.276, which implies that K[X_{1},\ldots ,X_{n}]S^{-1} for S=F[X_{1},\ldots ,X_{n}]\backslash \{0\} is a Hilbert ring in which every maximal ideal has rank n.

sec.title: When Nil Implies Nilpotency
sec.p: If I is a nil ideal, when is I nilpotent in the sense that I^{n}=0 for some n\geq 1, that is, all products x_{1}\ldots x_{n} of n elements of I are =0? The index of nilpotency is the least exponent n such that I^{n}=0.

statement.label: 3.37. Theorem
statement.p: If k is a field, then any multiplicative closed nil submonoid of k_{n}\approx End_{k}k^{n} is nilpotent of index \leq n.

sec.p: This follows from the next theorem.

statement.label: 3.38. Theorem
statement.p: If M is an R-module of length n, then any multiplicative nil submonoid of End M_{R} is nilpotent of index \leq n.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See 3.69 below.

sec.title: Shock’s Theorem
sec.p: Recall for any subset A of a semigroup R with 0, the left annihilator ^{\perp } A= \{r\in R\,|\,ra=0\ \forall a\in A\}. Similarly for A^{\perp }. And, as is the case for rings, {\perp }\mathrm{acc} (resp. {\mathrm{acc}}\perp ) denotes the ace on left (right) annihilators.

statement.p: Shock’s Theorem [71B] Let R be a semigroup with 0 and {acc}\perp . If R has a non-nilpotent nil submonoid, N, then (1) there is a set \{a_{i}\}_{i\in \omega } of elements of R so that

where A_{n}=\{a_{i}\}_{i\geq n};(2) If R is a ring, then \{a_{i}\}_{i\in \omega } can be chosen so that \{a_{i}R\}_{i\in \omega } are independent right ideals, i.e., the sum \oplus _{i\in \omega }a_{i}R is direct.

sec.p: Shock’s theorem implies the next corollary and the following theorems of Levitzki, Herstein-Small and Lanski.

statement.label: 3.40. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is a semigroup with 0, and R satisfies the acc on right and left annihilators (={acc}\perp and\ dcc{\perp }), then every nil multiplicative submonoid of R is nilpotent.

statement.label: 3.41. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a ring with {acc}\perp and {dcc}\perp , then any nil subring is nilpotent.

statement.label: 3.42. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right Goldie ring, then every multiplicative nil submonoid S of R is nilpotent.

statement.label: 3.43. Remarks.
statement.p: 1) Herstein and Small proved this for nil subrings S\ (loc.cit.), and Levitzki proved it in [45] for right and left Noetherian rings in answer to a problem of Köthe. Finally Goldie [60] proved that nil subrings are nilpotent in one-sided Noetherian rings. (See Goodearl and Warfield [89], p.98 for additional references); 2) In their Addendum to [64], Herstein and Small [66] point out that an example of Saşiada shows that nil does not imply nilpotency in one-sided \mathrm{acc}\perp rings; 3) Lenagan [73] showed that nil implies nilpotency for subrings of rings with Krull dimension (see 14.29D). Moreover, Gordon, Lenagan and Robson [73] announced that the prime radical of a ring R with Krull dimensions is nilpotent, a result (14.30A) that appears in R. Gordon and Robson [73]. (Cf. Goldie and Small [72].)

sec.title: Kurosch’s Problem
sec.p: Kurosch’s Problem (=KP): If A is an algebraic algebra over a field k, is every finitely generated subalgebra finitely dimensional? The answer is negative (see below) but theorems of Kaplansky [46] and Levitzki [46] answered (KP) positively for algebraic algebras of bounded degree (nil algebras of bounded index of nilpotency): thus every finite subset generates a finite dimensional (resp. nilpotent) subalgebra. In particular, if a finitely generated ring satisfies the identity x^{n}=0, for a fixed integer n\geq 1, then the ring is nilpotent.

sec.title: The Nagata-Higman Theorem
sec.p: A related theorem of Nagata-Higman states that in any associative algebra A over a field k of characteristic p that any subalgebra B satisfying the identity x^{n}=0 for an integer n

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Graham Higman [56] proved it in greater generality. However, in his review (MR, 92d:13023) of Formanek’s Survey [90], E. Zel’manov states (without a reference!) that J. Dubnov and V. Ivanov proved the Nagata-Higman Theorem in 1943.

sec.p: Note if N is the commutative algebra over a field k of characteristic p with an infinite basis \{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty } such that x_{i}^{p}=0\ \forall i, then N is nil but not nilpotent.

sec.title: \aleph _{0}-Categorical Nil Rings Are Nilpotent
sec.p: A ring R is \aleph _{0}-categorical if there exists a unique countable model for R.

statement.label: Theorem.
statement.p: (Cherlin [80]). Any \aleph _{0}-categorical associative nilring N is nilpotent.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This answered a question of Baldwin and Rose who proved:

statement.label: Theorem
statement.title: (Baldwin and Rose [77]).
statement.p: Any \aleph _{0}-categorical ring R has nil Jacobson radical.

statement.label: Corollary.
statement.p: Any \aleph _{0}-categorical ring R has nilpotent Jacobson radical.

sec.title: The Golod-Shafarevitch Theorem
sec.p: Jacobson [64], p.260 also cites the example of Golod of a finitely generated nonnilpotent nil algebra B over a field F. Thus, B is not finite dimensional (the main point of the example). Any such example has to be non-commutative: that is, nil \Longrightarrow nilpotency for finitely generated commutative nil algebras. A theorem of Golod-Shafarevitch enables one to find over any countable field an infinite dimensional nil algebra generated by three elements, thus answering (KP) in the negative. For an exposition, see Herstein [68], p.192.

sec.title: Some Amitsur Theorems on the Jacobson Radical
sec.p: We now cite some fundamental theorems of Amitsur on the Jacobson radical.

statement.label: 3.43A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is an algebra over a field k of cardinal |k|>dim_{k}R, then the Jacobson radical rad R is a nil ideal.

statement.label: 3.43B. Theorem
statement.p: Under the same conditions as 3.43A, R is an algebraic algebra iff every right or left regular element (i.e.,non zero-divisor) is a unit.
Corollary to 3.43A. If R is a f\cdot g (qua ring) algebra over an uncountable field k, then rad R is nil.
Corollary to 3.43A. If N is a nil algebra over an uncountable field k, then the n\times n matrix algebra N_{n} is a nil algebra.

sec.p: Cf. Jacobson [65], p.20ff. Also see 3.50 below.

statement.label: 3.46. Theorem
statement.p: If R is an algebraic algebra over an uncount able field k, then the n\times n matrix algebra R_{n} is algebraic.

sec.p: We remark on another theorem of Amitsur; a consequence of 3.43A, namely:

statement.label: 3.47. Theorem
statement.p: If k is a field of characteristic 0 not algebraic over \mathbb{Q}, e.g., if k is uncountable, then the group algebra kG of any group G is semiprimitive.

sec.p: See Jacobson [64], p.254, Theorem 3 and Corollary.

statement.label: 3.48. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a ring, then rad R[x]=N[x] for the polynomial ring R[x] and a nil ideal N of R. If R is an algebra over an uncountable field k, then N[x] is the maximal nil ideal of R[x].

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Smoktunowicz and Puczylowski [01] show (when k is countable) N[x] need not be nil. Cf. 3.50 below.

statement.label: 3.49A. Corollary.
statement.p: If R has no nil ideals \neq 0, then R[x] is semiprimitive.

statement.label: 3.49B. Corollary
statement.p: If R is commutative, then rad R[x]= N[x] where N is the maximal nil ideal of R.

statement.label: 3.49C. Remark.
statement.p: By 3.49A, R[x] is semiprimitive for any commutative domain, i.e. R need not be semiprimitive for R[x] to be.

sec.title: Koethe’s Radical and Conjecture
sec.p: Let K_{\ell }(R) denote the sum of all nil left ideals of a ring R. If x\in K_{\ell }(R) and r\in R, then ra is nilpotent, say (ra)^{n}=0, hence (ar)^{n+1}=0, that is, ar is nilpotent. This shows the well-known fact that K_{\ell }(R) is an \mathrm{ideal}=K_{r}(R). If K_{\ell }(R) is nil, then it is called the Köthe nil radical, denoted K(R).
Let N(R) denote the sum of all nil ideals of R, and consider the property:
(K1) The sum of two nil left ideals of a ring R is nil.
The truth of (K1) for all rings R is called Köthe’s conjecture and is equivalent to:
(K2) K(R)=N(R) for all rings R.
(K3) K(R)=0 iff N(R)=0 for all rings R.
(K4) N(R_{n})=N(R)_{n}, for all n\times n matrix rings R_{n} over R.
Then (K1)-(K4) are equivalent. Cf. Rowen [89], 2.6.35.

statement.label: 3.50. Theorem.
statement.p: Amitsur’s Theorem [56a, 56b, 57b, 59, 71, 01]. If R is an algebra over an uncountable field k, then (K1)—(K4) hold, and moreover, the Jacobson radical J(R[X])=N(R)[X]=N(R[X]), for the polynomial ring R[X].

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See 3.43, 3.45, and 3.48. Cf. Rowen loc.cit.

statement.label: 3.50A. Remark.
statement.p: Kegel [63] proved that the sum of two nilpotent rings is nilpotent, and Kegel [64] asked the same question for nil or locally nil subrings. The latter question (for locally nil) was given a counter-example by Kelarev [93].

sec.p: Cf. Kelarev [97] where this question and related ones are discussed. Also see:

statement.label: 3.50B.
statement.p: Klein’s Theorem [94]. The sum of finitely many nil ideals of bounded index is nil of bounded index.

sec.title: A General Wedderburn Theorem
sec.p: A right R-module M is balanced if the canonical homomorphism of R into the biendomorphism (bicentralizer, bicommutator) ring of M is surjective. The classical Wedderburn-Artin Theorem states that every minimal right ideal M of a simple right Artinian ring R is balanced, in which case R has a representation as a full ring of linear transformations on a finite dimensional vector space M over the (generally noncommuntative) field D=\mathrm{End}M_{R}. A theorem of Morita [58] applies to any ring R: any generator M of the category mod -R is balanced, and M is finitely generated projective as a canonical left module over B=EndM_{R}. (See the author’s paper [66b] for an elementary proof employing just linear and matrix algebra. Also see “Snapshots” (“Rieffel, Lang, Smale and Me”).) Now, if R is any simple ring, then it is a triviality to verify that any nonzero right ideal M is a generator of mod -R, so R\rightarrow \mathrm{End}_{B}M is surjective. Moreover, simplicity of R implies the kernel is zero, R\approx \mathrm{End}_{B}M, and so Morita’s theorem implies the General Wedderburn Theorem of Rieffel [65]. Then, finite projectivity of M over B yields an idempotent e in the full n\times n matrix ring B_{n}, for an appropriate integer n, a ring isomorphism R\approx eB_{n}e, and B_{n}eB_{n}=B_{n} so Morita’s theorem implies that of Hart [67]. In the case M is a minimal right ideal of R, then B is a sfield by Schur’s lemma, so then M is a finite dimensional (by the finite generation of M over B) vector space over B. In this case, M is free over B, say M\approx B^{n}, and then R is isomorphic to the n\times n matrix ring B_{n} so Morita’s theorem implies the Principal Wedderburn [08]-Artin [27] Theorem. Moreover, if M is a uniform right ideal, then B is a right Ore domain with a right quotient sfield D (see 6.26f), and R has a full right quotient ring Q(R)\approx D_{m}, for some integer m (Theorem of Goldie [58] and Lesieur-Croisot [59], see 3.13).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: For more on balanced modules, see 13.29–30 (Theorems of Camillo and Fuller).

sec.title: Koh’s Schur Lemma
sec.p: In this connection, a theorem of Koh [66] is of interest: If a ring R has a maximal annihilator right ideal I, say I=x^{\perp }, then B=\mathrm{End}(R/I)_{R} is an integral domain \approx \mathrm{End}(xR)_{R}. If in addition, R is a simple ring, then Morita’s theorem on balanced modules applies, namely, U=xR is f\cdot g projective over an integral domain B, and R\approx \mathrm{End}_{B}U canonically. (See, e.g. Faith [72], p.350, 724-25.)

sec.title: Categories
sec.p: We shall not give here the somewhat tedious definitions of a category C, the morphisms of C, the functors T:C\rightsquigarrow D between categories, the natural equivalence of two functors

the equivalence C\approx D of categories, all of which are due to Eilenberg and Mac Lane [45], and are to be found in many places in the literature (e.g. my Algebra [72], p. 72ff (vol. I), Freyd [64], Mitchell [65], among others).

sec.title: Morita’s Theorem
sec.p: The categories mod-R and mod-S over two rings R and S consist of the right modules over these rings, and the morphisms of mod-R are the homomorphisms f:M\rightarrow N between them.

statement.p: Morita’s Theorem [58]. The categories mod-R and mod-S over two rings R and S are equivalent iff there exists a f\cdot g projective generator P of mod-R and a ring isomorphism S\approx EndP_{R}. In this case we write mod-R\approx mod{-}S.

sec.p: In this case, \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(P,-) induces the category equivalence \mathrm{mod}{-}R\rightsquigarrow \mathrm{mod}{-}S, and \mathrm{Hom}(P^{\star },-) is the inverse equivalence, where P^{\star }=\mathrm{Hom}_{R}(P,R). Cf. my Algebra [72,81], p.450ff. Also see Arhangel’skii, Goodearl, and Huisgen-Zimmermann [97].

The condition \mathrm{mod}{-}R\approx \mathrm{mod}{-}S is reflexive, symmetric and transitive; R and S are then said to be Morita Equivalent or Similar. Notation: R\sim S. If R is a sfield, then S\sim R iff S\approx R_{n}, the full n\times n matrix ring over R. (Thus two sfields R and S are similar iff they are isomorphic qua rings. The same is true of two commutative rings, or two integral domains.)

sec.title: Theorems of Camillo and Stephenson
sec.p: The next theorem answered a question of W. Stephenson.

statement.p: Camillo’s Theorem [84]. Two rings R and S are Morita equivalent iff there exists a ring isomorphism End_{R}R^{(\omega )}\approx End_{S}S^{(\omega )} between their respective rings of column finite matrices.

sec.p: Stephenson [69] generalized the fundamental theorem of projective geometry by showing that a lattice isomorphism L(F)\approx L(G) between the lattices of subspaces of free modules F and G of ranks \geq 3 over rings A and B induces a Morita equivalence A\sim B. See end-of-chapter 17 notes (Excerpts of Letters of Victor Camillo).

sec.title: The Basic Ring and Module of a Semiperfect Ring
sec.p: The following folkloric results are fundamental in the study of semiperfect rings.

statement.p: Definition and Proposition. Let R be a semiperfect ring with Jacobson radical J and let \{e_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} be orthogonal indecomposable idempotents such that 1=e_{1}+\cdots +e_{n}. Then R is said to be a basic ring iff the equivalent conditions hold:

def.p: R/J is a finite product of sfields.
(3+i) Right left symmetry of (i), i=1,2.

sec.p: Note, by (SP3) of 3.30, e_{i}Re_{i} is a local ring \forall i.

statement.p: Definition and Theorem. Let R be a semiperfect ring with radical J, as in the first statement of the last Definition, and renumber \{e_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} so that \{e_{i}\}_{i=1}^{t}, for maximal t\leq n is such that the equivalent conditions (1) and (2) above hold. Then e_{0}=e_{1}+\cdots +e_{t} is called a basic idempotent and e_{0}R is called a (right) basic module of R. Furthermore: (I) R_{0}=e_{0}Re_{0} is a basic ring, called the basic ring of R;(II)R_{0} is Morita equivalent to R;(III) If e_{0}^{\prime } is another basic idempotent of R, there exists a unit x\in R so that e_{0}^{\prime }=xe_{0}x^{-1}, and

that is, any two basic rings of R are isomorphic by a map extendible to an inner automorphism of R; (IV) The basic module e_{0}R is a minimal generator of mod-R, that is, e_{0}R is isomorphic to a direct summand of every generator of mod-R. Any two basic modules are isomorphic; (V) Two semiperfect rings are Morita equivalent iff they have isomorphic basic rings, hence two basic rings are Morita equivalent iff they are isomorphic.

sec.p: For proofs, see my Algebra II, [76], p.44, 18.24, or Morita [58]. These results were known and used in finite dimensional algebras and Artinian rings by myriad researchers, e.g. by J.H.M. Wedderburn, M. Hall, Jr., R. Brauer and C. Nesbitt, T. Nakayama and others; in particular by Brauer in his theory of blocks for group algebras and Artinian rings, generalized by the author to perfect rings in op.cit., p.171f., 22.34ff.
We also note:

statement.label: 3.54. Theorem.
statement.p: A ring R is semiperfect iff R is a semilocal ring in which idempotents modulo the radical J lift.

sec.p: See op.cit.,p.45, where the appellation lift/rad ring is applied for rings with the stated property on idempotents, and called SBI rings elsewhere (see 8.4Aff).

sec.title: The Regularity Condition and Small’s Theorem
sec.p: If I is an ideal of a ring R then \mathcal{C}(I) denotes the set of all x\in R such that \overline{x}=x+I is a regular element of \overline{R}=R/I, that is, \overline{x}^{\perp }=\,^{\perp }\overline{x}=0. Thus \mathcal{C}(0) is the set of regular elements of R. R is said to satisfy the regularity condition if \mathcal{C}(0)=\mathcal{C}(N), where N=\mathrm{prime}\,\mathrm{rad}\,R.

statement.label: 3.55A. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative Noetherian ring R satisfies the regularity condition iff the associated primes of R are the minimal primes of R. In this case Q(R) is Artinian.

sec.p: Cf. Theorem 16.31 on commutative acc\perp rings and the Remark.

statement.label: 3.55B. Theorem
statement.p: A right Noetherian ring R with prime radical N has right Artinian classical right quotient ring Q=Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) iff R satisfies the regularity condition. In this case Q=Q_{c\ell }^{\ell }(R).

statement.label: 3.55C. Theorem
statement.p: A right Noetherian right hereditary ring R has right Artinian Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R).

sec.title: Reduced Rank
sec.p: If R is a semiprime Goldie ring with right quotient ring Q=Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R), and M is a right R-module, the reduced rank of M is defined as the Jordan-Hölder length \rho (M) of M\otimes _{R}Q as a right Q-module. The concept of reduced rank was originated by Goldie [64].

statement.label: 3.56. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Any f\cdot g right R-module M over a semiprime Goldie ring R has finite reduced rank \rho (M);(2) Reduced rank plays an important part in Warfield’s characterization [79b] of rings R for which Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) exists and is Artinian (see 3.57); (3) The reduced rank of M over a right Noetherian ring R with prime radical N is defined to be

where \{M_{i}\}_{i=0}^{n} is a descending chain of submodules such that (M_{i}/M_{i+1})N=0,i=0,\ldots ,n-1;(4) Any f\cdot g right R-module over a Noetherian ring R has finite reduced rank; (5) The concept of reduced rank of a module extends to a ring R such that R/N is right Goldie and N nilpotent.

sec.p: Using the above concepts and results one can prove:

statement.label: 3.57. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R with prime radical N has right Artinian Q=Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) iff R/N is right Goldie, N is nilpotent, R has finite right reduced rank, and satisfies the regularity condition.

sec.p: See Goodearl and Warfield [89], p. 175 for a discussion of this and the previous results, including Talintyre’s contributions in 3.55, the results of Warfield [79b], and Stafford [82]. Robson [67] characterized rings with Artinian Q somewhat differently. Cf. Theorem 7.6B and the remark following.

sec.title: Finitely Embedded Rings and Modules Theorems of Vámos and Beachy
sec.p: A module M is finite embedded ( = f.e.) if \mathrm{soc}(M) is f\cdot g and essential.

statement.label: Example.
statement.p: Any Artinian module M is f.e. Cf. 3.61.

sec.p: See Vámos [68], Beachy [71] and my Algebra II, pp.67–69, 19. 13A–19.16B, for the background and proofs of the following.

statement.label: 3.58. Theorem.
statement.p: A right R-module M is f.e. iff the submodules of M have the finite intersection property ( = fip); namely, if S=\{S_{i}\}_{i\in I} is a set of submodules of M, then the intersection is zero iff a finite subset of S has zero intersection.

statement.label: 3.59. Corollary.
statement.p: If a f.e. right R-module M embeds in a product \prod _{i\in I}N_{i} of modules \{N_{i}\}_{i\in I}, then M embeds in a finite product \prod _{a\in A}N_{a} where A is finite subset of I.

statement.label: 3.60. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right finitely embedded iff R embeds in a finite product of copies of any faithful right R-module N.

sec.p: Cf. my Algebra II, 19.13A.

statement.label: 3.61. Theorem
statement.p: A right R-module is Artinian iff every factor module is finitely embedded.

sec.p: Cf. my Algebra II, 19.16B. Also see Shock’s Theorem 7.28.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Vámos introduced f.e. modules as the dual of f\cdot g modules; hence an f.e. module is also called cofinitely generated; (2) An equivalent condition to that of 3.61: M is quotient finite dimensional and semiArtinian (= Loewy). Cf. 7.49-50.

statement.label: 3.61B. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right Artinian iff every factor ring is right finitely embedded.

statement.label: 3.61C. Corollary.
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a simple ring R:

def.p: R is right f.e.
R is left f.e.
R is right Artinian
R is left Artinian.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: (Trivial) If S is the right socle of R, then RS=R, hence R is a sum, hence a direct sum, of simple R-modules. This implies that R is semisimple. See Theorem 2.1.

sec.title: The Endomorphism Ring of Noetherian and Artinian Modules
sec.p: If A is an endomorphism of M, we investigate the effect on A of various chain conditions on M.

statement.label: 3.62. Remarks.
statement.p: Let A be an endomorphism of a module M.

def.p: If k is a natural number such that \ker A^{k}=\ker A^{k+1}, then A^{k}M\cap \ \ker A^{k}= 0,A induces an injection in A^{k}M, and A induces a nilpotent endomorphism in \ker A^{k}.
If t is a natural number such that A^{t}M=A^{t+1}M, then A induces a surjection in A^{t}M,A induces a nilpotent endomorphism in \ker A^{t}, and M=A^{t}M+\ker A^{t}.

statement.label: 3.63. Remarks.
statement.p: If M is any R-module, then an element f\in S=\mathrm{End}\,M_{R} has a (two-sided) inverse in S if and only if f is an automorphism of M, that is, if and only if f is an isomorphism of M onto M.

sec.p: Let M be an R-module, let S=\mathrm{End}\,M_{R}, and let A\in S. Then:

def.p: If M is Artinian, A is an automorphism if and only if A is an injection.
If M is Noetherian, A is an automorphism if and only if A is a surjection.
Uniqueness of the free basis number. Let R be a right Noetherian ring, and let M be a free module with a finite free basis x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}.
(a) If y_{1},\ldots ,y_{m} is any free basis of M, then m=n, and there exists an automorphism f of M such that f(x_{i})=y_{i},i=1,\ldots ,n;
(b) If y_{1},\ldots ,y_{m} generates M, then m\geq n. Furthermore, y_{1},\ldots ,y_{m} is a free basis if and only if m=n.
(Vasconcelos) Any surjection f:M\rightarrow M of a f\cdot g module M over a commutative ring R is an automorphism. Conclude that (3) also holds for commutative R.

sec.title: Fitting’s Lemma
sec.p: Applying 3.63 to the situation of 3.62 (1) and (2), if M is Artinian, then so is the submodule A^{k}M of (1), and A induces an automorphism a of A^{k}M. If M is Noetherian, then so is the submodule A^{t}M of (2), and A induces an automorphism b of A^{t}M. Now let M be both Artinian and Noetherian, and assume A is not an automorphism. Then there exist integers k and t such that

Since A induces an automorphism of A^{k}M, necessarily A^{k+1}M=A^{k}M, and therefore k\geq t. On the other hand, A induces an automorphism b of A^{t}M. Hence, if x\in \ker A^{t+1}, then 0=A^{t+1}x=bA^{t}x, and A^{t}x=0, so x\in \ker A^{t}. Then M=A^{s}M\oplus \ker A^{s} by 3.62 (1) and (2). This proves the next result.

statement.label: 3.64. Theorem
statement.p: If M is a module of finite length s, then any endomorphism A induces an automorphism in the submodule A^{s}M, induces a nilpotent endomorphism in ker\ A^{s}, and M=A^{s}M\oplus kerA^{s}.

statement.label: 3.65. Corollary.
statement.p: Let M be an indecomposable R-module of finite length s, and let S=End\, M_{R}.

def.p: Every element of S is either a unit, or is nilpotent.
The set of N of nilpotent endomorphisms of M is a nilpotent ideal of S of index \leq s (Cf. 3.68).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: (1) If A\in S, then by Fitting’s lemma, M=A^{s}M\oplus \ker A^{s}. Since M is indecomposable, either M=A^{s}M, or else M=\ker A^{s}. By Fitting’s lemma, A is an automorphism in the former case, and A is nilpotent in the latter case.

(2) Now let A,B\in S be such that AB is an automorphism, that is, such that AB has an inverse C\in S. Then A(BC)=(CA)B=1, and consequently neither A nor B is nilpotent; that is, both A and B are automorphisms. Thus, if B\in N, then AB\in N and BA\in N. Hence, in order to show that N is an ideal of S it remains only to show that N is an additive subgroup of S. Let A,B\in N, and suppose for the moment that A-B=C\not \in N. Then C is an automorphism, so A_{1}-B_{1}=1, where A_{1}=AC^{-1},B_{1}=BC^{-1}. We already know that A_{1},B_{1}\in N. Thus, A_{1}^{s}=0, and, by the binomial theorem,
Since B_{1}\neq 0, there exists a natural number k such that B_{1}^{k-1}\neq 0, and B_{1}^{k}=0. Then
a contradiction, which proves that A-B=c\in N for all A,B\in N. Therefore N is an ideal of S, and the following Proposition 3.68 proves that N is nilpotent of index \leq s.

statement.label: 3.66. Corollary
statement.p: The endomorphism ring of an indecomposable module of finite length s is a local ring with nilpotent radical of index \leq s.

sec.title: Köthe-Levitzki Theorem
sec.p: Let K be a ring, and let S be a multiplicative submonoid of the n\times n matrix ring K_{n}. Then, S is said to be in (strict) upper triangular form, provided that for some set \{e_{ij}\}_{i,j=1}^{n} of matrix units of K_{n}, and unit some x\in K_{n} every element s\in x^{-1}Sx has the canonical form
with s_{ij}=0 whenever i>j (resp. whenever i\geq j). Then, the elements of S are said to be placed simultaneously into (strict) upper triangular form.

statement.label: 3.67. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) If K is a field, and if T_{n}(M) is the set of (strict) upper triangular matrices of K_{n} relative to some set M of n\times n matrix units, then a submonoid S can be placed into (strict) upper triangular form if and only if there is a unit x\in K_{n}, and a set M such that xSx^{-1}\subseteq T_{n}(M).
(2) S can be put into (strict) upper if and only if S can be placed in (strict) lower triangular form.

statement.label: 3.68. Proposition
statement.p: If K is a sfield, then any multiplicative nil submonoid S of K_{n}\approx End_{K}K^{n} can be placed simultaneously into strict triangular form, and S^{n}=0.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: For n=1, there is nothing to prove. Assume the proposition for vector spaces K^{m} of dimension m<n. Let V=K^{n}. then, there is a vector subspace U of V of dimension <n such that US\subseteq U. Otherwise, VS=V, and then there exist elements s_{1},\ldots s_{k}\in S such that

Now one of the elements s_{1},\ldots ,s_{t}, say a=s_{1}, occurs infinitely often in the sequence \{s_{i_{t}}\}_{t\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}}. Then, there is a sequence \{s_{i_{t}}^{\prime }\}_{t\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}} of elements of S such that
Put W=Va. Since a is nilpotent, \dim W<\dim V. Furthermore,

Since, therefore, there exists t>0 such that

statement.label: 3.69. Theorem
statement.p: If M is an R-module of length n, then any nil submonoid of A=EndM_{R} is nilpotent of index \leq n.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: We prove it first under the assumption that M is semisimple. If M is homogeneous, that is, if M is a direct sum of isomorphic simple modules, then A\approx K_{n}, where K=\mathrm{End}\,V_{R} is the endomorphism sfield of a simple submodule V. In this case, the theorem follows from 3.68. Otherwise, M=H\oplus G is a direct sum of two fully invariant submodules of lengths h and n-h respectively. If S is a nil submonoid of A, then S induces a nil submonoid \overline{S} of End H_{R}, and a nil submonoid S^{\prime } of End G_{R}. Then \overline{S}^{h}=0,S^{\prime n-h}=0, and S^{n}=0.

In the general case, we may assume that the socle H of M has length m< n. Since H is fully invariant, an element s\in S induces \overline{s}\in \mathrm{End}(M/H)_{R}, and s^{\prime }\in \mathrm{End}\,H_{R}, both of which elements are nilpotent. By the induction hypothesis, \overline{S}=\{\overline{s}\,|\,s\in S\} and S^{\prime }=\{s^{\prime }\,|\,s\in S\} are nilpotent of indices n-m, and m respectively. Thus, given a seqeuence \{s_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} of elements of S, then
Thus S^{n}=0, completing the induction and proof.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See Shock [72b] for generalizations to modules M of finite Goldie dimension or acc on “rationally closed” submodules (see 12.OB). In the latter case, any nil subring S of A is nilpotent. This generalizes a theorem of Small for Noetherian M. (See op. cit., p.313.)

sec.title: Kolchin’s Theorem
sec.p: A matrix A is unipotent if A=1+B, where B is nilpotent. (An equivalent formulation: the characteristic roots of A are all =1.) Kolchin’s theorem states that any multiplicative semigroup S of unipotent matrices over a commutative field k can be placed simultaneously in triangular form. It is tempting to derive Kolchin’s theorem from 3.69; however, the B’s do not form a multiplicative submonoid in general. (They do, obviously, when S consists of commuting matrices, but this is an unnecessary restriction. Moreover, there is a theorem which permits the diagonalization of commuting matrices over an algebraically closed field. See Jacobson [53, p.134].)

statement.p: Burnside’s Theorem. Any irreducible semigroup S of linear transformations on a vector space V of dimension n over an algebraically closed field k contains n^{2} linearly independent transformations.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Let R be a subalgebra of L=\mathrm{End}_{k} spanned by S. Then, V is a simple R-module, so (2.4 and 2.4f) applies, so that R=L, so S has n^{2}=\dim _{k}L linearly independent transformations.

statement.label: 3.71. Corollary.
statement.p: If t is the number of distinct traces of elements of S in 3.70, then S has at most t^{n^{2}} elements.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: On the algebra of all linear transformations on V, introduce the inner product (A,B)=Tr(AB). (This is easily seen to be nonsingular.) Let c_{1},\ldots ,,c_{t} be the distinct traces that occur. Let A_{j}(i=1,\ldots ,n^{2}) be n^{2} linearly independent elements in S (Theorem 3.70). Each X in S satisfies equations Tr(A_{i}X)=b_{i} where b_{1},\ldots ,b_{n^{2}} are chosen from the c’s.
These equations determine X uniquely, so there are at most t^{n^{2}} choices for X.

statement.label: 3.72. Theorem
statement.p: Let S be a multiplicative semigroup of unipotent matrices over a field k. Then the elements of S can be placed simultaneously into triangular form.

statement.title: Proof (Kaplansky [69b], p.137–8).
statement.p: Let n be the size of the matrices. We argue by induction on n. The case n=1 is trivial.

statement.label: Case I.
statement.p: The scalar field is algebraicaly closed. If S is irreducible, then by 3.71, S has only one element, and one matrix is always reducible (here n>1). Hence S is reducible. Then by choosing a basis for the invariant subspace of S and extending it to a complete basis, all the elements of S will have matrices of the block form:
Now the sets S_{L}, of the upper left corners B, and S_{R}, of the lower right corners D, form multiplicative semigroups of unipotent matrices of dimension less than n.

sec.p: One can then use the induction hypothesis to triangulate simultaneously these matrices, and all elements of S will then have been put in triangular form.

statement.label: Case II.
statement.p: An arbitrary scalar field k. Form the algebraic closure of k and triangulate the elements of S simultaneously as matrices over the extension field. Then any product of n matrices (T-1), where T is in S and 1 is the identity matrix, must be zero. Let r be the smallest integer such that the product of any r elements (T-1) is zero. Then there exist elements T_{1},\ldots ,T_{r-1} in S such that
Find a vector x such that
Then for any T in S,y(T-1)=0, or yT-y. This shows that S is reducible. The argument can now proceed as in Case I.

statement.label: 3.73. Remark.
statement.p: The group T of nonsingular upper triangular matrices of degree n over the field k is a solvable group, and in fact, T is an extension by an abelian group of a nilpotent group.

sec.p: [Hint: Let U=1+N, consisting of all unipotent matrices, where 1 is the identity matrix, and N is the ideal of strictly upper triangular matrices. Then, 1+N^{i},(1\leq i\leq n) is a normal subgroup of U, and the commutator formula [1+N^{i},1+N^{j}]\subseteq 1+N^{i+j} for the case of i=1, and variable j, shows that U is a nilpotent group. Moreover, U is a normal subgroup of T, and T/U is abelian.]

sec.title: Historical Notes on Local and Semilocal Rings
sec.p: The importance of semilocal rings stems from a vast number of applications from such diverse fields as algebraic geometry, commutative and noncommutative algebra, group theory, module theory, and category theory. In algebraic geometry, or commutative algebra, for example, one can consider the local ring at a point on an algebraic variety, or at a prime ideal of a ring.

According to Bourbaki [65, Note Historique, p.131] the general idea of a local ring developed very slowly: Grell (1926), and Krull (1938), for domains, Chevalley (1944) for Noetherian rings, and the general case by Uzkov (1948).

Beginning about 1940, the local ring R_{P} at a prime ideal P of a domain R was consistently used by Krull (and his school), and in algebraic geometry by Chevalley and Zariski. Krull’s term Stellenring was superseded by Chevalley’s terminology local ring, a ring associated with a point of a variety which gives “local properties” of the variety, for example, the ring of all functions regular at that point (also see Nagata [62, p.xi]). This chronology omits the important work of Hensel at the turn of the century on p-adic numbers; however, Hensel considered not R_{P} but the completion of R_{P}, that is, the p-adic completion (see Bourbaki, loc.cit. and also Matlis’ Theorem 5.4B).

Köthe [30a] studied noncommutative semilocal rings with a Köthe radical, that is, a nil ideal K containing every nil onesided ideal. (It is an open question if every ring has a Köthe radical, but see Theorem 3.50.) Köthe (loc.cit.) proved that a semilocal ring R with Köthe radical K is isomorphic to a full matrix A_{n} over a local ring A iff R/K is simple. Moreover R\approx \mathrm{End}_{A}E, where E is one of the rows of A_{n} considered as a module over A. This theorem generalizes the Wedderburn-Artin theorem, and the theorem of Noether [29] (for simple semisimple R). Moreover, Köthe [30a, p.182, Satz13] proved that in a semilocal lift/rad ring with radical J, and right prindecs (=principal indecomposable right ideals) eR and fR, that eR\approx fR iff eR/eJ\approx fR/fJ. (Köthe’s proof of this is for J =Köthe radical.)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Lambek [66] extended Köthe’s theorem to a semiperfect ring R having R/J simple.

sec.p: Köthe [30b] generalized two theorems of Shoda to a semilocal ring R with nil radical K:

def.p: The intersection of all the nilsubrings of R is K.
In case R is Artinian, any two maximal nilpotent subrings of R are conjugate, and every nilpotent subring is contained in a maximal nilpotent subring.

sec.p: (Shoda proved (1) for Artinian, and (2) for finite rings.) Also (1) has been generalized by Michler [66] to right Noetherian R;

(2) implies that any nilpotent subring S of an n\times n matrix ring k_{n} over a field k can be placed simultaneously into triangular form, inasmuch as the ring T_{n}(k) of upper triangular matrices is maximal nilpotent. In answering a conjecture of Köthe, Levitzki [31] (also [45a]) showed that every nilsubring of an Artinian (also Noetherian) ring is nilpotent, and thereby sharpened Köthe’s theorem, that is, then nil subrings of k_{n} can be placed simultaneously in \vartriangle -form (see 3.68). Levitzki [50] generalized nil \Rightarrow nilpotence to multiplicatively closed systems (M-systems) of left and right Noetherian rings. (See 2.33 and 2.38 A–B.)

Fitting [33] established the relationship between the direct decomposition of a module M of finite length and endomorphism ring A (loc.cit., p.528, Satz 4). In particular, M is indecomposable iff A is local (loc.cit. p.533, Satz 8). This is called Fitting’s “lemma” (see 3.65 and 8.8f).

Kaplansky [68, p.4] expressed his doubt that Artinian rings are the natural generalization of finite dimensional algebras because “natural examples are not common,” and suggests, as an alternative, rings which are finitely generated modules over Noetherian subrings of their centers (that is, PI-algebras). Be that as it may, semiprimary rings certainly do arise naturally as endomorphism rings of (Jordan-Hölder) modules of finite length.

Levitzki [44] characterized semiprimary rings as semilocal rings modulo the ideal N generated by all nilpotent one-sided ideals, and satisfying the dec on products of ideals in N; and Björk (or who?) characterizes semiprimary rings as follows: there exists an integer n such that R does not contain a strictly decreasing sequence of n principal left ideals.

Chase anticipated Björk’s theorem (3.32f) stating that right modules satisfy the dec on finitely generated submodules whenever R satisfies the dec on principal right ideals. Chase proved this holds (on both sides) for a semiprimary ring. See the Appendix of my paper [66a].
Theorem 3.68, placing nil submonoids of K_{n} simultaneously into triangular form, is attributed to Levitzki by Jacobson [43], but the theorem can be deduced from a theorem of Köthe [30].
A theorem generalizing both Kolchin’s Theorem 3.72 and the commutative field case of 3.68 is proved by Kaplansky [69b], p.137.

sec.title: Further Notes for Chapter 3
