sec.p: The purely algebraic theorem of Kolchin [48b], given in 3.72, was preceded by the theorem of Lie-Kolchin which states that any connected solvable algebraic matrix group over an algebraically closed field can be placed simultaneously into triangular form (Kolchin [48a]). This has been proved by Borel [69, p.243] in a way which yields as an immediate corollary Mal’cev’s theorem [49, 51] which states that if M is any solvable subgroup of the group GL(n,k) [the general linear group of nonsingular n\times n matrices over a field k] over an algebraically closed field k, then M is an extension by a finite group of a group which can be placed simultaneously into triangular form. Moreover, a theorem of Zassenhaus [38] states that the derived series of any solvable subgroup of GL(n,F), for any field F, is bounded by a number z(n) independent of F.

sec.title: Free Subgroups of GL(n,F)
sec.p: A theorem of Tits [72] on a conjecture of Bass and Serre states that any finitely generated subgroup G of GL(n,F), for any field F, and n>1, contains either a free group of rank >1, or else is an extension by a finite group of a solvable group. (Over characteristic 0, the subgroup G is not required to be finitely generated.) A number of theorems on the structure of solvable subgroups of GL(n,F) of Zassenhaus, (e.g. a maximal irreducible subgroup has a unique maximal Abelian normal subgroup when F is infinite), Mal’cev and others, are presented in Suprunenko [63].

sec.title: Sanov’s Theorem
sec.p: On the subject of free subgroups of GL(n,F) is the following explicit example.

statement.label: 3.74. Theorem

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This theorem is quoted in Jespers’ survey [98], p.146, Prop. 2.1, which refers to the book by Kargapolov and Merzljakov [79].

sec.p: Recall, G is Hamiltonian if every subgroup is normal.
A consequence to Sanov’s theorem is a corollary to the Hartley-Pickel theorem (see below).

statement.label: 3.75. Corollary.
statement.p: If G is a non-Abelian and non-Hamiltonian finite group, then the units group \mathbf{U}(\mathbb{Z}G) of the integral group ring \mathbb{Z}G contains a non-Abelian free subgroup.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The Wedderburn-Artin decomposition of the rational group algebra \mathbb{Q}G contains an n\times n matrix ring D_{n} for some skew field D and n\geq 2, so the corollary follows easily from Sanov’s theorem. Cf. Jespers, ibid., p.146.

statement.title: (Hartley-Pickel Theorem [80]).
statement.p: If G is a non-Abelian finite group, then \mathbf{U}(\mathbb{Z}G) contains a finite non-Abelian free group of rank 2 iff G is not a Hamiltonian 2-group.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Jespers, ibid., p.147, Corollary 2.6 and Milies and Seghal [02].

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Also refer to Jespers, ibid, for related results of Berman, Ritter and Seghal, and Bass and Milnor on \boldsymbol{U}(\mathbb{Z}G).

sec.title: Steinitz and Semi-Steinitz Rings
sec.p: A free right R-module F is a (semi, or f)-Steinitz module if every (finite) independent subset of elements extends to a free basis. A right (semi-) Steinitz ring is one in which every (f\cdot g) free right R-module is (semi-) Steinitz.

statement.label: 3.77A. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is Steinitz iff R is a local ring over which every flat R-module is free, equivalently by Theorem 3.31, R is a local perfect ring.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This is generalized to right Steinitz rings in Theorem 3.78.

statement.label: 3.77B. Theorem
statement.p: A free right R-module of rank n\geq 2 is semi-Steinitz iff R is a local ring and L^{\perp }\neq 0 for every n-generated left ideal L\neq R.

statement.label: 3.78. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right Steinitz iff R is a right perfect local ring, that is, a local ring with a left T-nilpotent maximal ideal.

def.p: Nashier and Nichol [91] show that a commutative ring R is semi-Steinitz iff R is local and every f.g. proper ideal has nonzero annihilator. This follows from Theorem 3.77B.

Nashier and Nichols, loc. cit., also characterize a weakly semi-Steinitz ring R, that is, a ring over which every finite independent subset of a f\cdot g free R-module extends to free basis. This happens iff R is a Hermite ring and every f\cdot g proper ideal has nonzero annihilator.

Mahdou [01] considers a split-null extension R=A\ltimes E (see 4.24) for any module E over a commutative ring A, and shows that R is (weakly-semi, or semi) Steinitz iff A is. He also considers local properties.

statement.label: 3.79. Theorem
statement.p: If F is a free right R-module, and J is the Jacobson radical of R, and if G is a submodule of F such that F= G+FJ, then G has a direct sumand\approx F.

sec.title: Essentially Nilpotent Ideals
sec.p: A right ideal I of a ring R is said to be essentially nilpotent if I contains a nilpotent right ideal that is essential in I.

statement.p: Shock’s Theorem [71b]. Any right vanishing (= left T-nilpotent) right ideal I of a ring R is essentially nilpotent. Furthermore, so is any right ideal I of prime rad R in an acc\oplus or\ {acc}\perp ring.

statement.label: 3.81. Theorem
statement.title: (ibid.).
statement.p: If R is commutative, then prime rad R is essentially nilpotent.

sec.title: Comment on the Köthe Radical
sec.p: Cohn [03b] pointed out that the usual definition of the Köthe radical is the sum of all nil ideals, and the question of Köthe is whether it contains all nil one-sided ideals. This is equivalent to the Köthe conjecture stated sup 3.43A.

sec.label: Chapter 4
sec.title: Direct Product Decompositions of von Neumann Regular Rings and Self-injective Rings
sec.p: A ring R is von Neumann regular ( = VNR) if it satisfies the equivalent conditions:
(VNR) For every a\in R there exists x\in R so that axa=a.
(VNR 1) Every principal right ideal pR is generated by an idempotent, i.e., pR=eR for some e=e^{2}\in R.
(VNR 2) Every f\cdot g right ideal is generated by an idempotent.
(VNR 3) Every f\cdot g right ideal is a direct summand of R.
(VNR i)^{\prime } Left-right symmetry of (VNR i), i=1,2,3.

These rings were introduced by von Neumann [36] as co-ordinate rings of infinite dimensional projective and continuous geometries. Cf. Kaplansky [69b], p.111. (A projective geometry in the classical sense can be viewed as a lattice of submodules of a vector space, equivalently, as a lattice of right ideals of a full matrix ring over a sfield. Cf. 12.4.)
A VNR ring is unit-regular if x in (VNR) can be chosen to be a unit.
4\star Remarks and Results.

def.p: Any semisimple ring R is a fortiori VNR since by Theorem 2.1, every sub-module of every module is a direct summand.
Any union of any chain of VNR rings is VNR.
Any n\times n matrix ring R_{n} over a VNR ring R is VNR. (see von Neumann, ibid.)
One checks that every product of (unit) regular VNR’s is (unit) regular.
Every full linear ring R=\mathrm{End}_{D}V of a vector space V over a sfield D is VNR. (See Kaplansky [69b], p.111.)
Ehrlich [76] shows that R in (5) is unit-regular iff n=\dim _{D}V<\infty , in which case R\approx D_{n}.
Ehrlich, ibid., shows that if 2 is a unit of a unit regular ring R, then every element of R is a sum of two units. Cf. her characterization of unit regular rings in Chapter 6, Theorem 6.3B.
Any right and left self-injective VNR ring R is unit regular. (This is a theorem of Utumi—see 4.7B.)

sec.title: Clean Rings
sec.p: A ring R is said to be clean if every element a in R can be written a=u+e for a unit u and idempotent e. Note that any factor ring of a clean ring is clean.
4\star \star Remarks and Results.

def.p: (Camillo-Yu [94].) A ring R is semiperfect iff R is clean and has no infinite sets of orthogonal idempotents. (Loc. cit., Theorem 9).

(Han-Nicholson [01].) Any full n\times n matrix ring R_{n} over a clean ring R is clean (loc. cit., Cor. 1). Moreover a split-null extension of an (A,B)-bimodule M is clean iff both A and B are clean (ibid. Cor. 3).

(Camillo-Khurana [01].) A ring R is unit-regular iff every element a of R has the form a=u+e, where u is a unit and e is an idempotent “disjoint from a”, i.e., aR\cap eR=0. (This paper corrects the proof of Theorem 5 of Camillo-Yu [94], and (3) actually strengthens the result.)
(Han-Nicholson [ibid.]) If R is any commutative ring, then the polynomial ring R[X] is not clean.
(Ibid.) The power series ring R[[X]] is clean iff R is clean.
Any direct product of clean rings is clean.

sec.title: Flat Modules
sec.p: A right R-module M is flat provided that the functor
is exact from the category R-mod of left R-modules to the category Ab of Abelian additive groups.

statement.label: 4.A. Theorem
statement.p:
An R-module M is flat iff M is a direct limit of projectives.⁠11
This theorem has long been ascribed to Lazard, and I wish to thank J-L. Gómez-Pardo for the reference to Govorov [65]. See P. M. Cohn’s review of the latter, e.g. on p.324 of Small [81].

sec.p: Thus: any projective R-module is flat. A consequence of Schanuel’s lemma is that any finitely presented flat R-module is projective (Cf. Faith [72a,81], pp.436–7, esp.11.30). Furthermore, any f\cdot g flat module over a commutative integral domain is projective hence finitely presented. See Endo’s theorem below, and also see Sandomierski [68], where this is proved also for finite dimensional nonsingular rings: f\cdot g flat modules are projective. Also see Sahaev [69,77], and Jøndrup’s [76]. Cf. 12.9.

statement.label: 4.A1. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative, and Q=Q_{c\ell }(R) is semilocal, then every f\cdot g flat R-module is projective.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Examples of commutative rings R with semilocal Q are:
(a) When R has “few zero divisors”–see 9.9.
(b) Rings with \mathrm{acc}\perp , e.g., whenever Q has \mathrm{acc}\perp (see, e.g. 16.31–32; for example whenever Q is Noetherian), or when R has acc on principal annihilators. (See 9.9C.)

statement.label: 4.A2. Theorem
statement.p: If a ring R is embeddable in a right Noetherian or right perfect ring R, then every flat right R-module is an \aleph _{0}-directed union of countably generated flat right R-modules, and every f\cdot g submodule of a flat right R-module embeds in a free module.

sec.p: Below, let R\in P denote that f\cdot g flat R-modules are projective.

statement.label: 4.A3.
statement.p: Jømdrup’s Theorem [70]. If R is commutative, then R\in P iff the power series ring R[[x]]\in P. Moreover, then A\in P for any R-algebra A when R\subseteq center of A.

sec.title: Character Modules and the Bourbaki-Lambek Theorem
sec.p: If M is a left R-module, then M^{\prime }=\mathrm{Hom}(M,\mathbb{Q}/\mathbb{Z}) is a canonical right R-module called the character module of M, where

statement.label: 4.B.
statement.p: Bourbaki [61A]-Lambek [64] Theorem. A left R-module M is flat iff its character module M^{\prime } is an injective right R-module.

sec.p: Cf. Cheatham and Stone [81].

def.p: If M is a(B,A)-bimodule, then the following are equivalent:
(a) Hom_{A}(M,) : mod{-} A\rightsquigarrow mod{-}B preserves injectives.
(b) If Q is the smallest injective cogenerator of mod-A, then Hom_{A}(M,Q) is injective in mod-B.
(c) The left adjoint \otimes _{B}M of the functor (a) is exact.
(d) M is a flat B-module.
If I is an ideal of a ring A, then every injective right A/I module is injective in mod-A if and only if A/I is flat in A-mod.
If B is a subring of A, then every injective right A-module is an injective right (canonical) B-module iff A is flat as a (canonical) left B-module.

statement.label: 4.D. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) This is a corollary to a more general theorem (due to Gabriel) on injective-preserving functors of Abelian categories. See Theorem 6.28 of my Algebra I.
(2) Theorem 4.B is a corollary of 4.C: see my Algebra I, p.440, Prop. 11.35 (and the remark following).
(3) (Faith [72B]). If R is VNR, then an R-module E is \Sigma -injective iff R/(\mathrm{ann}_{R}E) is semisimple Artinian.
This follows from 3.7 and 4.C.

sec.title: When Everybody Is Flat
sec.p: Semisimple rings are the rings over which every module is projective. We now consider when every R-module is flat:

statement.label: 4.1A. Theorem.
statement.p: Harada [56] and Auslander [57] Theorem. All right R-modules over a ring R are flat iff R is von Neumann regular (= VNR) iff all left R-modules are flat.

statement.label: 4.1B. Theorem.
statement.p: Camillo [74]-Pillay [80] Theorem. If the polynomial ring R[x] is left or right semihereditary, then R is VNR.

sec.p: Pillay extended Camillo’s theorem to non-commutative R. According to C. U. Jensen in his review of Pillay’s theorem, which is the case R is non-commutative, the converse does not hold, by an unpublished example of Jøndrup. However, Fieldhouse’s theorem [78] states that the converse holds assuming that R[x] is, e.g., left coherent (see 6.6): if R is VNR then R[x] is left semihereditary. Moreover:

statement.label: 4.1C.
statement.p: McCarthy’s Theorem [73]. If R is a commutative VNR then R[x] is semihereditary.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Power series rings over a VNR ring are considered in §6, 6.12ff.

statement.label: 4.1D.
statement.p: Kaplansky’s theorem on Torsion Splitting [60]. A commutative integral domain is Prüfer (= semihereditary) iff the torsion submodule of every f\cdot g module splits off.

statement.label: 4.1D^{\prime }.
statement.p: Chase’s Theorem [60]. A commutative domain is Dedekind (=Noetherian Prüfer) iff every torsion module of bounded order splits off.

sec.title: Singular Splitting
sec.p: The singular submodule sing M of an R-module M consists of all m\in M, whose annihilators are essential right ideals of R.

One verifies that S=\mathrm{sing}\ M is a fully invariant submodule in the sense tht f(S)\subseteq S\ \forall f\in \ \mathrm{End}\ M_{R}. Thus sing R_{R} is an ideal called the right singular ideal of R. M is nonsingular if sing M=0. (For a domain R, the torsion submodule of M=\mathrm{sing}\ M.) R has singular splitting if sing M splits in M for all right R-modules M.
R is right nonsingular provided that sing R_{R}=0.
Examples of Nonsingular Rings. (1) Any domain; (2) Any simple ring R. (Note: sing R_{R} is an ideal, hence necessarily = 0 in (2).)

statement.label: 4.1E. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a commutative ring R:

def.p: R has singular splitting,
Sing M is injective for all M in mod-R,
Sing R_{R}=0 and R/I is semisimple for every essential right ideal I.
R is VNR and every bounded singular submodule splits.

statement.p: Then, R is hereditary.

sec.p: Cf. 4.1G and H(2).

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Huynh [98] pointed out that in general (2) does not imply (4). Huynh also pointed out that a right PCI domain not a field is a counter-example to this implication (see 4.1K below); (2) Since E(M)/M is singular for any R-module M, then injectivity of singular modules implies R is hereditary. (In the terminology of §14, R has right global dimension \leq 1.) Any semihereditary ring is right nonsingular. Cf. 4.2B^{\prime }.

statement.label: 4.1E^{\prime }. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is a commutative self-injective ring with singular splitting, then R is semisimple.

statement.label: 4.1F.
statement.p: Fuelberth and Teply Theorem [72]. Over a commutative ring R, the singular submodule splits off in every f\cdot g module iff R is semihereditary and every non-singular f\cdot g module is “almost finitely presented.”

statement.label: 4.1G. Theorem
statement.p: Every singular right R-module is injective iff R/I is semisimple for all essential right ideals I. Then R is right hereditary, (rad\ R)^{2}=0, and R/(soc\ R_{R}) is Noetherian.

sec.p: Cf. 12.4C^{\prime }-H and 12.8. also see Osofsky-Smith [91].

statement.label: 4.1H. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) The conditions of 4.1G are not left-right symmetric: see 4.1K below for characterizations of these rings: (2) Under the conditions of 4.1G, then R/I is singular hence injective. Thus, e.g. if R is right uniform, then R is right PCI, hence by 3.18C, R is either semisimple or a right hereditary Noetherian domain. Any right PCI domain has singular splitting (op.cit.).

sec.p: For the next theorems, consult Chapter 14 for the concept of global dimension.

statement.label: 4.1I. Theorem
statement.p: If R has singular splitting, then R has global dimension \leq 2.

statement.label: 4.1J. Theorem
statement.p: There exists a splitting ring R of global dimension 2.

statement.label: 4.1K. Theorem
statement.p: Every singular right R module is injective (=R is right SI) iff R is a finite product R=K\times R_{1}\times \cdots \times R_{n} such that K/soc(K_{K}) is semisimple, and each R_{i} is Morita equivalent to a right SI-domain.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Goodearl, op.cit., p.56.

sec.title: Utumi’s Theorems

statement.p: Theorem of Utumi ([56,67]). If R is a right self-injective ring, then the Jacobson radical rad R is the right singular ideal J, and \overline{R}=R/J is a right self-injective VNR ring.

sec.p: Wong-Johnson [59] is the case J=0 of Utumi’s theorem.

statement.label: 4.2A. Theorem
statement.p: If A is the endomorphism ring of a quasi-injective right R-module M, then J=\mathit{rad}\ A is the set of all a\in A whose kernels are essential submodules, A/J is a right self-injective VNR ring, and idempotents lift modulo any subset I containing J.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p:
Osofsky [68A] proved (inter alia) that A/J is right self-injective.⁠22
Theorem 4.2A is proved in Goodearl [79], Theorem 1.22, p.11. (Also see p.13, loc. cit.)

statement.label: 4.2B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right self-injective ring whose maximal ideals have nonzero left annihilators, then R/rad\ R is a finite product of simple rings, and J=rad\ R is a right annulet.

statement.label: 4.2C. Theorem
statement.p: If R is two-sided self-injective, then: (1) R is VNR iff (2) R is a semiprime ring and J is a right annulet.

statement.label: 4.2D. Remark.
statement.p: Actually one can weaken the self-injective hypothesis in 4.2C to just requiring instead (3): the maximal regular ideal M(R) splits off as a right ideal in R. In this case: (1)\Leftrightarrow (2). A sufficient condition for (3) is that R/J is a finite product of simple rings. The theorem in this case is a conjecture of Shamsuddin which is the subject of Faith [96a]. Regarding (3), see theorem 4.4 below.

sec.title: Weak or F\,{\cdot }\,G Injectivity
sec.p: A right module M over a ring R is weak \aleph _{0}-injective (or f\cdot g-injective) provided for any homomorphism f:I\rightarrow M of a f\cdot g right ideal there exists m\in M such that f(x)=mx\ \forall x\in I. In contradistinction to injective modules, any direct sum of weak \aleph _{0}-injective modules is weak \aleph _{0}-injective. (Cf. 3.4B and 3.7) \aleph _{0}-injectivity denotes the same property whenever I is countably generated. (Cf. sup. 6.1)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: A f\cdot g or weak \aleph _{0}-injective module is called f-injective by Gupta [69] and semi-injective by Matlis [85].

sec.p: The next theorem indicates a plenitude of f\cdot g-injective modules that are not necessarily injective (Cf. 3.22).

statement.label: 4.2E. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right semihereditary iff every factor module of an injective right module is f\cdot g injective.

statement.label: 4.2E^{\prime }. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is semihereditary iff E(M)/M is f\cdot g injective for each R-module M.

statement.label: 4.2F. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right \aleph _{0}-injective VNR ring and I is an ideal such that R/I has no uncountable independent set of right ideals, then R/I is right self-injective.

sec.title: Abelian VNR Rings
sec.p: A von Neumann regular (= VNR) ring R is Abelian, or strongly regular, if R satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

def.p: All idempotents are central.
R has no nonzero nilpotent elements (=R is reduced).
All one-sided ideals are ideals.
For each a\in R there exists x\in R so that a^{2}x=a.
Every one-sided ideal \neq 0 contains a central idempotent \neq 0.
R/P is a skew field for each prime ideal P.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) These equivalences are due to Arens and Kaplansky [48], and Forsythe and McCoy [46]. See, e.g. Goodearl [79], p.35. Also see theorems 3.2 and 3.5, pp. 26–28 of loc.cit.; (2) Forsythe and McCoy proved more generally that all idempotents are central in any reduced ring; (3) (Ehrlich [76]) If R is Abelian VNR, then all n\times n matrix rings R_{n} are unit-regular (Cf. Goodearl loc.cit.).

sec.p: If e is an idempotent of a VNR ring R, then eRe is a VNR ring, and e is said to Abelian provided that eRe is an Abelian VNR ring.

statement.label: 4.3A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right self-injective VNR ring, then R=R_{1}\times R_{2} where R_{1} is Abelian, and R_{2} has no Abelian idempotents \neq 0. Moreover, R_{2} is left self-injective.

statement.label: Corollary.
statement.p: Any right self-injective Abelian VNR ring is left self-injective.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See sup. 12.4C for definition of right continuous used in the next theorem.

statement.label: 4.3B. Theorem
statement.p: Any right continuous VNR ring R is a product R_{1}\times R_{2} where R_{1} is Abelian and R_{2} is right self-injective.

sec.title: The Maximal Regular Ideal
sec.p: The existence of the maximal regular (=VNR) ideal M(R) of a ring has been demonstrated by Brown-McCoy [50], and that M(R/M(R))=0.

statement.label: 4.4. Theorem
statement.p: The maximal VNR ideal M(R) of a ring R splits off as a ring direct factor iff the image of M(R) splits off in R/radR as a right ideal. Sufficient conditions for this are:

def.p: The image \overline{M(R)} of M(R) in \overline{R}=R/radR splits off as a right or left ideal.
R is right and left continuous (e.g. self-injective).
\overline{R} is a finite product of simple rings (e.g. \overline{R} is semisimple).

sec.p: This type of theorem was originated by M. Hall, Jr. [40] and Mal’cev [42] who show essentially that the maximal semisimple ideal M(R) splits off of any finite dimensional algebra R, a result that Brown-McCoy extended to right Artinian rings. For an application of Theorem 4.4 to VNR rings, see Remark 4.2D. Cf. Birkenmeier-Kim-Park [97].

sec.title: Products of Matrix Rings over Abelian VNR Rings
sec.p: The next theorem is a theorem of Kaplansky [50].

statement.label: 4.5A. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a VNR ring and n a positive integer. Then R\approx A_{n} for an Abelian VNR ring A iff all (left) primitive factor rings of R have index n.

statement.label: 4.5B. Theorem.
statement.p: Kaplansky [50] and Armendariz-Steinberg [74] Theorem If R is a right self-injective VNR ring, then the following conditions are equivalent:

def.p: R is isomorphic to a finite product of full matrix rings over Abelian (= idempotents are central) VNR rings.
R/P is Artinian for all primitive ideals P.
R/M is Artinian for all maximal ideals M.
R has bounded index (of nilpotency).

sec.p: This theorem is due to Kaplansky [50], as stated in 4.5A, without assuming self injectivity when all R/M have the same index n and then R\approx A_{n} for some Abelian VNR ring A; and Armendariz-Steinberg [74] in the general case. See Goodearl [79, p.79] for other credits, including Goodearl and Utumi. Also, see Carlson [76] who proves 4.5B for complete VNR maximal left quotient rings of finite index.
Cf. \Pi -Regular rings sup. 8.4F. Cf. also 4.18.

sec.title: Products of Full Linear Rings
sec.p: A full right linear ring is defined to be \mathrm{Hom}_{D}(V,V)=\mathrm{End}_{D}V, for a right vector space V over a skew field D.

statement.label: 4.6. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is isomorphic to a direct product of full right linear rings iff R is VNR, right self-injective and has essential right socle (= every nonzero right ideal contains a minimal right ideal).

sec.p: The special case when R is a prime ring characterizes a full right linear ring and is due to Utumi (Cf. Utumi [63d]). Actually, Chase-Faith ([65]) characterize when the maximal right quotient ring of a ring R is a direct product of full linear rings. Cf. Lambek-Michler [76]. Hudry [75] and O’Meara [75] independently characterize when R has classical right quotient ring Q that is a product of linear rings. Hutchinson [71] gives necessary and sufficient conditions when a ring R has a full linear maximal quotient ring—see Chapter 12 for the definition. Also see Hannah and O’Meara [77a] and esp. Hannah [79b] in this regard.

statement.label: 4.6A.
statement.p: Definition and Proposition. R is Dedekind Finite (Directly Finite in Goodearl [79]) provided that xy=1\Longrightarrow yx=1 for each x,y\in R. A necessary and sufficient condition for R to be Dedekind Finite (=DF) is that R/radR be DF. R is stably finite provided that every matrix ring R_{n} is Dedekind Finite. Noetherian, commutative and semilocal rings are examples of stably finite rings.

statement.label: 4.6A^{\prime }.
statement.p: Historical Notes. (1) In his 1887 classic “Was sind und was sollen die Zahlen,” Dedekind introduced the concept of finiteness of sets, namely: if F:S\rightarrow T is a 1-1 mapping of a set S onto a subset T, then S=T;(2) Leary [92] generalized the concept to rings R, namely: if whenever f:R\rightarrow R is a monomorphism of R-modules, then f is an isomorphism. In this case R is right Dedekind finite, equivalently, if x\in R and if x^{\perp }=0 then x is a unit. (This follows by considering x=f(1).) (3) For a VNR ring R,x^{\perp }=0 is equivalent to the existence of an element y\in R with yx=1. Thus, the definition in 4.6A for a VNR ring R is equivalent to that given in 4.6A^{\prime }(2); (4) Since xy=1\Rightarrow e=yx is idempotent, any Abelian VNR is DF.

sec.title: Jacobson’s Theorem

statement.label: 4.6B. Theorem
statement.p: A Dedekind Infinite ring R possesses an infinite set \{e_{ij}\}_{i,j=1}^{\infty } of matrix units, hence an infinite set \{e_{ii}\}_{i=1}^{\infty } of orthogonal idempotents.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: If xy=1, then g=yx is an idempotent such that
and the elements
are the desired matrix units, since
where \delta _{jp} is the Kronecker delta (=1 if j=p, and 0 if j\neq p).

sec.p: As defined sup. 3.13, R has \mathrm{acc}{\oplus } denotes finite Goldie dimension, that is, R contains no infinite direct sums of right ideals.

statement.label: 4.6C. Corollary.
statement.p: Any ring R with no infinite set of orthogonal idempotents, in particular, any acc{\perp } or acc{\oplus } ring R, is Dedekind Finite.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) This also shows any semilocal ring R, or any ring R such that R/\mathrm{rad}R has \mathrm{acc}{\perp }, or \mathrm{acc}{\oplus }, is DF; (2) Any subring of a DF ring is DF.

statement.label: 4.6C^{\prime }.
statement.p: Utumi’s Theorem [65]. If each one-sided ideal of R is essential in a direct summand of R, then R is Dedekind Finite.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See loc. cit., or the author’s book [76], p. 86, Theorem 19.41.

statement.label: 4.6C^{\prime \prime }. Corollary.
statement.p: Any right and left self-injecive ring R is Dedekind Finite.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Rings with the property of Utumi’s theorem are called CS-rings (see 12.4Cs), characterized by the property that every complemented right (left) ideal is a direct summand.

sec.title: Shepherdson’s and Montgomery’s Examples
sec.p: (1) Shepherdson [51] shows there exists a domain R such that the 2\times 2 matrix ring R_{2} is not DF.
(2) Montgomery [83] shows that if L is an algebraic extension field of a field k,L\neq k, then there exists an algebra A over k which is a domain, hence DF, such that A\otimes _{R}L is not DF.

sec.title: Group Algebras in Characteristic 0 Are Dedekind Finite

statement.label: 4.6D.
statement.p: Kaplansky’s Theorem [69]. If K is a field of characteristic 0, then for any group G, the group algebra KG is Dedekind Finite.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The proof uses a non-trivial result of Kaplansky (op.cit.) and Zalesski [72] which states that the “trace” a=tr\ e any idempotent e\neq 0,1 is a rational number such that 0<a<1. If xy=1 in KG, then e=yx is an idempotent which has trace =1, hence e=1. (See e.g. Passman [77], p.38.)

def.p: Zalesski [72] proved for any idempotent e of a group algebra KG, that tr\ e lies in the prime subfield of K. See Passman [77], p.48, Theorem 3.5.

Another proof of theorem 4.6D can be given using Theorem 4.6C^{\prime }, Snider’s Theorem 12.0C, and the Johnson-Wong Theorem 12A on self-injective quotient rings of nonsingular rings. See, e.g., Theorem 12.0E.

sec.title: Prime Right Self-injective VNR Rings

statement.label: 4.7A.
statement.p: Utumi’s Theorem [65]. A right self-injective VNR prime ring R is simple under the following assumption: R is Dedekind Finite, in particular, if R is also left self-injective, or left \aleph _{0}-injective.

sec.p: Cf. Goodearl [79], p.106, Theorem 9.30 and also references on p. 109.

statement.label: 4.7B. Theorem
statement.p: Any right and left self-injective VNR ring R is Dedekind Finite and unit regular.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Goodearl, loc.cit., p.105 Theorem 9.29.

statement.label: 4.7C. Corollary.
statement.p: Any right and left self-injective ring is Dedekind Finite.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By Utumi’s theorems 4.2 and 4.7B, R/\mathrm{rad}\ R is DF, hence Prop. 4.4.6A applies.

statement.label: 4.7D. Theorem
statement.p: If R is unit-regular, then every n\times n full matrix ring R_{n} is Dedekind Finite.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Goodearl, loc.cit., p.50, Prop. 5.2.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Also see Henriksen’s theorem 6.3D.

sec.title: Goodearl-Handelman Characterization of Purely Infinite Rings
sec.p: A ring R is purely infinite if R has no Dedekind Finite central idempotents e\neq 0 (= such that eRe Dedekind Finite).
Let _{R}R^{\omega } denote a direct product of \aleph _{0} copies of R as a left R-module.

statement.label: 4.8. Theorem
statement.p: A VNR right self-injective ring R is purely infinite iff _{R}R\approx {_{R}}R^{\omega } (equivalently, _{R}R^{\omega }\hookrightarrow {_{R}}R).

sec.p: Goodearl and Handelman in op.cit. classified simple right self-injective rings. Cf. Hannah [80] on countability in VNR self-injective rings, and also 4.9 and 4.12.

statement.label: 4.9. Corollary
statement.p: If R is a prime VNR right self-injective ring, then R is Dedekind Finite iff R has at most countable left Goldie dimension (=R has no uncountable independent sets of left ideals). Then R is simple.

sec.p: See Goodearl [79], 10.19–20, pp.118–119, and Utumi’s theorem 14.7A above.

sec.title: Kaplansky’s Direct Product Decompositions of VNR Rings
sec.p: A VNR ring R has Type I: if R has a faithful Abelian idempotent e (that is, no central idempotent except 0 is orthogonal to e). \mathrm{I}_{f} denotes Dedekind Finite and \mathrm{I}_{\infty } Dedekind Infinite of Type I.

R has Type II, if R has a faithful Dedekind Finite idempotent e(=eRe is Dedekind Finite) but no Abelian idempotents \neq 0. Types \mathrm{II}_{f} and \mathrm{II}_{\infty } are defined similarly as \mathrm{I}_{f} and \mathrm{I}_{\infty }.
R has Type III if R contains no nonzero Dedekind Finite idempotent.

statement.p: Kaplansky’s Theorem (Special Case). Every VNR right self-injective ring R is uniquely a product of rings of Types I, II, and III. Furthermore, every VNR right self-injective ring is a product of a Dedekind Finite ring and a Dedekind infinite ring, hence R decomposes uniquely into products of rings of Types I_{f},I_{\infty },II_{f},II_{\infty }, and III.

sec.p: This theorem is a special case of Kaplansky’s more general theorems [68]. See Goodearl [79], Theorem 10.13 and 10.22, pp. 115 and 120ff.

sec.title: Kaplansky’s Conjecture on VNR Rings: Domanov’s Counterexample and Goodearl’s and Fisher-Snider’s Theorems
sec.p: The conjecture of Kaplansky: Are prime VNR rings primitive, equivalently, do they have a faithful simple module?
Domanov [77,78] constructed non-primitive prime VNR group algebras over arbitrary fields. See Theorem 11.9^{\prime }.
Goodearl [73b] verified this conjecture for a right self-injective VNR ring.

statement.p: Goodearl’s Theorem [73B]. If R is a right self-injective VNR ring, then:

def.p: The ideals of R that contain a prime ideal P are linearly ordered, under inclusion, and are all prime ideals.
If P is a closed prime ideal of R(=P_{R} has no essential extension in R_{R}), then the ideals of R containing P are well-ordered.
If R is a prime ring, then R is primitive.
If R is directly indecomposable as a ring then R is prime, hence primitive.

sec.p: A set B of nonzero ideals of R is a base if every nonzero ideal contains an ideal in B.

statement.p: Fisher-Snider Theorem [74]. If R is a prime VNR ring with a countable base of ideals \{I_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty }, then R is primitive. In particular, any countable prime VNR ring is primitive.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Domanov’s counterexample and Theorem 4.12 owe to some pioneering work of Formanek and Snider [72]. (See the introduction to Domanov [77].)

sec.title: Azumaya Algebras
sec.p: In considering products of rings we have thus far failed to consider tensor products, which leads inevitably to the consideration of Azumaya algebras, and the Brauer group.

statement.p: Azumaya Algebra Definition and Theorem. An algebra A over a commutative ring k is called an Azumaya algebra if A satisfies the equivalent conditions.

def.p: A is a projective module over the enveloping algebra A^{e}=A\otimes _{k}A^{0}, where A^{0} is the opposite algebra.
A is a finitely generated projective module over k, and A^{e}=End_{k}A canonically.
A^{e} is Morita equivalent to k.
A is a finitely generated module over k, and for all maximal ideals m of k, the factor algebra A/mA is a central simple k/m-algebra.
A is finitely generated projective and central over k and every ideal I of A is of the form I=I_{0}A, where I_{0}=I\cap k.
A generates mod-A^{e} and k=End_{A^{e}} A.

statement.p: When this is so, then k is the center of A.

sec.p: Most of this is due to Azumaya [51] over local k, and the carry-over to general k is due to Auslander-Goldman [60]. (Az 5) is due to Rao [72], and this condition was axiomatized to rings by Azumaya [80]. M. Artin [69] characterized Azumaya algebras containing a field in the center via polynomial identities and Procesi and Small [72] removed the field requirement. See 15.8. Also see Faith [92], p. 550, for additional references and the following:

statement.label: 4.14. Proposition.
statement.p: If A is an Azumaya algebra over a commutative ring k, then the f.a.e.

def.p: A is right self-injective.
A is left self-injective.
k is self-injective.
A^{e} is right self-injective.
A^{e} is left self-injective.

sec.p: In regard to 4.14, see 4.16.

statement.p: Azumaya’s Theorem [51]. If A is an Azumaya algebra over a commutative ring k, and if A is a subalgebra of an algebra K over k, then K\approx A\otimes _{k}A^{\prime }, where A^{\prime } is the centralizer of A in K.

sec.p: A proof and partial converse is given by Bass [68].

statement.label: 4.15A. Remark.
statement.p: A finite dimensional simple central algebra A over k is characterized by the property that K=A\otimes _{k}A^{\prime } for any algebra K over k. See Jacobson [55,64], p.118. The same is true for Azumaya Algebras over k assuming that K is f\cdot g projective over k. (See Bass, ibid.)

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: (1) An algebra A over a commutative ring k is separable provided that A is a projective module over its enveloping algebra A^{e}=A\otimes _{k}A^{0}. (This agrees with the definition given in 2.51. Cf. Hochschild [56], DeMeyer and Ingraham [71].);

(2) An algebra A over a commutative ring k is a k-split-split algebra, provided that an exact sequence 0\rightarrow A\rightarrow B\rightarrow C\rightarrow 0 of A-modules splits whenever it is split as k-modules.

statement.label: 4.15B. Theorem
statement.p: An algebra A over a commutative ring k is separable iff its enveloping algebra A^{e} is a k-split-split algebra.

statement.label: 4.15C. Corollary.
statement.p: An algebm A over k is an Azumaya algebra iff A is a central separable module-finite algebra over k.

sec.title: The Auslander-Goldman-Brauer Group of a Commutative Ring
sec.p: If k is a commutative ring, then the set k-ALG of all k-algebras are a semigroup with respect to the tensor product A\otimes _{k}B of algebras A and B over k. Let [A]=[A^{\prime }] denote that A and A^{\prime } are Morita equivalent k-algebras, which by Morita’s theorem (see 3.51) means that A^{\prime }\approx \mathrm{End}\ P_{A} for a f\cdot g projective generator P for right A-modules. (A generator P for A means that every right A-module is an epimorphic image of copies of P, equivalently that P^{n}\approx A\oplus X for an integer n\geq 1 and a right A-module X.)

Then the set of classes [A] of algebras is a semigroup under the product [A][B]= [A\otimes _{k}B]. Furthermore, the set Br(k) of all [A] such that A is an Azumaya algebra over k is a group such that [A]^{-1}=[A^{0}], called the Brauer Group (Auslander-Goldman [60]). This is named in honor of Richard Brauer [29] who discovered the Brauer group of a field k. In this case every [A]=[D] for a unique finite dimensional division algebra D over k depending on A. The theorems of Wedderburn, Tsen and Chevalley, discussed in §2, are statements about the triviality of the Brauer group over the indicated fields (e.g. finite fields). Moreover, Grothendieck [65] showed that Br(k) is a torsion group for any commutative ring k.

sec.title: Menal’s Theorem on Tensor Products of SI or VNR Algebras

statement.label: 4.16A
statement.p: If A and B are algebras over a field k, and if A\otimes _{k}B is either right self-injective, or VNR, then both A and B enjoy the same property, and furthermore, either A or B is an algebraic algebra over k.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: If A is a two-sided self-injective algebra over a field k, then every non-zero divisor is a unit. Thus, by the Amitsur-Small theorem [96] (see 3.43B), then A is an algebraic algebra when |k|>\dim _{R}A.

sec.p: See Menal’s General Theorem in Faith [92] and also Menal [82] on the radical and semi-primitivity of A\otimes _{R}B for VNR rings A and B.

4.16A is a grand generalization of a lemma used in the proof of Hilbert’s Null-stellensatz, namely that a commutative ring extension K=k[a_{1},\ldots ,a_{n}] of a field k can be a field only if K is algebraic over k.

sec.title: Lawrence’s Theorem on Tensor Products of Semilocal Algebras

statement.label: 4.16B
statement.p: If A and B are algebras over a field k, and if A\otimes _{k}B is semilocal, then A and B are algebraic algebras.

statement.label: 4.16C. Remark.
statement.p: Sweedler [75] (for commutative algebras) and Lawrence [76] characterize when a tensor product of algebras over a field is local.

sec.p: One consequence of Menal’s theorem is:

statement.label: 4.17A.
statement.p: Busqué-Herbera Theorem. If in Menal’s theorem the product A\otimes _{k}B is QF, then either A or B is QF.

sec.p: See Busqué [93], Prop. 2.1. The proof uses Theorem 3.7.
Another theorem of Menal is of interest to the study of self-injective VNR rings.

statement.label: 4.17B. Theorem
statement.p: Every right self-injective VNR ring is isomorphic to a product of algebras over fields.

sec.p: See Busqué [93], Lemma 2.4.

sec.title: Armendariz-Steinberg Theorem
sec.p: It has been noted in several places in the literature that the center of a self-injective ring need not be self-injective. (See, e.g. Pascaud-Valette [79], Herbera-Menal [89] or Clark [89]). In this connection, one notes:

statement.p: Armendariz-Steinberg Theorem [74]. If R is a right self-injective VNR ring, then the center of R is also.

sec.title: Strongly Regular Extensions of Rings
sec.p: As defined by Arens and Kaplansky [48] a ring A is strongly regular (s.r.) in case to each \alpha \in A there corresponds x=x_{\alpha }\in A depending on \alpha such that \alpha ^{2}x=\alpha . As stated following 4.2C, Abelian VNR is a variant term.

A ring A is defined to be a s.r. extension of a subring B in case each \alpha \in A satisfies \alpha ^{2}x-\alpha \in B with x=x_{\alpha }\in A. S.r. rings are, then, s.r. extensions of each subring. A ring A which is a s.r. extension of the center has been called a \xi -ring (see Utumi [57], Drazin [57], and Martindale [58].)

statement.label: 4.19A. Theorem
statement.p: A s.r. ring is a subdirect product of division rings.

sec.p: Since any s.r. ring is semiprimitive, a later result stating that any semiprimitive \xi -ring is a subdirect product of division rings (see (Martindale [58], op.cit.) contains this result.

statement.label: 4.19B. Theorem
statement.p: If a semiprimitive ring A is a s.r. extension of a commutative subring B, then A is a subdirect product of division rings.

sec.p: The proof depends on the following:

statement.label: 4.19C. Theorem
statement.title: (op.cit.).
statement.p: If A is a primitive ring, not a division ring, and if A/B is s.r., then B is dense in the finite topology on A.

statement.label: 4.19D. Corollary.
statement.p: (op.cit.). In order that a semiprimitive ring A be a s.r. extension of a subring B, it is necessary that B be a subdirect product of primitive rings and integral domains.

sec.title: Pseudo-Frobenius (PF) Rings
sec.p: Right PF rings, generalizing QF rings, were introduced by Azumaya [66] as rings R such that every faithful right R-module is a generator in the category of right R-modules.

statement.label: 4.20. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right Pseudo-Frobenius (=PF) iff R satisfies the equivalent conditions:

def.p: R is right self-injective semiperfect and has essential right socle (=ES).
R is right self-injective and has finite essential right socle (= right finitely embedded).
R is an injective cogenemtor for mod-R.
R is right self-injective and every simple right module embeds in R.
Every faithful right R-module M generates mod-R, that is, there exists an epimorphism M^{n}\rightarrow R for some integer n, depending on M.

sec.p: Cf. Faith [76a], 24.32. Every 2-sided PF ring has a Morita self-duality induced by \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(\ ,R). See 13.7. Also see Rutter [71], where this theorem is extended to the endomorphism ring of “PF-modules”.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: In connection with (PF2), see the theorem of Beachy-Kamil 3.60. Thus, (PF2) via 3.60 implies that R embeds in a finite product M^{n} of any faithful module, so injectivity implies that R splits in M^{n}, hence (PF6) holds.

sec.p: Note, 3.33B and C imply that over a left perfect ring R, every right R-module M has ES. Thus by (PF1):

statement.label: 4.21. Corollary.
statement.p: Every left perfect right self-injective ring R is right PF. Consequently, a semiprimary right self-injective ring is right PF.

sec.p: The next result is used in the proof of the Faith-Walker Theorem 3.5B.

statement.label: 4.21A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is semilocal then any f\cdot g projective cogenerator of mod-R is injective, and R is right self-injective.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Loc. cit., also Proposition 24.9, p.206, of Faith [76].

statement.label: 4.21B. Corollary.
statement.p: Any semilocal right cogenerator ring R is right PF.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Osofsky [66] proved the converse of Cor. 4.21B. Cf. Theorem 4.20.

statement.label: 4.22. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions:

def.p: R is QF.
R is left perfect, right and left PF.
R is right self-injective, left perfect, and J/J^{2} is finitely generated in mod-R.

statement.label: 4.22A.
statement.p: Proposition and Definition. A ring R is right Kasch if R satisfies the equivalent properties:

def.p: Every maximal right ideal of R is a right annihilator;
Every simple right R-module embeds in R;
The injective hull E(R_{R}) is a cogenerator of mod-R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: (1) \Rightarrow (2) since if M is a maximal right R-module, and if (1) holds then M=x^{\perp } for some 0\neq x\in R, hence
Since every simple right module V\approx R/M for some such M, then (1) \Rightarrow (2).

Conversely, (2) \Rightarrow (1) since if f:R/M\hookrightarrow R, then x^{\perp }=M where x=f(1). (3) is an immediate consequence, since R is essential in E(R), hence a simple module V\hookrightarrow E(R) iff V\hookrightarrow R.

statement.label: 4.22B. Theorem.
statement.p: A ring R is right PF iff R is right Kasch and right self-injective.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This follows immediately from (PF5) of Theorem 4.20.

statement.label: 4.22C. Theorem
statement.p: Any right PF ring R is right and left Kasch. (Cf. 4.23A.)

def.p: A right PF ring R is left PF iff R is left self-injective.
A ring R is left and right PF iff R is a left and right cogenerator.
Every factor module of R^{2} (both in mod-R and R-mod) is torsionless iff R is left and right PF.

statement.label: 4.23B. Corollary
statement.p: A left perfect right and left self-injective ring is QF.

statement.title: (Osofsky’s Example).
statement.p: The Split-Null or Trivial Extension B\ltimes E of a (B,B)-bimodule E (i.e., (ax)b=a(xb)\ \forall a,b\in B,x\in E) is a ring whose additive group is the product B\ltimes E and whose multiplication is defined by (a,x)(b,y)= (ab,xb+ax). B\times E is isomorphic to a ring 2\times 2 matrices under a mapping

Osofsky [66] gave the first non-Artinian, i.e., non-QF example of a PF ring, namely, the split-null or trivial extension \mathbb{Z}_{(p)}\ltimes \mathbb{Z}_{p^{\infty }} where Z_{(p)}\approx \mathrm{End}\mathbb{Z}_{p^{\infty }} is the ring of p-adic integers, i.e., the completion of the local ring \mathbb{Z}_{p}.
Moreover:

statement.label: 4.25. Theorem
statement.title: (Faith [79b], Fossum-Griffith-Reiten [75]).
statement.p: If E is a (B,B)-bimodule such that _{B}E is faithful, then the split-null extension R=B\ltimes E is right self-injective (resp. right PF) iff E_{B} is injective (resp. injective cogenerator) and B=EndE_{B}.

def.p: The needed (and used) hypothesis _{B}E faithful was missing in Faith [79].
Using this theorem, Dischinger and Müller [86] proved that a right PF ring need not be left PF.

sec.title: FPF Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right FPF if every f\cdot g faithful right R-module generates mod-R. Any right PF ring is trivially FPF; also any Prüfer domain is FPF. See Faith-Pillay [90] for additional examples. Endo [67] originated the concept, but not the terminology, of FPF rings. See 4.27ff.

statement.p: Camillo-Fuller [76]. A ring R is right (F)PF iff every (f\cdot g) faithful right R-module is left flat over its endomorphism ring.
Endo’s Theorem [67]. A Noetherian commutative ring R is FPF iff R is a finite product of Dedekind domains and QF local rings.

sec.p: See, e.g. Reiner [75], for the concept of A-order in the next two theorems.

statement.label: 4.28A. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a Noetherian commutative domain with quotient field K, then a projective A-order R of a semisimple K-algebra S is right FPF iff R is a hereditary maximal order in S.

statement.label: 4.28B. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a semiprime ring that is module finite over its center A. Then R is FPF if and only if R is a semihereditary maximal A order in a left and right self-injective ring.

sec.p: The next theorem generalizes Endo’s theorem for Noetherian R. Cf. 5.42.

statement.p: Splitting Theorem (Faith [79A], Faith-Pillay[90]. Any commutative FPF ring R splits: R=R_{1}\times R_{2} where R_{1} is semihereditary and R_{2} has essential nil radical.

sec.p: See, e.g. Faith-Pillay, p.57. An ideal I of R is a waist if every ideal of R either contains I or is contained in I.

statement.p: Local fpf Ring Theorem (Op.cit.). If R is a commutative local ring then R is FPF iff Q(R) is injective, the singular ideal Z(R) is a waist of R, and R/Z(R) is a valuation domain.

sec.p: See, e.g., Faith-Pillay, p.56, Theorem 3.9. The proof uses the characterization of commutative FPF rings—see 5.42.

statement.label: 4.31. Theorem
statement.p: A one-sided perfect two-sided FPF ring is QF.

sec.p: This generalizes Kato-Osofsky’s theorem for one-sided perfect two-sided PF (see 4.24).

statement.label: 4.32. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a separable k-algebra whose center is a free k-module, then A is FPF iff k is FPF.

sec.p: Note. This extends results of S. Page for when C=k, and Herbera - Menal [89] for the group algebra A=kG of a finite group of unit order.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: For additional results on FPF rings, see the lecture notes of FaithPage [84] and Faith-Pillay [90]; and the papers of Clark [89], Herbera [91], Herbera and Menal [89], Herbera and Pillay [93], Faticoni [84, 87, 88], Kobayashi [85, 88], Yoshimura [91], [94], and Yousif [91]. See the author’s papers [77b], [79a, b, c], [82b] and [84b, c, d]. Also see 5.23ff for when products of FPF rings are FPF and 5.40ff. for some FPF structure theorems. For when cyclic faithful modules are generators, see Birkenmeier [87,89] and Yoshimura [95], [98]. Yoshimura [01] gave a survey of FPF rings.

sec.label: Chapter 5
sec.title: Direct Sums of Cyclic Modules
sec.p: A semisimple ring R has the following property: right \Sigma -cyclic: every right R-module M is a direct sum of cyclic modules.
The corresponding property for finitely generated right R-modules is called right \sigma -cyclic or FGC ring.

statement.label: 5.1A. Theorem
statement.p: Artinian commutative \Sigma -cyclic rings are the finite product of Artinian chain rings.

sec.p: Cohen-Kaplansky [51] proved the Artinian hypothesis redundant. This also follows from Chase’s Theorem 3.4E.
To proceed, we pause for additional definitions.

A ring R is completely primary in case it is a local ring with nilpotent radical. A primary ring is a ring which is isomorphic to a full ring of n\times n matrices over a completely primary ring. As stated previously, R is semiprimary in case rad R is nilpotent, and R/\mathrm{rad}R is semisimple. Thus, by 3.31 a semiprimary ring is left and right perfect. A semiprimary ring, then, may not be a direct sum of primary rings. We cite Asano’s criterion:

statement.label: 5.1A^{\prime }.
statement.p: Asano’s Criterion [49]. For a semiprimary ring R with radical J, the conditions are equivalent:

def.p: R is primary-decomposable,
R/J^{2} is primary-decomposable,
the prime ideals of R are commutative,
the prime ideals are comaximal in pairs.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The proof requires the Chinese Remainder Theorem. See for example, the author’s Algebra II, p.50, 18.37.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Fitting [35b] proved this for an order R in a finite dimensional simple algebra.

sec.title: Uniserial and Serial Rings
sec.p: A generalized left uniserial ring is a left Artinian ring R in which each principal indecomposable left ideal has a unique composition series as a left R-module. A left uniserial ring is a left serial ring which is a direct product of finitely many primary rings. A left serial ring R is a ring (not necessarily Artinian) which is a finite direct sum of uniserial (= chain) left modules (e.g. a finite direct sum of valuation rings is serial).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Any left serial ring R is a semilocal ring, and every homomorphic image of R is left serial. (See, e.g., Fachini [98], p. 11, Lemma 1.20 and Proposition 1.22.)

sec.p: An Artinian principal ideal ring is a ring which is both left and right Artinian and a left and right principal ideal ring.

statement.label: 5.1B.
statement.p: Classical PIR Theorem. Any commutative PIR is FGC.

sec.p: This follows classically since PIR’s are elementary divisor rings (see 6.3), or one can apply 7.5A and reduce to Artinian PIR’s (which are uniserial, hence \sum -cyclic) and PID’s which are FGC by the Fundamental Theorem of Abelian groups.
Uzkov put on the finishing touches:

statement.label: 5.1C. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative Noetherian ring R is FGC iff R is a PIR.

statement.label: 5.2A. Theorem
statement.p: Artinian serial rings are \Sigma -cychc.

sec.p: Below, J(R)= rad R.

statement.label: 5.2B
statement.p: A semiprimary ring R is Artinian uniserial if R/J(R)^{2} is QF.

sec.p: See Faith [76], p.237–238, Cor.25.4.3 and Props. 25.4.6A and B. Also see 5.2E below, 13.7A, and 13.15.

statement.label: 5.2C. Theorem
statement.title: (Murase [63, 64], Amdal-Ringdal [68], and Eisenbud-Griffith [71b]).
statement.p: Any Artinian serial ring A decomposes into a product A_{0}\times A_{1}\times A_{2}\times A_{3} where J(R) denotes the radical of any ring R, and:

def.p: A_{0} is semisimple and A_{i} has no semisimple direct factors, i>0.
A_{1} is Artinian PIR.
A_{2} has finite global dimension modulo J(A_{2})^{2} (=the square of its radical).
A_{3} is QF modulo J(A_{3})^{2}.

statement.label: 5.2D. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is a serial Artinian ring iff every left R-module is a direct sum of uniserial modules.

sec.p: Cf. Skornyakov [69].

statement.label: 5.2E. Theorem
statement.p: For a left Artinian ring R the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is serial,
every 2-generated module is a direct sum of uniserial modules,
every indecomposable (right and left) module is quasi-injective (=QI),
every indecomposable module is quasi-projective (=QP),
every indecomposable left R-module is both QI and QP,
R/J(R)^{2} is serial,
every indecomposable injective, or projective, left R-module is uniserial.

statement.label: 5.3A. Theorem
statement.p: A hereditary Noetherian prime (=HNP) ring R is an Artinian serial ring modulo any ideal I\neq 0 (Cf. 7.1).

statement.label: 5.3B. Theorem.
statement.p: Over a hereditary Noetherian prime (HNP) ring R every finitely generated module M is a direct sum of uniserial (= has a unique decomposition series) modules and right ideals.

sec.p: This follows since Kaplansky’s theorem for modules over hereditary rings implies that the torsion submodule t(M) splits off, and that M/t(M) is isomorphic to a direct sum of right ideals; then the theorem of Eisenbud, Griffith and Robson above applies: modulo any nonzero ideal R is a (generalized uni) serial ring, so by Nakayama’s theorem just cited M\approx t(M)\oplus M/t(M) is isomorphic to a direct sum of uniserial modules and right ideals.

statement.label: 5.3C. Theorem
statement.p: A Noetherian serial ring is a direct product of an Artinian serial ring and a finite product of hereditary prime rings.

sec.p: Cf. Chatter’s Theorem 7.2; also Robson’s Theorem 7.4.

sec.title: Nonsingular Rings
sec.p: A ring R is left nonsingular if x=0 is the only element with essential left annihilator {^\perp }{x}, that is, R has zero left singular ideal. (See §12 for an elaboration and an equivalent formulation.) Thus, R is a left nonsingular ring if _{R}R is a nonsingular module (sup. 4.1E).
For the concept \oplus acc, see sup. 3.13.

statement.label: 5.3D. Theorem
statement.p: For a semiperfect ring R the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is left nonsingular (=n.s.) and serial.
R is left semihereditary (=s.h.), \oplus acc, and Q_{\max }^{\ell }(R) is left flat over R.
R is left n.s., has finite left Goldie dimension (=\oplus acc) and all f\cdot g non-singular left modules are projective.
R is serial and s.h. (both sides).

sec.title: Bounded Rings
sec.p: For the next several results, we require some definitions.

def.p: A ring R is right bounded if every essential right ideal contains an ideal which is an essential right ideal.
A ring R is weakly right bounded if every essential right ideal contains a nonzero ideal.
A ring R is strongly right bounded if every nonzero right ideal contains a nonzero ideal, equivalently, R is the only faithful cyclic right R-module.

R is right fully bounded (=\mathbf{FB}) if every prime factor ring of R is right bounded. Since every nonzero ideal of a prime ring is an essential right ideal, this is equivalent to the definition of FB sup.3.36E. As before, FBN denotes fully bounded Noetherian.
Levy and Smith (see Theorem 5.3F below) use the term essentially right bounded to mean right bounded.
Faith and Page [84], Definition 1.3A, use the term right bounded to mean weakly right bounded. (See Theorem 5.44B.)

A strongly right bounded ring R is right bounded. (Proof: If I is any nonzero right ideal then I contains an ideal A which is essential in I when R is strongly right bounded. [See, e.g., Faith-Page [84], Note 1.3D.] Then, if I is essential in R, so is A.)
Trivially any commutative ring R is right bounded
A semisimple ring R is right (and left) bounded since R is the only essential right (resp. left) ideal. See Theorem 2.1

A simple ring R is weakly right bounded iff R is semisimple. (By (4), any semisimple ring R is right bounded, hence weakly right bounded. To see the converse for a simple ring R, if I is any right ideal, and if K is a complement right ideal, then H=I+K is an essential right ideal and I\cap K=0. (See 3.2Es.) Then H contains a nonzero ideal, so H=R by simplicity of R, hence I is a direct summand of R. Thus, R is semisimple.)
A simple ring R is strongly right bounded iff R is a sfield.

If R is a prime ring, and if R is module-finite over a commutative Noetherian ring, then every essential one-sided ideal of R contains a nonzero central element, hence R is right and left fully bounded. (See Goodearl-Warfield [89], Prop. 8.1, p.132. The proof is non-trivial.)
Any full matrix ring over a commutative ring R is fully bounded, and so is any subring. Furthermore:
The ring of integral quaternions is fully bounded. (Loc. cit. p.133.)
Obviously any factor ring of a right FBN ring is FBN. Moreover, any right FBN ring is right bounded. (Loc. cit., Exercise 8F, p.137.)
If R is right FBN, then any right primitive factor ring is simple Artinian, hence semisimple, (Loc. cit., Prop. 8.4, p.134.) Thus, any right FBN primitive ring is simple Artinian.

statement.label: 5.3E. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a prime right Goldie right bounded ring such that R/I is an Artinian serial ring for every ideal I\neq 0, then R is right hereditary.

statement.label: 5.3F. Theorem
statement.p:
If R is an essentially right bounded⁠11
See Remark (1) above., right Noetherian semiprime ring such that R/I is a serial ring for each right essential two-sided ideal, then R is right hereditary.

statement.label: 5.3G. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right Noetherian semiprime ring whose proper factor rings are all (left and right) serial rings, then either R is a serial Noetherian ring, or a prime ring.

sec.title: FGC Rings
sec.p: All rings in this section are commutative.

Kaplansky [49, 52] (cf. [69], p.80) initiated the problem of determining all FGC commutative rings; when all f\cdot g modules decompose into a direct sum of cyclic modules. In 1952, Kaplansky proved that almost valuation domains are FGC domains, and for several decades, these and PID’s were the only known FGC domains.

A domain R is (Matlis) h-local provided that: (1) every prime ideal P\neq 0 is contained in exactly one maximal ideal (=R/P is a local ring); 2) every ideal I\neq 0 is contained in just finitely many maximal ideals (=R/I is semilocal).

statement.label: 5.4A.
statement.p: Matlis’ Theorem [66]. A domain R is h-local iff

sec.p: The “h” stands for “homological” (Cf. Matlis [66] and [72], p.27), and mspecR is the set of all maximal ideals.

sec.title: Linearly and Semicompact Modules
sec.p: A right R-module M is linearly compact (=\,l.c.) in the discrete topology if (\star ) any finitely solvable system \{x\equiv x_{a}(\mathrm{mod}\, I_{a})\,|\,a\in A\} of congruences is solvable for any index set A, where x_{a}\in M and I_{a} is a submodule. Any Artinian module is l.c.; any right l.c. ring R is semiperfect (Sandomierski [72]).
A ring R is semicompact (Matlis [59]) if (\star ) holds true assuming just that each I=\mathrm{ann}_{M}X for a subset X\neq \phi of R (i.e., I is an annihilator submodule).
SC 1 Theorem (Matlis [59]). Any injective module over a commutative ring R is semicompact.
SC 2 Theorem (Fleischer [58]). If R is a Prüfer domain, any divisible semi-compact module is injective.
SC 3 Theorem (Matlis [85]). For an f\cdot g-injective module M over a commutative ring, the following are equivalent:

def.p: M is injective,
M is semi-compact,
M is “principally” semicompact.

sec.p: Cf. Theorem 6.B.

sec.title: Maximal Rings
sec.p: R is a maximal ring if it is commutative and linearly compact. Then R is a finite product of local rings, hence semilocal (Zelinsky [53]). Furthermore, then and only then R has a Morita duality (Ánh [90]. Cf. Morita [58] and Mueller [70]). If R is l.c. with Jacobson radical J and J^{\omega }=\bigcap _{n\in \omega }J^{n} then R/J^{\omega } is Noetherian (Mueller [70]).

See Zariski-Samuel [60], Nagata [62] and Cohen [46] for the completion \hat{R}_{p} of a local ring R_{p}. Any complete local Noetherian ring, e.g. any Artinian ring, is maximal (see 5.4B). Furthermore:

statement.label: 5.4A^{\prime }. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a Noetherian commutative semilocal ring with Jacobson radical m, and let (a_{1},\ldots ,a_{n}) be an ideal whose radical is m. Then the completion R^{\ast } of R in the m-adic topology is isomorphic to the power series ring A in n variables over R modulo the ideal (a_{1}-x_{1},\ldots a_{n}-x_{n}) of A.

statement.label: 5.4A^{\prime \prime }. Theorem
statement.p: Let m_{1},\ldots ,m_{n} be the maximal ideals of R in Theorem 5.4A^{\prime }. Then R^{\ast } is the finite product of the completions of the local rings of R at m_{i},i=1,\ldots ,n.

sec.title: Almost Maximal Valuation, and Arithmetic Rings
sec.p: A ring R is almost maximal if R/I is maximal for all ideals I\neq 0. R is locally almost maximal if R_{M} is almost maximal for each maximal ideal M. An (almost) maximal valuation ring is a valuation ring that is (almost) maximal. A ring R is (right) Bezout if all f\cdot g (right) ideals are principal. Any valuation ring is Bezout, and conversely for a local ring. R is an Arithmetic ring if R is locally a valuation ring. Any semilocal Arithmetic ring is Bezout (Hinohara [62]). Cf. Kaplansky [70-74], p.37, Theorem 60.

statement.label: 5.4B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative and Noetherian, and P is a prime ideal, then the completion \hat{R}_{p} is a commutative Noetherian complete local ring, hence maximal (i.e., linearly compact), and\approx End_{R}E(R/P). Moreover, E(R/P) is an Artinian \hat{R}_{p}-module (cf. 5.4E).

statement.label: 5.4C. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative valuation domain R with quotient field Q is almost maximal iff Q/R is injective.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Also see Theorems 6.19 and 6.19A.

sec.p: Note, by Gupta’s theorem 4.2B, for any valuation domain, Q/R is f\cdot g-injective.

statement.label: 5.4D. Theorem
statement.p: A valuation ring R with maximal ideal M is almost maximal iff E(R/M) is a uniserial module.

statement.label: 5.4E. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative and M is an Artinian right R-module with simple socle, then A=End_{R}M is a complete local Noetherian commutative ring and M_{A} is the minimal injective cogenerator.

statement.label: 5.5. Theorem
statement.p: A locally almost maximal h-local Bezout domain is FGC.

statement.label: 5.6. Theorem
statement.title: (Brandal [73], Th. 2.9).
statement.p: A commutative domain is almost maximal iff it is h-local and locally almost maximal (cf. S. Wiegand [75]).

statement.label: 5.7. Theorem
statement.title: (Kaplansky [52], Brandal [73] and Shores-Wiegand [74]).
statement.p: An almost maximal commutative Bezout domain is FGC.

sec.p: Kaplansky [52] proved this for Almost Maximal Valuation Domains (= AMVD), whereas Gill [71] and Lafon [69] extended it to general almost maximal valuation rings (=\ AMVR).

sec.title: Torch Rings
sec.p: R is a torch ring (Shores and Wiegand [74]; also called an umbrella ring elsewhere) provided:

def.p: R is not local,
R has a unique minimal prime ideal P,
The ideals of R contained in P form a chain under inclusion,
R/P is h-local, and
R is Bezout and locally almost maximal.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See Facchini [83] for examples of torch rings that are not trivial extensions of h-local domains.

statement.label: 5.8. Theorem
statement.p: A torch ring is FGC.

sec.title: Fractionally Self-injective Rings
sec.p: A commutative ring R is fractionally self-injective (= FSI) if for every ideal I the factor ring R/I has self-injective classical quotient ring Q(R/I). In this case Q(R/I) is FSI for every ideal I.

statement.label: 5.9. Theorem
statement.title: (Vámos [77B, 79]).
statement.p: Every FSI ring R is a finite product of indecomposable FSI rings. The indecomposable FSI rings are either (I) AMVR’s; (II) h-local domains which are locally almost maximal; or (III) torch rings.

statement.label: 5.10. Theorem
statement.p: Every FGC ring has only finitely many minimal prime ideals.

sec.p: This not only classified reduced FGC rings, but actually in a footnote Vámos [7b] pointed out that this theorem together with his results completed the classification of FGC rings as follows (cf. Vámos [79]).

sec.title: FGC Classification Theorem

statement.p: FGC Classification Theorem. The following conditions are equivalent conditions on a commutative ring R.

def.p: R is a FGC ring (=f\cdot g modules are direct sum of cyclic modules),
R is FSI and Bezout,
R is Bezout and a finite product of the three types of rings (I), (II), and (III) of 5.9.

sec.p: Vámos [75] also studied commutative rings, called SISI rings, over which every subdirectly irreducible factor ring is self-injective. Morita rings, locally Noetherian rings, and FSI rings are important examples (see sup. 9.1).

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: G. Köthe proved that an Artinian commutative ring R with the property

is an uniserial (einreihig) ring (see 5.1A). Cohen and Kaplansky [51] countered with the observation that it was redundant to assume that R is Artinian. S.U. Chase [60] proved commutativity is not necessary to assert the ring is right Artinian, and moreover, that finitely generated modules can replace the cyclics in the statement. (But, then, the ring is no longer necessarily serial, of course.) Finally Faith and Walker [67], Faith [71], and Vámos [71] noticed that finite cardinality of the modules in the direct summands played no role; if there exists a set of modules such that every right module decomposes into a direct sum of modules isomorphic to modules in that set, then the ring is right Artinian. Cf. Griffith [70]. The proof of this makes heavy use of another theorem of Chase [60] (see 1.17A) on direct sum decompositions of modules: If there is a cardinal number c not less than the cardinal of R such that the product R^{c} is a pure submodule (for example, a direct summand) of a direct sum of right R-modules having cardinal not exceeding c, then R satisfies the dec on principal left ideals (= right perfect rings).

sec.title: Classification of FPF and CFPF Rings

statement.label: 5.12A. Remark.
statement.p: As defined sup 4.26, a ring is FPF if every finitely generated faithful module generates mod-R, and CFPF if all factor rings of R are FPF. A theorem of Faith ([82a]) shows that any FPF commutative ring R has self-injective quotient ring, hence any CFPF ring is FSI and conversely (cf. Faith and Pillay [90], pp. 67–68). Also see 5.31ff, esp. 5.42.

statement.label: 5.12B. Remark.
statement.p: A reduced commutative ring R is FPF iff R is a semihereditary ring with self-injective quotient ring Q (Faith [79], cf. Faith-Pillay [90]). This is an easy consequence of 5.42.

statement.label: 5.13A. Theorem
statement.p: For a commutative local ring R, the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is FPF.
Every faithful module generated by two elements generates mod-R.
Every faithful module generated by two elements is a direct sum of cyclics.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Loc. cit., p.193, Theorem 25.

statement.label: 5.13B. Corollary.
statement.p: For a commutative local ring R, the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is CFPF.
R is AMVR.
Every 2-generated module is a direct sum of cyclics.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Ibid.

sec.title: Maximal Completions of Valuation Rings
sec.p: The principal ideals of a valuation ring R with maximal ideal m is a totally ordered monoid under reverse order by inclusion, called the valuemonoid M (Shores [74]). Let (R,m,M) denote this situation. Then (R^{\prime },m^{\prime },M^{\prime }) is said to be an extension of (R,m,M) if R^{\prime }\supseteq R amd m^{\prime }\cap R=m. The extension is said to be immediate provided that k^{\prime }=R^{\prime }/m^{\prime }\approx k=R/m and M^{\prime }\approx M canonically. Then R is maximally complete if (R,m,M) has no proper immediate extension.

R^{\prime } is called a maximal completion of R if (R^{\prime },m^{\prime },M^{\prime }) is an immediate extension and R^{\prime } is maximally complete. See Kaplansky [42], p.303, Schilling [50], p.39; Ostrowski [35], p.368 gives a slightly different definition. Also see Vicknair [87], p.56, for this and the following:

statement.label: 5.14A. Proposition.
statement.p: The cardinality of a valuation ring [R,m,M] is bounded by that of k[[M]], where k=R/m.

statement.label: 5.14B. Corollary.
statement.p: Every valuation ring R has a maximal completion.

statement.label: 5.14C. Remark.
statement.p: According to Kleiner [99], the concept of a valuation of general fields extending Hensel’s p-adic valuations is due to Kürshak in 1913, who proved the existence of their completions, and in 1918 Ostrowski determined all valuations of the field \mathbb{Q} of rational numbers. Also see Ribenboim [99].

sec.p: The next theorem is due to Kaplansky [42], Theorem 4, when R is a domain, and Vicknair [87], Theorem 1.2 for general R.

statement.label: 5.15A. Theorem.
statement.p: A maximal valuation ring R is maximally complete, and conversely for a valuation domain R.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) By Gill [70], any almost maximal valuation ring R with zero divisors is maximal; (2) It is easy to see that any FGC ring is FPF: if M is finitely generated, then M=R/I_{1}\oplus \cdots \oplus R/I_{n} for ideals I_{1}\subset I_{2}\subset \cdots \subset I_{n} (i.e. R is an elementary divisor ring (see sup 6.3) in accordance with the structure theory of FGC rings (see e.g. Brandal [79] or Vámos [77]), so M is faithful only if I_{1}=0, so M\approx R\oplus X in mod-R as required. Thus, any FGC ring is CFPF.

sec.title: Mac Lane’s and Vámos’ Theorems

statement.label: 5.15B. Theorem
statement.p: If K is a field with a maximal valuation, then K is algebraically closed iff the value group is divisible and the residue field of the valuation ring is algebraically closed.

sec.p: Cf. Kaplansky’s article in op.cit., esp.p.523, §6. Also Vámos [75b], p.107, Prop.9, and Theorem A, p.108. Ánh [97] has a new approach and discusses the relation with Newton’s method of approximating roots.

statement.label: 5.15C. Theorem
statement.p: A field K is multiply maximally complete with respect to two inequivalent non-trivial valuations iff K is algebraically closed and |K|^{\aleph _{0}}=|K|.

statement.label: 5.15D. Corollary.
statement.p: A maximally complete field K is multiply maximally complete iff K is algebraically closed.

sec.p: This follows from Vámos’ theorem because any maximal valuation domain R not a field satisfies |R|^{\aleph _{0}}=|R| by Proposition 4, op.cit. Also see F.K. Schmidt [33] and Schilling [50], Chap. 7, on multiply complete fields.

sec.title: Gill’s Theorem
sec.p: Let (R,m) denote a local ring with maximal ideal m.

statement.label: 5.16. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative local ring (R,m) is an almost maximal valuation ring ( = AMVR) iff E=E(R/m) is uniserial. (Thus, if R is not a domain, then R is an MVR iff E is uniserial.)
Mueller-Ánh Theorem. A commutative local ring (R,m) is maximal, equivalently, linearly compact iff E=E(R/m) is linearly compact over R and R\approx End_{R}E canonically.

sec.p: This follows from Ánh’s Theorem 13.6, and Mueller’s Theorems 13.5 and 13.1.

statement.label: 5.18. Corollary.
statement.p: A commutative local ring (R,m) is a MVR iff R is linearly compact and E(R/m) is uniserial.

sec.title: Vamosian Rings
sec.p: A commutative ring R is Vamosian (after the author’s paper [86b]) provided E(R/m) is linearly compact (=\;l.c.) for all maximal ideals m. A ring R is SISI provided that subdirectly irreducible factor rings are self-injective, equivalently (Vámos [75]), E(R/m) is fully invariant for all maximal ideals m (equivalently, submodules of E(R/m) are quasi-injective).

statement.label: Example.
statement.p: (Vámos [75]). Any commutative Morita ring R, (hence by Ánh’s theorem 13.6 any l.c. R), is Vamosian, and any Vamosian ring is SISI.

Another (Vámos) example: If R_{m} is Noetherian for all maximal ideals m (= R is locally Noetherian), then R is SISI. In this case, R[x] is locally Noetherian, hence SISI, for any variable x (see, e.g. Faith [86b]).

statement.label: 5.19. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative valuation ring R is an AMVR iff R is SISI. (Thus, a SISI valuation ring with zero divisors is maximal.)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Vámos’ Theorem [75], p.126, was stated for R Vamosian (= classical in op.cit.).

sec.title: Quotient Finite Dimensional Modules
sec.p: An R-module M is quotient finite dimensional ( = q.f.d.) provided that every factor module M/N of M has finite Goldie dimension.

statement.label: 5.20A. Theorem
statement.p: A right R-module M is q.f.d. iff every factor module has f\cdot g socle.

statement.label: 5.20B. Theorem
statement.p: An R-module M is q.f.d. iff for every submodule N there is a f\cdot g submodule S such that rad(N/S)=N/S, that is, N/S has no maximal submodules.

sec.p: Camillo’s proof requires ideas of a theorem of Shock [74]. See 7.21ff and “Letter from Victor Camillo”.
It is known that any linearly compact module M is q.f.d. See Herbera-Shamsuddin [95] for references. Also see 6.37.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: A module M is Noetherian iff M is q.f.d. and satisfies the acc on subdirectly irreducible submodules (Faith [98]). See 16.50.

statement.label: 5.21. Theorem
statement.p: Over a semilocal commutative Vamosian ring R, every f\cdot g module M is q.f.d.

statement.label: 5.21. Example
statement.p: If R=k[[x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n},\ldots ]] is the power series ring in infinitely many variables, and if A is the factor ring modulo the ideal generated by all products \{x_{i}x_{j}\}_{i,j=1}^{\infty }, then A is SISI but not Vamosian. Every subdirectly irreducible factor ring of A has Jordan-Hölder length \leq 2, hence is QF, hence self-injective, so A is SISI, but not q.f.d., hence not Vamosian.

sec.title: The Genus of a Module and Generic Families of Rings
sec.p: A right module M over a ring R is said to have a unimodular element (UME) if there exists u\in M such that uR is a direct summand of M canonically isomorphic to R. Thus, M has a UME iff there is an epimorphism M\twoheadrightarrow R.

Thus, M generates mod-R if and only if M^{n}\rightarrow R is onto for some integer n>0; equivalently, M^{n} has a UME. In this case, we let \gamma (M) denote the infimum of all such integers n, and call this the genus of M. If M does not generate mod-R, we set \gamma (M)=\infty . The (little) right genus of a ring R will be denoted by g_{r}(R) and is defined to be the supremum of \gamma (M)<\infty for M finitely generated in mod-R. The big right genus G_{r}(R) is defined similarly without restriction on finite generation of M. Clearly, g_{r}(R)\leq G_{r}(R), and equality holds when R is a right Noetherian ring (R. Wiegand, 5.25). Also by a theorem of Vasconcelos and Wiegand, if \dim R=n<\infty , then G(R)\leq n+1 (see 5.25).

A family F=\{R_{i}\}_{i\in I} of rings is generic of (with) bound B or right B-generic if there exists a function B:\mathbb{Z}^{+}\rightarrow \mathbb{Z}^{+} such that for all modules M if \gamma (M)<\infty and \nu (M)<\infty is the minimal number of elements in any set of generators of M, then \gamma (M)\leq B(\nu (M)). The product theorem states that any product of a generic family of rings of bound B is a ring which is generic of bound B (considering a ring as a family with one member) (see Theorem 5.28).

For example, a family of rings each of genus \leq g is generic with bound \leq g, where g also denotes the constant function. Moreover, any family of commutative rings is generic of bound 1_{\mathbb{Z}^+}. A corollary of the product theorem is that any product R=\Pi _{i\in I}R_{i} of a generic family of right FPF rings is right FPF. (In particular, the product of any family of commutative FPF rings is FPF.) This implies that any product of self-basic right FPF rings is right FPF, in particular, any product of self-basic right PF rings is right FPF.

Another corollary to the product theorem states that if \{R_{k}\}_{i\in I} is any family of commutative rings each having the property P(n,g): there exist integers n\geq 0 and g>0 with the property that for all i\in I every finitely generated R_{i}-module of free rank \geq n+1 has genus \leq g, then their product R also has property P(n,g) (see Corollary 5.34). The FPF theorem is the case P(0,1).
That a commutative ring is generic with bound the identity is given by:

statement.label: 5.23A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative ring, then \gamma (M)\leq \nu (M) for any f\cdot g generator M.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p:
Let M^{n}	woheadrightarrow R. Then there exist elements x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}\in M,\, f_{n}\ldots , f_{n}\in M^{\star } such that \sum 
olimits _{i=1}f_{i}(x_{i})=1. If t=

olimits _{j=1}^{t}f_{j}^{\prime }(m_{j})=1, so that M^{t}	woheadrightarrow R holds, that is, \gamma (M)\leq t=
u (M).

statement.label: 5.23B. Corollary.
statement.p: If M is a f\cdot g faithful projective over a commutative ring R, then (M generates mod-R) and \gamma (M)=\gamma (M^{\star })\leq \nu (M).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: M generates mod-R by Azumaya’s Theorem 3.3D.

statement.label: 5.24. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative of dimension n, then G(R)\leq n+1, hence \gamma (M)\leq n+1 for any generator M.

statement.label: 5.25. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right Noetherian ring, then G(R)= g(R).

sec.p: For proofs, see the author’s paper [79c], pp. 621-622.

statement.label: 5.26. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) An unpublished result of D. Eisenbud states for R= k[x,y], the polynomial ring in 2 variables over a field k, that G(R)=1; (2) R. Wiegand has asked which commutative rings have the property that every generator has a faithful direct summand.

sec.title: The Product Theorem
sec.p: The proof of the product theorem requires:

statement.label: 5.27. Lemma.
statement.p: The only f\cdot g right ideal H of a product \Pi _{i\in I}R_{i} of rings which contains the direct sum \oplus _{i\in I}R_{i} is the unit ideal.

The Product Theorem (Faith [79c]). A family \{R_{i}\}_{i\in I} of rings is right B-generic iff the product R=\Pi _{i\in I}R_{i} is B-generic. Thus, for every generator of mod-R with \nu (M)=n<\infty we have:
where M_{i}=Me_{i}, and e_{i}\in R_{i} is the identity element, \forall i\in I.

statement.label: 5.29. Corollary.
statement.p: If M is an f\cdot g module over a product of rings R=\Pi _{i\in I}R_{i}, if M_{i}=Me_{i} generates mod-R_{i} where e_{i}:R\rightarrow R_{i} is the projection idempotent, and if sup\{\gamma (M)_{i})\}_{i\in I}=\gamma <\infty , then M generates mod-R and \gamma (M)=\gamma . Thus

statement.label: 5.30. Corollary.
statement.p: Let R=\Pi _{i\in I}R_{i}. Then
