sec.p: This follows from the corollary and the proof of the product theorem.

statement.label: 5.31. Corollary.
statement.p: Any product of commutative FPF rings is FPF. Similarly for products of right FPF self-basic rings.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Both are generic families.

statement.label: 5.32. Corollary.
statement.p: Any right generic product of right (F)PF rings is right FPF.

statement.label: 5.33. Examples.
statement.p: (1) If F_{n} is the n\times n matrix ring over a local ring F, then the product R=\prod \limits _{n\in Z^+}F_{n} is not generic, since \gamma (M)=\infty for the cyclic module M=eR, where e=e^{2} is the idempotent the j-th component of which is the e_{11}-matrix in F_{n}; (2) An infinite product of right PF rings is never right PF since a semiperfect ring contains no infinite sets of orthogonal idempotents. Furthermore, a product of PF rings is not necessarily FPF, e.g. R= \prod \limits _{n\in Z^+}F_{n} is not. Nevertheless, any product of right PF rings of right genus \leq g is right FPF of genus \leq g, according to Corollary 1.22E; (3) Let R= \prod \limits _{i\in I}M_{n}(F_{i}), where F_{i} is a self-basic right (F)PF ring. Then R is right FPF of genus n, according to Cor. 5.32 since G_{r}(M_{n}(F_{i}))=n,\, \forall i\in I, by Example (1) 5.33.

sec.title: Serre’s Condition

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: The free rank of a module M, denoted frk(M) is the smallest integer t so that for every maximal ideal P, the local module M_{P} has a free direct summand \approx R_{p}^{t}.

sec.p: Below frk= free rank.

statement.label: 5.34. Corollary.
statement.p: Let R=\prod \limits _{i\in I}R_{i} be a product of commutative rings such that there exists an integer n>0 such that each R_{i} satisfies Serre’s condition P(n,g): that is, any finitely generated R_{i}-module of frk>n+1 has an unimodular element. Then R satisfies P(n, g).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Let M be any finitely generated R-module of frk\geq n+1. If P_{i} is any maximal ideal of R_{i}, then P=P_{i}\oplus R_{i} where R_{i}= \prod \limits _{j\neq i}R_{j}, is maximal in R, and (M_{i})_{p}=M_{p} has rk\geq n+1, so M_{i} has unimodular element, that is, \gamma (M_{i})=1; hence \gamma (M)=1 by Corollary 5.29.

statement.label: 5.35. Theorem.
statement.p: Let \{R_{i}\}_{i\in I} be a family of rings such that R_{i} is a commutative ring of one of the following types:

def.p: a Bezout domain,
a local FPF ring (e.g. any AMVR, or any self-injective local ring),
an FPF ring of genus 1,
any product of rings \{R_{i}\} where R_{i} has type (i)–(iv).

statement.p: Then: R=\prod \limits _{i\in I}R_{i} is FPF of genus 1.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The rings (i)–(iii) are all FPF of genus 1; hence by Corollary 5.29 so are the rings in (iv); hence so is R=\prod \limits _{i\in I}R_{i}.

sec.p: A commutative local ring R is FPF iff every faithful module M with \nu (M)= 2 is a direct sum of cyclics [79a]. This is generalized to arbitrary products of commutative rings of genus 1 in Theorem 5.38 and Corollary 5.39. Any self-injective commutative ring is FPF [79a].

statement.label: 5.36. Proposition.
statement.p: If R is any ring and M is a generator such that \gamma (M)=1 and 2\leq \nu (M)=n<\infty , then
where B is an f\cdot g projective such that

sec.p: See the author’s paper [79c], Prop.13.

statement.label: 5.37. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is commutative, then in the proposition, B is a progenerator (=f\cdot g projective generator).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By Azumaya’s theorem, all that is required is that B be faithful. But R^{n}=R_{1}\oplus B\Rightarrow R^{n}a=(Ra)^{n}\approx R_{1}a for all a\in R which annihilates B, and this implies n=1 since R_{1}a is cyclic, contrary to the assumption.

statement.label: 5.38A.
statement.p: The 2\times 2 Theorem. If R is FPF and commutative of genus 1, then every faithful module M with \nu (M)= 2 is a direct sum of two cyclics: M\approx R\oplus R/K.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: \gamma (M)=1 so the corollary applies: M=R\oplus B/K, where R^{2}\approx R\oplus B, and B generates mod-R. Then B\approx R\oplus Y so R^{2}\approx R^{2}\oplus Y which means that Y_{m}=0,\,\forall maximal ideals m; hence Y=0, and B\approx R, so M=R\oplus R/K is a direct sum of cyclics.

sec.p: We shall abbreviate the conclusion of the 2\times 2 Theorem by the terminology: Every faithful 2-generated module is 2-cyclic. In this case, we say the 2\times 2 Theorem holds.

statement.label: 5.38B. Corollary.
statement.p: Any product of commutative FPF rings of genus 1 is FPF, and hence the 2\times 2 Theorem holds.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Apply 5.35(iii) to the 2\times 2 theorem 5.38A.

statement.label: 5.39. Remark.
statement.p: The FGC Theorem 5.11 shows that no infinite product of rings can be CFPF, that is, that product theorem for FPF rings fails for CFPF rings. (Finite products of CFPF rings are CFPF however.)

sec.p: In [67], Endo initiated the study of FPF rings.

statement.p: Endo’s Theorem [67]. A commutative Noetherian ring R is FPF iff R is a finite product of Dedekind domains and QF rings.

sec.title: FPF Split Null Extensions

statement.label: 5.41. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R=B\ltimes E be the split-null or trivial extension of a faithful module E over a commutative ring B. R is an FPF ring iff the partial quotient ring BS^{-1} with respect to the set S of elements of B with zero annihilator in E is canonically the endomorphism ring of E, that is BS^{-1}=End_{B}ES^{-1}. Every finitely generated ideal with zero annihilator in E is invertible in BS^{-1}, and E=ES^{-1} is an injective module over B.

sec.p: The proof uses the author’s following characterization of commutative FPF rings, (5.25), and also the characterization of self-injectivity of a split-null extension (4.25).

statement.p: FPF Ring Theorem (Faith [82a]). A commutative ring is FPF iff R has the following two properties:
(FPF 1) Every finitely generated faithful ideal is projective.
(FPF 2) R has injective quotient ring Q_{c}(R).

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) This theorem is illustrated by the result that a domain R is FPF iff R is Prüfer. (In view of the fact that by the theorem a commutative self-injective ring R is FPF, the theorem indicates that finitely generated faithful ideals of a self-injective ring R are projective, but the fact that f\cdot g ideals in a self-injective or f\cdot g-injective ring are annihilators implies that R is the only one!) Theorem 5.42 is contained in Faith-Pillay [90]. (2) For when Q_{c}(R) is semiperfect self-injective, see Mewborn and Winton [69].

sec.title: Semiperfect FPF Rings

statement.label: 5.43. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a semiperfect right FPF ring, then R is right self-injective iff the Jacobson radical J(R) is the right singular ideal

statement.label: 5.44A. Corollary
statement.p: (1) If R is a semiperfect right FPF ring with nil Jacobson radical, then R is right self-injective; (2) Moreover, a local right FPF ring R is self-injective iff rad R consists of zero divisors.

sec.p: As Yousif remarks: To deduce (1) of the Corollary from the theorem requires a result of Faticoni [87] stating that nil ideals are right singular in semiperfect right FPF rings.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: For the concepts weakly and strongly bounded used below, see the Definitions and Remarks preceding 5.3E.

statement.label: 5.44B. Theorem
statement.p: Any right FPF ring R is weakly right bounded.

statement.label: 5.45. Theorem
statement.p: (1) Any right self-injective semiperfect ring R with strongly right bounded basic ring R_{0} is necessarily right FPF; (2) Semiprime semiperfect right FPF rings are semihereditary and finite products of full matrix rings of finite rank over right bounded local Ore domains which are right and left valuation rings; (3) The basic ring of a semiperfect right CFPF ring is right duo (= right ideals are two-sided), right FGC, and are finite products of right valuation rings; (4) Conversely, any ring Morita equivalent to a finite product of rings that are right FGC, right VR and right duo is a semiperfect right CFPF ring.

statement.label: 5.46. Remarks.
statement.p: Faticoni [84,87] made significant additions to the theory. (Cf. 5.46A,5.4B and 5.48.) Endo [67] also studied the situation where every finitely generated projective faithful R-module generates mod-R.

sec.title: Faticoni’s Theorem
sec.p: We next cite two theorems of Faticoni. Also see Theorem 5.48.

statement.label: 5.46A. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a semiperfect ring in which (*) every right regular element is regular. Then: R is right FPF iff (i) the basic ring R_{0} is strongly right bounded; (ii) every f\cdot g faithful right ideal is a generator, and (iii) R has a semiperfect right self-injective classical right quotient ring Q=Q_{\mathrm{cl}}^{r}(R).

statement.label: 5.46B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right FPF, then Q_{\max }^{r}(R) is semiperfect right self-injective iff R has finite right Goldie dimension and (*) holds.

sec.title: Kaplansky’s and Levy’s Maximal Valuation Rings

statement.label: 5.47. Examples.
statement.p: (1) Kaplansky [42] constructed rings of formal power series \Sigma _{\gamma \in \Gamma }\alpha _{\gamma }x^{\gamma } in a variable x, with coefficients \alpha _{\gamma } in a field, and exponents \gamma coming from a totally ordered group \Gamma , and showed these rings are MVR’s i.e., there exist MVR’s with arbitrary value group \Gamma ;(2) By the FGC Classification Theorem 5.11, a ring R is CFPF iff FSI, and a local ring R is CFPF iff R is AMVR. Cf. Faith-Pillay [90], p.66, Theorem 3.17; (3) Levy [66] gave an example of a non-Noetherian commutative ring R of which all factor rings modulo nonzero ideals are self-injective rings, and some of the factor rings are PF. The ring exhibited is the ring R of all formal power series in a variable x indexed by the family W of all well-ordered sets of nonnegative real numbers. Thus, an element r of R has the form r=\Sigma _{i\in W}a_{i}x^{i}, with a_{i}\in R, and unique i\in W. The only nonzero ideals of R are: the principal ideals (x^{b}), and those ideals of the form
Thus, if I is any nonzero ideal, then \overline{R}=R/I is completely self-injective (and non-Noetherian). By 5.9, R is an AMVR, and FGC by 5.11.

sec.p: The next theorem generalizes Endo’s theorem 5.40.

statement.label: 5.48. Theorem
statement.p: A Noetherian ring R is FPF iff R is the finite product of bounded Dedekind Prime rings and a QF ring.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Faith-Page op.cit. further assumed that R is semiperfect.

sec.title: Page’s Theorems

statement.p: Page’s Theorem [78]. A VNR ring R is right FPF iff R is a right self-injective of bounded index. In this case R is left self-injective and left FPF.

statement.label: 5.50. Corollary
statement.p: A right self-injective VNR ring R is right FPF iff R is Morita equivalent to a strongly regular (= Abelian) right and left self-injective ring.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Any strongly regular right self-injective ring R is left self-injective by Utumi’s Theorem 4.3A.

sec.p: The next result belongs in §12 where the concepts maximal right (left) quotient rings are defined.

statement.label: 5.51. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right nonsingular right FPF ring R, then Q=Q_{\max }^{r}(R)=Q_{\max }^{\ell }(R), and is FPF.

sec.p: See our Lecture Notes Faith-Page [84], for additional results on nonsingular FPF rings.

sec.title: Further Examples of Valuation Rings and PF Rings
sec.p: A ring R is a right chain ring, or right valuation ring (= VR) provided the set of right ideals are linearly ordered. As before (see Remark 4.24), R=B\ltimes E denotes the split-null extension of a B-bimodule E. A module E_{B} is uniserial if its submodules are linearly ordered. We next cull some examples from the author’s paper [79b].

statement.label: 5.52. Proposition.
statement.p: A split-null extension R=B\ltimes e is a right VR iff B is a right VR,\ E is uniserial, and bE=E,\ \forall 0\neq b\in B.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: If R is a right VR, then B\approx R/(0,E) is right VR, and E\approx (0,E) is uniserial. If b\neq 0\in B, then (b,0)R\not \subset (0,E); hence
so bE=E. The converse follows by reading up.

sec.p: A VD is a domain which is a VR. For simplicity, from here on we shall assume that B whence R is commutative.

statement.label: 5.53. Corollary.
statement.p: Let E be a faithful B-module over a commutative ring B. Then R=B\ltimes E is a VR iff B is a VD and E is an uniserial divisible B-module.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Immediate.

statement.label: 5.54. Corollary.
statement.p: Let E be a torsion free module over a commutative domain B. Then R=B\ltimes E is a VR iff B is a VD and E is a uniserial injective B-module. In this case R is injective iff E is \mathbf{strongly balanced}, i.e., B=End_{B}E.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Any torsion free divisible module over a domain is injective, so apply the corollary. (Conversely, any injective module is divisible.) The last sentence follows from Theorem 4.25.

statement.label: 5.55. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R=B\ltimes E be a split-null extension where B is commutative. Then, the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is a PFVR (=a\ VR which is PF).
B is an almost maximal valuation domain (AMVD), E=E(B/rad\ B) is the injective hull of B/rad\ B, and B=End_{B}E.
B is a local domain such that E=E(B/rad\ B) is uniserial and strongly balanced.
B is an MVD and E=E(B/rad\ B) is strongly balanced.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By Gill’s theorem 5.4D, a local ring B is AMVR iff E(B/J) is uniserial, where J= rad B. Thus, using Theorems 4.25 and 5A, (3) \Leftrightarrow (3) follows. Moreover, (1) \Leftrightarrow (3) by 5.54 and Corollary 4A of the author [79b]; and (2) \Leftrightarrow (4) by a theorem of Vámos [75].

statement.label: 5.56. Corollary.
statement.p: If B is a Noetherian commutative local domain, and E= E(B/J), then the ring R=B\ltimes E is an injective VR iff B is a complete discrete valuation domain. In this case R is PF.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Follows from 5.55 and Matlis’ theorem 5.4B (since B is a Noetherian VD). Also see 4.24-5.

sec.title: Almost Finitely Generated Modules
sec.p: Following Weakley [83], a right R-module M is said to be almost finitely generated ( = a.f.g.) if M is not finitely generated but every proper submodule of M is finitely generated, equivalently, Noetherian. The quasi-cyclic group \mathbb{Z}_{p^{\infty }} is a.f.g.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Redei [57, 59] refers to the concept of one-step (Einstufig) objects, i.e. not having a property P but every subobject has property P. In Redei’s terminology, a module M is a.f.g. iff M is one-step Noetherian.

statement.label: 5.57. Results
statement.p:
⁠22
I am following the exposition of Weakley [83] and Heinzer-Lantz [85], pp.202–203. Let M be an a.f.g. module over a commutative ring R. Then:

def.p: Every nonzero endomorphism a of M is onto M. (Since ker a is not f\cdot g, then aM is not f\cdot g, hence aM=M.)
The annihilator ann_{R}M is a prime ideal. (Follows from 1.)

By 1 and 2, one may suppose that M is a divisible module over a domain R, and it follows from this that M is either torsion or torsion-free. (If M has nonzero torsion submodule t(M), then since t(M) is divisible, it is infinitely generated, hence t(M)=M.)
If M is torsion-free, then M\approx Q, where Q=Q(R) is the quotient field of R. (M, being torsion-free, is a vector space over Q, but clearly must have dimension 1 since M is a.f.g.)
M is the union of a chain of cyclic submodules. (This follows from divisibility of M and the fact that the union of any strictly ascending chain of submodules is equal to M.)
Any Artinian R-module which is not Noetherian has a.f.g. submodules namely, the minimal non-Noetherian submodules.

statement.label: 5.58. Theorem
statement.p: If a commutative integral domain R has a faithful a.f.g. module M, then there exists a ring S between R and its quotient field K=Q(R) and an ideal I of S such that M\approx K/I.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: The authors state that this theorem answers a question raised in Gilmer and Heinzer [83], and the proof requires Proposition 1.8 of Weakley [83]. Furthermore, Artinian a.f.g. modules over Prüfer domains are determined in the following Gilmer-Heinzer theorem:

statement.label: 5.59. Theorem
statement.p: If M is a faithful Artinian a.f.g. module over a Prüfer domain R, then M is isomorphic to R_{P_{0}}/R_{P} where P is any maximal ideal of R such that PR_{P} is principal and P_{0} is the intersection of the powers of P.

sec.title: Two Theorems of Vámos on Linearly Compact Quotient Fields

statement.p: Vámos’ First Theorem ([77, Proposition 2.11]). If R is a domain with linearly compact ( = l.c.) quotient field Q(R), then the integral closure S of R in Q(R) is a valuation ring.

statement.label: 5.61. Remark.
statement.p: (See Faith-Herbera [97], Theorem 3.5, for a generalization.)

sec.p: Vámos gave a characterization of Noetherian domains with l.c. quotient field:

statement.p: Vámos’ Second Theorem. ([77, Theorem 3.7]). If R is a Noetherian domain, then Q(R) is l.c. iff R is a field, or a complete local domain of dimension 1.

sec.title: Vámos-Weakley Theorems on Almost Finitely Generated Modules
sec.p: We combine some of Vámos’ and Weakley’s results in the following proposition:

statement.label: 5.64. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a domain that is not a field and denote by Q its field of quotients. Then the following statements are equivalent:

def.p: R is Noetherian and Q is linearly compact ( = l.c.) as an R-module.
Q/R is Artinian as an R-module and R is a complete Noetherian ring.
R is a complete Noetherian domain with Krull dimension 1.
R is a complete Noetherian domain with Krull dimension 1 and its integral closure is a discrete valuation ring that is finitely generated as an R-module.
Q(R)/R is an Artinian a.f.g. R-module and R is a l.c. ring.
Q(R) is an a.f.g. linearly compact R-module.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Statements 1, 2 and 3 are equivalent because of Vámos’ results above and proof [77, Theorem 3.7]. Statements 4, 5 and 6 are equivalent because of Weakley’s [83, Proposition 1.4] and Vámos’ results, 5.60 and 5.62.
The truth of the proposition follows from the fact that if R is a one-dimensional complete Noetherian domain, then Q(R)/R is an Artinian a.f.g. module (cf. Maths’ [73, Theorem 7.1]).

statement.label: 5.64. Example.
statement.p: Let K be any field and for i=1,\ldots ,n, let \alpha _{i}\in \mathbb{N}. The power series ring K[[x^{\alpha _{1}},\ldots ,x^{\alpha _{n}}]] is a complete Noetherian domain with Krull dimension 1 whose integral closure is finitely generated as an R-module.

sec.title: Historical Note
sec.p: The proof of the characterization of commutative FPF rings (see Theorem 5.42) is nontrivial and requires the concept of a maximal quotient ring Q_{\max }(R) (see 9.27s and §12).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Yoshimura [98] characterizes an FPF ring R by a 1-1 correspondence between invertible ideals and f\cdot g overmodules (in which case they are projective by Theorem 5.42), where “invertibility” and “overmodule” are defined with respect to the injective hull E(R) of R. Cf. Faith-Pillay [90], p.45, Theorem 2.21 which implies that E(R)=Q_{\max }(R) in this case. Also see 12.14.

sec.label: Chapter 6
sec.title: When Injectives Are Flat: Coherent FP-Injective Rings
sec.p: A right R-module M is finitely presented (=f\cdot p) provided that there is an exact sequence
where m and n are integers \geq 1. Any f\cdot p R-module is f\cdot g, and any f\cdot g right R-module over a right Noetherian ring is f\cdot p. Moreover, any f\cdot g projective R-module is f\cdot p.

A right R-module M is FP-injective provided that \mathrm{Ext}_{R}^{1}(F,M)=0 for every finitely presented R-module F, equivalently, every homomorphism S\rightarrow M of a f\cdot g submodule S of a free module F extends to a homomorphism F\rightarrow M.

A submodule A of a right R-module B is (Cohn) pure in B provided that the induced homomorphism \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(M,B)\rightarrow \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(M,B/A) is an epimorphism for all f\cdot p R-modules M, or equivalently, for any f\cdot p left R-module F, the canonical homomorphism A\otimes _{R}F\rightarrow B\otimes _{R}F is an embedding. (See Cohn [59], or Warfield [69].)

statement.label: 6.A. Theorem.
statement.p: A right R module M is FP-injective iff M is a pure submodule of an injective module.

sec.p: 6.A was cited in Menal-Vámos [84] as “probably folklore, and the proof is left to the reader.”

sec.title: Pure Injective Modules
sec.p: As defined informally, sup. 1.26, a right R-module M is algebraically compact, or pure-injective provided that every system of linear equations for arbitrary index sets I and J of the form
in the unknowns (x_{j})_{j\in J}, and r_{ij}\in R are almost all =0 for each i\in I, can be solved provided that L(I^{\prime }) can be solved for each finite subset I^{\prime } of I.

Thus: linear equations are simultaneously solvable iff finitely solvable (Mycielski [64]), cited by Warfield [69a], p.707, who establishes that pure-injective envelopes exist (see 6.46 below), and determines the algebraically compact modules over Prüfer rings, extending Kaplansky’s classification over PID’s. Also see Facchini [85a].

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p:
The terminology for pure-injective derives from the property that a right R-module M is pure-injective iff M is a direct summand of any module containing M as a pure submodule (See, e.g. Fuchs [69], Warfield [69a], or Kaplansky [69], Proposition, p.84.)⁠11
In fact, pure-injectivity can be viewed as injectivity in an appropriate category; see Gruson-Jensen [73]. The next result is a consequence of this and 6.A.

statement.label: 6.B. Theorem.
statement.p: A right R-module M is injective iff M is FP-injective and pure-injective.

statement.label: 6.C. Theorem.
statement.p: (See Theorem 6.52) If R is commutative and M a pure-injective R-module, then End M_{R} is an “F-semiperfect” ring.

sec.p: Cf. Jensen-Lenzing [89], p. 180, Corollary 8.27. Also see 6.52s.

statement.label: 6.D. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative, then any linearly compact R-module is pure-injective.

statement.label: 6.D^{\prime }. Theorem
statement.p: If _RM_{S} is a bimodule, and if _{R}M is linearly compact, then M_{S} is pure-injective.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Zimmermann [82] gives an example of a right Artinian, hence linearly compact, ring not right pure-injective; (2) Also see Onodera [81] for a simple proof of 6.D^{\prime }; (3) A left linearly compact bimodule _{A}M_{B} is right pure-injective by Zimmermann’s Theorem [72,77]. See Jensen-Lenzing [89], p.289, Theorem 11.18. (The converse does not hold (loc.cit.) p.303.); (4) For pure-injective group rings, see 11.8.

sec.p: A ring R is right (self) FP-injective if R_{R} is an FP-injective R-module. A ring R is right \aleph _{0}-injective if \mathrm{Ext}_{R}^{1}(R/I,R)=0 for all countably generated right ideals I, equivalently for every mapping f:I\rightarrow R there exists a\in R so that f(x)=ax\quad \forall x\in I. R is right (self) p-injective (weak-\aleph _{0} or f\cdot g-injective) if this holds true for all principal (resp. f\cdot g) right ideals I. A right self-FP-injective ring R is weak \aleph _{0}-injective. A VNR ring is right and left FP-injective (cf. 6.2).

statement.label: 6.E. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right FP-injective iff R_{n} is right p-injective for all n\geq 1.
Theorem of Menal-Vámos [89] Every ring A is embedded in a ring R that is right and left (self) FP-injective. (Cf. 6.21.)

statement.label: 6.2A. Remark.
statement.p: In certain cases, e.g. when R contains a field, or has torsionfree additive group, or is commutative and coherent, then R is FP-injective iff R is pure in all its ring extensions (Menal-Vámos [89]). It is known that not every ring A embeds in a self-inject ring (loc.cit.), and Mal’cev [37] showed that not every integral domain embeds in a sfield. Cf. 6.26ff.

statement.label: 6.2B. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is left FP-injective iff every finitely presented right R-module is torsionless.

sec.p: From 6.2B one can show that R is left FP-injective iff every n\times n matrix ring R_{n} is left f\cdot g-injective and iff every f\cdot g right ideal of R_{n} is a right annihilator \forall n. Theorem 6.E is a stronger result.

statement.label: 6.2C. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a Prüfer domain, then an R-module M is FP-injective iff M is divisible: Mr=M\ \, \forall 0\neq r\in R.

statement.label: 6.2D. Corollary.
statement.p: Every factor module of an injective module over a Prüfer domain is FP-injective (cf. 4.2B).

sec.title: Elementary Divisor Rings
sec.p: A ring R is an elementary divisor ring (=EDR) if every n\times n matrix A over R is equivalent (or associate) to a diagonal matrix D, that is PAQ=D for P and Q non-singular. Examples are VR’s, VNR rings, and PID’s. That \mathbb{Z} is an EDR is due to Smith in 1870, and some 40 years later Steinitz [11,12] studied matrices and modules over the ring of algebraic integers. See O’Neill [96b] for this reference.

statement.label: 6.3A. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is an elementary divisor ring iff every finitely presented module is a direct sum of cyclic R-modules.

sec.p: In [69], Kaplansky states (p.80) that Theorem 6.3A for a domain R “ought to have been the main theorem of [49]” but it was never clearly stated! He also asks whether every Bezout domain is an EDR.
If an ideal I has the property that for every 0\neq a\in I there exists b\in I such that I=aR+bR, then I is said to be generated by 1\frac{1}{2} elements.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) Any EDR is Arithmetic (see 6.4 and 6.5A below), in fact, Bezout (loc.cit.). A semilocal Arithmetic ring is Bezout by the theorem of Hinohara [62], sup 5.4B; (2) Heitman and Levy [H-L] discovered interesting examples of Prüfer domains in which every f\cdot g ideal is generated by 1-1/2 elements, e.g. every Prüfer domain R of dimension 1 has this property, and if R has Jacobson radical not=0, then R is Bezout (=f\cdot g ideals are principal). (3) For more on Prüfer rings, see 9.29ff. Also see Fontana et al [97].

sec.p: A ring R is right(left) Hermite if every 1\times 2 (resp. 2\times 1) matrix is equivalent to a diagonal matrix. Any right Hermite ring is left Hermite (Menal-Moncasi [82]). A ring R is unit-regular if for every a\in R there exists a unit u\in R so that aua=a. A VNR ring R is unit-regular iff R cancels from direct sums, i.e., R\oplus A\approx R\oplus B\Rightarrow A\approx B. More generally, one has the following:

statement.label: 6.3B. Theorem
statement.p: Let M be a right R-module such that A= EndM_{R} is VNR. The following conditions are equivalent:

def.p: A is unit-regular.
If M=M_{1}\oplus M_{2}=N_{1}\oplus N_{2} and if M_{1}\approx N_{1}, then M_{2}\approx N_{2}.
If e and f are idempotents of A such that eA\approx fA, then (1-e)A\approx (1-f)A.

statement.label: 6.3C. Corollary.
statement.p: Any Abelian VNR is unit-regular.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Goodearl [79], p.38.

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: An R-module M has the cancellation property if (2) of 6.3B holds.

statement.label: 6.3D. Theorem
statement.p: Every unit-regular ring R is an elementary divisor ring; indeed, any rectangular matrix is equivalent to a diagonal matrix, and the n\times n matrix ring R_{n} is unit regular.

sec.p: This answered a question of Handelman and Vasershtein, and the proof required a theorem of Vasershtein [71].

statement.label: 6.3E. Theorem
statement.p: Over a VNR ring R every rectangular matrix is equivalent to a diagonal matrix iff R^{2}\oplus A\approx R\oplus B implies R\oplus A\approx B for all right R-modules A and B.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: It is known that over any ring R, that any Artinian module cancels from direct sums (Camps-Dicks [93]; see 8.D). Also see 6.3G below.

sec.title: Stable Range and the Cancellation Property
sec.p: We say that 1 is in the stable range for a ring E if whenever xa+b=1 in E, there is an element y\in E such that a+yb is a unit. Bass proved (see Swan [68], 11.8), that a semisimple artinian ring has 1 in the stable range. Since E clearly has 1 in the stable range if E/J(E) does, it follows in particular that any semilocal ring has 1 in the stable range.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Any ring R with stable range 1 is Dedekind finite; for if xa=1, then (taking b=0 in the definition), a is a unit. (2) The above is the definition for “left” stable range 1, and this implies “right” stable range 1. (See Lam [95b], Exercises in Classical Ring Theory, pp. 15-16, Ex. 1.25 and comment.)

statement.label: 6.3F. Theorem
statement.p: If M is a right R-module over any ring R, and if 1 is in the stable range for End M_{R}, then M has the cancellation property.

statement.label: 6.3G. Corollary.
statement.p: Any R-module with semilocal endomorphism ring has the cancellation property.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Apply 6.3F to Bass’ theorem stated sup. 6.3F.

statement.label: 6.3H. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a locally module-finite algebra over a commutative ring S such that S/J(S) is von Neumann regular. Then:

def.p: Finitely generated R-modules have the cancellation property

Let A,B be finitely generated R-modules. Then:(a)
If A^{n} is isomorphic to a direct summand of B^{n}, then A is isomorphic to a direct summand of B.(b)
If A^{n}\approx B^{n}, then A\approx B. (Cancellation of powers.)

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The proof uses Evans’ Theorem 6.3F.

statement.label: 6.3I. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a VNR ring which is left \aleph _{0}-injective (or right or left \aleph _{0}-continuous, Cf.12.4Cs), then the following are equivalent:

def.p: R has bounded index (of nilpotence)
All primitive factor rings are Artinian
All f\cdot g R-modules have 1 in the stable range of End M_{R}.
All f\cdot g R-modules have the cancellation property.

statement.label: 6.3J. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a VNR ring with Artinian primitive factor rings, then every f\cdot g R-module M has 1 in the stable range of End M_{R}.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This is not true for an arbitrary VNR ring, as Menal [88] pointed out. Cf. Goodearl-Moncasi [89].

sec.title: Fractionally Self FP-Injective Rings
sec.p: If P is a property of rings, then a ring R is fractionally P if Q(R/I) has property P for all ideals I, where Q(A) denotes the classical quotient ring of a ring A (cf. FSI rings in 5.9). A ring R is (right) Kasch if every maximal (right) ideal m is an annihilator right ideal, equivalently, ^\perp m\neq 0, equivalently, every simple (right) module embeds in R. Any right PF ring is right Kasch by 4.20, and any \mathrm{acc}{\perp } commutative ring R has Kasch quotient ring (Faith [91b]. Cf. Theorem 16.31.)

statement.label: 6.4. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is fractionally (self) FP-injective (=FSFPI) iff R is fractionally (self) p-injective. These rings are Arithmetic ( =R_{M} is a valuation ring for every maximal ideal M). Conversely, an Arithmetic ring R is FSFPI under any of the following conditions:

def.p: semilocal;
fractionally semilocal;
a 1-dimensional domain; or
fractionally Kasch.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Any Prüfer domain, in fact any semihereditary ring, is locally a chain domain, hence Arithmetic.

sec.p: Cf. the remark following 6.3A.
The proofs rely on Warfield’s characterization of arithmetical rings:

statement.label: 6.5A.
statement.p:
Warfield’s Theorem⁠22
As I reported in my Algebra II ([76],p. 129_{n}) in a letter of June 1974, Kaplansky attributed this theorem in the case R is a valuation ring to W. Krull. In this case M is a direct sum of CP modules. ([70]). A commutative ring R is Arithmetical iff every finitely presented R-module M is a direct summand of a direct sum of cyclicly presented (=CP) modules.

sec.p: The key ingredient in the proof is the following

statement.label: 6.5B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a local ring, and if there is a bound on the minimal number g(M) of generators of indecomposable finitely presented modules M, then R is a valuation ring.

sec.title: Coherent Rings: Theorems of Chase, Matlis and Couchot

statement.p: Chase’s Theorem [60]. A ring R is said to be \mathbf{left\ coherent} provided R satisfies the equivalent conditions:

def.p: any product of copies of R_{R} is a flat right R-module,
any product of flat right R-modules is a flat right R-module,
any f\cdot g left ideal of R is finitely presented (=f\cdot p),
any f\cdot g submodule of a free left R-module is f\cdot p.

sec.p: A ring R is coherent provided R is both left and right coherent. A left Noetherian ring is left coherent, and a VNR ring is coherent. Cf. 6.60ff.

statement.label: 6.7A. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is coherent iff Hom_{R} (A,B) is a flat R-module for all injective R-modules A and B, equivalently the endomorphism ring of any injective R-module is flat.

statement.label: 6.7B. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is coherent iff for every FP-injective R-module M and every maximal ideal P,M_{P} is an FP-injective R_{P}-module and R_{P} is coherent.

statement.label: 6.7C. Theorem
statement.p: (1) If every finitely embedded injective right R-module is flat, then R is left FP-injective; (2) The converse holds if R is a right linearly compact ring, or if the ideals of R are linearly ordered.

sec.p: Cf. 6.10A and B and 6.11.

statement.label: 6.7D. Theorem
statement.p: A valuation ring (=VR)R is an AMVR if there exists a non-maximal prime ideal P such that R/P is an AMVD.

statement.label: 6.7E. Corollary
statement.p: A VR is an AMVR if either (1) R is a \mathbb{Q}-algebra of Krull dimension \leq 1, or (2) the maximal ideal of R is not the union of proper prime ideals.

sec.title: When Injective Modules Are Flat: IF Rings
sec.p: While earlier we considered when all injective right R-modules are projective (see 3.5B), we now consider when they are all flat. A ring R is (right) IF provided that all injective (right) R-modules are flat. By Bass’ theorem 3.31, over a right perfect ring, any flat right R-module is projective, hence right perfect right IF rings are QF by 3.5B.

statement.label: 6.8. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right IF if and only if all finitely presented right R-modules embed in a free right R-module.

statement.label: 6.9. Theorem

title.sc: Colby [75], Gomez-Pardo and Gonzalez [83], Jain [73], Matlis [85] And Würfel [73]

statement.p: The following conditions on a ring R are equivalent:

def.p: R is IF.
R is coherent and every finitely generated ideal (either side) is an annihilator ideal.
R is coherent and flat modules (either side) are FP-injective
The classes of weak \aleph _{0}-injective modules and FP-injective modules are equal.
Annihilation induces a duality on the finitely generated one-sided ideals.
R is coherent and self FP-injective (both sides).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Matlis’ theorems are for commutative R, and his term for “IF” is “semiregular”.

statement.label: 6.10A. Theorem
statement.p: (1) A commutative ring R is IF if and only if R is coherent and locally IF; (2) A domain R is Prüfer (i.e., arithmetical) if and only if R/I is IF for all finitely generated ideals I\neq 0.

statement.label: 6.10B. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring is IF iff R is coherent and every f\cdot p module is R-reflexive.

sec.p: The next Corollary follows from Theorems 6.9 and 6.10 (Cf. 6.7B):

statement.label: 6.11. Corollary.
statement.p: A commutative coherent ring is self FP-injective if and only if it is locally self FP-injective.

sec.title: Power Series over VNR and Linear Compact Rings
sec.p: R[[x]] denotes the ring of formal power series over R.

statement.label: 6.12. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a VNR commutative ring. Then the power series ring R[[x]] is Bezout iff R is \aleph _{0}-injective.

sec.p: Note: By Theorem 6.9 (IF2) any VNR ring R is then FP-injective.
This is Theorem 42, p. 54 and the following is Theorem 43, p. 61, of Brewer [81].

statement.label: 6.13. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a VNR commutative ring. Then the following are equivalent conditions:

def.p: R[[x]] is semihereditary.
R[[x]] is a coherent ring.
R is \aleph _{0}-injective, and I^{\perp } is countably generated for every countably generated ideal I.
R is an \aleph _{0}-injective pp (= principal ideals are projective) ring.
R[[x]] is a Bezout pp ring.

sec.p: Herbera [91], Lemma 5.16 and Proposition 5.17, generalized these theorems to non-commutative rings.

statement.label: 6.14. Theorem
statement.p: If R[[x]] is right semihereditary, then R is a left \aleph _{0}-complete VNR. Moreover, if R is a left \aleph _{0}-complete and left \aleph _{0}-injective VNR, then R[[x]] is right semihereditary and right Bezout.

sec.p: See Lemma 5.16 and Proposition 5.17 (also see Lemma 5.18 and Theorem 5.19) of Herbera [91]. (Note right semihereditary and right Bezout = right Bezout and right pp.)

statement.label: 6.14A. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be strongly regular.

def.p: (Hirano, Hung and Kim [95]) If R is \aleph _{0}-injective, then R[[x]] is a duo ring and Bezout.
(Karamzadeh and Koochakapoor [99]) The converse of (1) holds.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Ribenboim [97] considers a generalized power series ring A=[[R^{S,\leq }]], where (S,+,\leq ) is a strictly ordered monoid, and characterizes when A is VNR (resp. skew field). Cf. Elliott-Ribenboim [90].

sec.p: For a good background on linearly compact rings, consult Ánh [90] and Xue [92].

statement.label: 6.15. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a linearly compact commutative ring, then R[[x]] is linearly compact iff R is Noetherian (and iff R is locally Noetherian).

sec.p: For proof, see Xue [96b]. By Brewer-Heinzer [80], R[[x]] is necessarily Hilbert for R[[x]] to be linearly compact.

sec.title: Historical Note
sec.p: Herbera proved 6.15 while a Fulbright Postdoctoral Fellow at Rutgers in Fall ’92. She later told me that 6.15 was a “bit folkloric,” e.g. “known to Menini and Ánh.” So perhaps more names ought to be attached to 6.15. I am very happy that Xue solved this problem, which I asked him (in a letter), and that he published his results.

sec.title: Locally Split Submodules
sec.p: A submodule A of an R-module B is said to be locally split if for every f\cdot g submodule A^{\prime } of A there exist a map f:B\rightarrow A such that f restricted to A^{\prime } is the identity. (This is equivalent to the same requirement for any cyclic submodule A^{\prime }=aR.)

statement.label: 6.16. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a right R-module M:

def.p: is onto.
M is locally split in each overmodule.
For every finite subset X of M there is an injective module E such that X\subseteq E\subseteq M.

sec.p: See Ramamurthi-Rangaswamy [73], where M with the above properties is said to be finitely injective, or strongly absolutely pure. Also see Facchini [95], who discusses aspects of strongly absolute pure modules relative to the question of whether R is necessarily Noetherian under the condition: (P) every f\cdot p injective (or absolutely pure) module is strongly absolutely pure (see 6.17–6.18).
Below, see §14 for the concept of projective dimension.

statement.label: 6.17. Theorem
statement.p: An almost maximal valuation domain R\neq Q satisfies (P) iff Q has projective dimension =1.

sec.p: A module M over a commutative domain R is h-divisible (after Matlis [72]) if M is a factor module of an injective module, equivalently, is an epimorphic image of a vector space over Q=Q(R).

statement.label: 6.18. Theorem
statement.p: Any absolutely strongly pure R-module over a domain is h-divisible, and conversely if R is an almost maximal valuation domain.

sec.p: The proof uses the theorem:

statement.label: 6.19. Theorem
statement.p: A valuation domain R with quotient field Q is almost maximal iff every epimorphic image of Q^{n} is injective over R,n\geq 1. (Cf. 5.4C.)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See Facchini [94], §4. for a generalization.

statement.label: 6.19A. Theorem
statement.p: Every homomorphic image of the quotient field Q of a domain R is injective iff R is an almost maximal Prüfer domain.

statement.label: 6.19B. Remark.
statement.p: See loc.cit. for other results and see the Math. Rev. (2000f:13041) of Olberding’s paper by M. Fontana for historical background.

sec.title: Existentially Closed Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right weakly linearly existentially closed (= WELEX) if every system of linear equations (LI) and a single linear inequation (LIE)
A ring R is right linearly existentially closed (= LEX) if R is WELEX with finitely many additional linear inequalities (FLIE) replacing the single (LIE).

A subring R of a ring A is existentially closed in A if every LE with FLIE with coefficients in R which has a solution in A already has a solution in R. Then R is existentially closed (EC) if R is EC in every ring extension A.

statement.label: 6.20. Theorem
statement.p: Any ring R can be embedded in an EC ring A.

sec.p: This is Theorem 7.2 of loc.cit.

statement.label: 6.21. Corollary.
statement.p: Any ring R can be embedded in a right and left FP-injective ring S.

sec.p: This is a corollary of the following:

statement.label: 6.22. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right and left FP-injective iff R is right and left WELEX.

statement.label: 6.23. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right and left LEX iff R is right and left FP-injective and 0 is the only finite one-sided ideal.

sec.title: Existentially Closed Fields
sec.p: Existentially closed skew fields are defined similarly, (see, e.g. Cohn [95], §6.5). According to Cohn, p.329, Notes and Comments, the concept EC was developed by “A. Robinson [63]; [and] the applications to sfields in §6.5 are taken from Cohn [75].”

statement.label: 6.24. Theorem
statement.p: If D is a sfield, then there exists an EC sfield L containing D, in which every finite consistent set of equations over D has a solution. When D is infinite, then L can be chosen to have the same cardinal as D, while if D is finite, then L can be chosen to be countable.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: A commutative field k is EC over k precisely when k is algebraically closed. Moreover, the center of any EC sfield D is algebraically closed.

statement.label: 6.25. Theorem
statement.p: Two EC sfields K and L that are countably generated over a field k are isomorphic iff they have the same families of subfields that are f\cdot g over k.

sec.title: Other Embeddings in Skew Fields

statement.p:
Ore’s Theorem [31]. An integral domain R has a right quotient field Q of the form \{ab^{-1} for all a,0
eq b\in R\} iff aR\cap bR
eq 0 for a
eq 0,b
eq 0,

sec.p: In this case R is a right Ore domain. It follows that a domain R is right Ore iff R is a uniform right R-module. (See 6.29 following.)
As mentioned sup. 6.2B:

statement.label: 6.27. Theorem
statement.p: Not every domain R can be embedded as a subring in a sfield.

sec.p: A similar theorem holds for semigroups with cancellation (cf. Lambek [51]). Cf. R.E. Johnson [69] for other examples of Mal’cev domains.

Note that the theorem of Menal and Vámos (Corollary 6.21) implies that a Mal’cev (or Malcev) domain R\, (= one not embeddable in a sfield) embeds in an FP-injective ring. However, anticipating a concept introduced in §12, sup. 12A, a better result holds:

statement.label: 6.28. Theorem.
statement.p: The maximal right quotient ring Q=Q_{\max }^{r}(R) of an integral domain R is a right self-injective VNR. Moreover, Q is a simple ring, and is a sfield iff R is a right Ore domain.

sec.p: Cf. the lectures of the author [67], or Goodearl [79]. The point here is that Q being VNR is right and left FP-injective, and right self-injective as a bonus. (Simplicity of Q follows from the fact that if I is a nonzero ideal of Q, then \exists 0\neq x\in I\cap R, and since x^{\perp }=0, there exists y\in Q so that yx=1\in I. Thus, I=Q.)

statement.p: Goldie’s Theorem [58]. A domain R is right Ore iff R has acc\oplus . In particular, any right Noetherian domain R is right Ore.

sec.p: Cf. 3.13. Also see 15.7B: PI-domains are Ore.

sec.title: Galois Subrings of Ore Domains Are Ore

statement.label: 6.30. Theorem
statement.p: If G is a finite group of automorphisms of a right Ore domain R, then the Galois subring R^{G} is a right Ore domain.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This answered a question of Bergman. Also see Bergman and Isaacs [73], Cohn [75], Harčenko [74,75], Kitamura [76,77], and Tominaga [73]. See 12.A and B.

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: A ring R is a right (semi) fir if every (f.g.) right ideal is free of unique rank.
Cohn’s Theorem [71] Any fir can be embedded in a universal sfield of fractions.

sec.p: This is done by inverting all full matrices (see Cohn [95], p.95) a method that extends to semifirs, in fact, to Sylvester domains presently defined (Cohn [95], Theorem 4.58 and Corollary 4.59, pp.181–182.)

Sylvester domains were introduced by Dicks and Sontag [78] as domains over which any two matrices A and B with the number n of columns of A equal to the number of rows of B satisfy the nullity condition:
on their “inner ranks” r(A) and r(B). Then Sylvester’s law of nullity (dating to 1884) holds:
(see loc.cit.).

sec.title: Rings with Zero Intersection Property on Annihilators: Zip Rings
sec.p: Zelmanowitz [76b] introduced the ring concept, which we call right zip rings, with the defining properties below, which are equivalent:
(ZIP 1) If the right annihilator X^{\perp } of a subset X of R is zero, then X_{1}^{\perp }=0 for a finite subset X_{1}\subseteq X.
(ZIP 2) If L is a left ideal and if L^{\perp }=0, then L_{1}^{\perp }=0 for a finitely generated left ideal L_{1}\subseteq L.

statement.label: 6.32. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Trivially, any left Kasch ring is right zip. In [76b] Zelmanowitz noted that any ring R satisfying the d.c.c. on annihilator right ideals ({=}\mathrm{dcc}\,\perp ) is a right zip ring, and hence, so is any subring of R. He also showed by example that there exist zip rings which do not have dcc \perp .

(2) In [91b] the author characterized a right zip ring by the property that every injective right module E is divisible by every left ideal L such that L^{\perp }=0. Thus, E=EL. (It suffices for this to hold for the injective hull of R.)
(3) We also showed that a left and right self-injective ring R is zip iff R is pseudo-Frobenius (= PF), and that a semiprime commutative ring R is zip iff R is Goldie.

Beachy and Blair [75] studied rings that satisfy the condition that every faithful right ideal I is co-faithful in the sense that I_{1}^{\perp }=0 for a finite subset I_{1}\subseteq I, equivalently, R\hookrightarrow I^{n} for n<\infty . Right zip rings have this property, and conversely for commutative R.

statement.label: 6.32A. Theorem
statement.p: If faithful ideals of R are co faithful then the same is true of R[X], for any commutative ring R, and any set X of variables.

statement.label: 6.32B. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is a commutative zip ring, then any polynomial ring R[X] over R is a zip ring, for any set X of variables.

sec.p: In [91b] the author raised the questions that resulted in the next theorem.

statement.label: 6.33. Theorem
statement.p: There exist right zip rings R such that (1) the polynomial ring R[x] is not right zip, (2) the n\times n matrix ring R_{n} is not right zip and (3) the group ring RG of a finite group G is not right zip.

sec.p: In fact, the example for (2) is an integral domain, hence a Mal’cev domain. The proof relied on coproduct constructions due to G. Bergman [74b]: Let k be a field, and A an algebra over k. Then the free product
where S is an (n-1)-fir.

statement.label: 6.34. Corollary.
statement.p: There exist integral domains not embeddable in left Noetherian nor right Artinian (nor right dcc{\perp }) rings.

sec.p: This follows from Corollary 3 of Cedó [91], stating that a free product A\star _{k}B of algebras over k can be right zip only if both A and B are, that S is a domain hence zip while M_{n}(S) is not zip. Thus, S is a Mal’cev domain with the property stated in the Corollary. Since k can be any field, it follows that the situation corresponding to the Camillo-Guralnick-Roitman Theorem 9.3 cannot transpire.

sec.title: On a Question of Mal’cev: Klein’s Theorem
sec.p: Can the multiplicative semigroup D^{\star } of a Mal’cev domain D be embedded in a group?

statement.label: 6.35. Theorem
statement.p: If an integral domain D has the property that any nilpotent n\times n matrix over D has index of nilpotency \leq n, then the multiplicative semigroup D^{\star } of D can be embedded in a group.

statement.label: 6.36. Remark.
statement.p: The examples of Mal’cev domains of Bokut’ [67], Bowtell [67], Johnson [69] and Klein [69] are such that D^{\star } can be embedded in a group. This gave an affirmative answer to Mal’cev’s question. (A typo nullified this statement in my Algebra II [76], p.140ff. Related questions are treated in papers of Klein (1967 and 1972 (cited loc.cit.), and papers of Bokut’ listed in Small [80] (Reviews in Ring Theory (1940–1979).)

sec.title: Weakly Injective Modules
sec.p: M is weakly R_{n}-injective provided every n-generated submodule S of E(M) is contained in a submodule X of E(M) with X\approx M.M is weakly-injective (= WI) if this holds for every n, that is, for every f\cdot g submodule S.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) Tuganbaev [77,82] uses the term (also poorly injective) quite differently: every endomorphism of any submodule S is induced by one of M. If R is semi-Artinian, these modules are all quasi-injective [77]; (2) A module M is called pseudo-injective if every monomorphism of a submodule S is induced by an endomorphism of M. These are not necessarily quasi-injective (Teply [75], JainSingh [75]) but they are when R is a serial ring (ibid.). Also, Kawada [57] showed that a right self-pseudo-injective algebra of finite dimension over an algebraically closed field is QF.

statement.label: 6.36A. Remark.
statement.p: At the Special Session in Ring Theory at Ohio State University in August 1990 organized by S. K. Jain and the Ohio group (López-Permouth, T. Rizvi, M. Yousif), Sergio López-Permouth pointed out that the ring R=T(k_{n}) of n\times n upper triangular matrices over a field k is left weakly self-injective, and that Gauss’ elimination method of reducing an n\times n matrix q\in Q=k_{n} to upper triangular form by row operations yields a nonsingular matrix x\in Q so that xq=r\in R. Since Q=E(_{R}R), then R is weakly R_{1}-injective as asserted. (I am indebted to S. López-Permouth [98] for refreshing my memory).

statement.label: 6.36B. Examples
statement.title: (Jain, López-Permouth, Saleh [72]).
statement.p: (1) R is QF iff R is right Artinian and right WI; (2) A domain R is a right Ore domain iff R is right weakly R_{1}-injective; (3) A domain R is left and right Ore iff R is right WI; (4) A right WI semiprime right Goldie ring is left Goldie; (5) A right WI right continuous ring is right self-injective.

statement.label: 6.37. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right quotient finite dimensional iff every direct sum of (weakly) injective right R-modules is weakly injective.

sec.title: Zip McCoy Rings
sec.p: The topics that follow in 6.38 are taken up in more detail in §16, 16.27ff.

statement.label: 6.38. Remarks.

def.p: If R\subseteq S are rings such that S_{R} is an essential extension of R, and if S is right zip, then so is R (Faith [76b]);
On the other hand, if S_{R} is a free left R-module, and if S is right zip, then so is R (Cedó [91], Lemma 2]);
Any left Kasch ring S trivially is right zip, hence any ring R satisfying conditions of Remark 1 or 2 is right zip;

If R is right zip, then every annihilator right ideal 
eq contains a minimal right annihilator 
eq 0 (Faith [91b], Theorem 3.1), hence every left annihilator ideal L
eq R is contained in a maximal left annihilator 
eq R (=R has left \mathcal{E}_{\max });

A commutative ring R is McCoy in case every f\cdot g faithful ideal I contains a regular element. Furthermore, R is McCoy iff Q(R) is McCoy. Huckaba-Keller [79]: Any polynomial ring R[X] over any ring R is McCoy (= property A in Huckaba [88]); See Huckaba [88], p.9, Theorem 2.7;

A commutative ring R has Kasch quotient ring Q=Q(R) iff R is zip McCoy by a result of the author [91b]. It follows from the above Remark and 6.32B that if R is zip then Q(R[X]) is Kasch. Also, Q(R) is semilocal Kasch iff Q(R[X]) is semilocal Kasch. Any commutative \mathrm{acc}{\perp } ring R has semilocal Kasch Q(R), hence is zip McCoy (ibid). By Theorem 2.1 (ibid), there exist zip rings which are not McCoy.

If a ring R has the finite left intersection property (= flip) for any family of left ideals \{I_{\alpha }\}_{\alpha \in A} the intersection is zero iff a finite subfamily has zero intersection. Then _{R}R is finitely embedded (f.e. = has f\cdot g essential socle. Cf. 3.58-61 and sup. 7.8). This is “the dual of f\cdot g according to Vámos [68]. (Cf. Faith [76], pp.67–70, esp. 19.13A–19.16B), which equates flip with the property that every faithful left ideal is cofaithful. Moreover, R is left Artinian iff every cyclic left module is f.e. The same result holds for modules, i.e., M is Artinian iff every factor module of M is f.e. (Vide Vámos, loc.cit. and Onodera [73]);
In [91b] the author showed that any group ring RG of a finite Abelian group G over a commutative zip ring R is zip;

Cedó [91] inter alia showed the n\times n matrix ring over a commutative zip ring is zip, and extended the above theorem on Abelian group rings to a non-commutative algebra R over an algebraically closed field k of characteristic not dividing |G|;
Regarding (4), any ring R with the acc on left point annihilators has left \mathcal{E}_{\max }.

statement.p: \mathcal{E}_{\max } is an acronym for enough maximal annihilators. See 6.38 (4).

sec.title: Associated Primes of Polynomial Rings
sec.p: For a commutative ring R, an associated prime ideal is a prime ideal P that is the annihilator of some element of R, and Ass R denotes the set of all such P. (See 3.16C, 16.11). By theorem 2.37E, any maximal annihilator ideal T is an associated prime ideal (also see 16.12), and \mathrm{Ass}^{\star }R denotes the set of all such T.

statement.label: 6.39. Theorem
statement.p: For any commutative ring R, the extension mapping of Ass\; R to Ass\;R[X] sending P to P[X] is a bijection. Thus: card\; Ass\;R=card\; Ass\;R[X] and card\; Ass^{\star }R=card\; Ass^{\star }R[X].

def.p: The proof employs the concepts of Lazard [69], and localization theory. The author [00b] has given a direct proof using results of Shock [72b], and Annin [01] has generalized this to non-commutative rings.

In my paper [91b], I erroneously denoted \mathrm{Ass}^{\star }R by Ass R, as Lam [98] pointed out to me. (\mathrm{Ass}^{\star }R= \mathrm{Ass}\;R if R is reduced by Prop. 16.11A). With this understanding, all the results in my cited paper are correct to my knowledge.

sec.p: In his “Mathematical Notes” paper, McCoy [57b] discussed annihilator ideals in polynomial rings: “if f is a zero divisor in the polynomial ring R[X], where R is a commutative ring, there exists a nonzero element c in R such that cf= 0\ldots it is clear that the theorem as stated does not generalize to more than one indeterminate. Moreover, it has been pointed out in Problem 4419 of this Monthly (1950, p.692 and 1952, p.336) that the theorem is not necessarily true for noncommutative rings\ldots ”
McCoy went on to consider annihilator ideals of the polynomial ring R[X] in a finite set X of variables. If S is any subset \neq \emptyset of a ring A, let

be the right ideal of A annihilated by S. After R. Baer, we will call this a right annulet. If S is a right ideal, then S^{\perp } is an ideal of A, called an annulet. In this terminology, McCoy proved:

statement.label: 6.40. Theorem
statement.p: Any nonzero annulet ideal I of a polynomial ring A=R[X] in any set of variables has nonzero intersection with R.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: In a seminar talk that I gave in March 1989, my colleague, Professor W. Vasconcelos, pointed out that McCoy’s proof and theorem for finite X could be extended to arbitrary X.

def.p: See Remarks 6.38, (5) and (6) for the definition, and examples of McCoy rings, e.g. any commutative ring R with Kasch Q(R) is McCoy;
Any commutative ring R such that f\cdot g ideals of Q(R) are annihilators, e.g. when Q(R) is VNR, or FP-injective, is a McCoy ring. See. 6.42 below.

Any valuation ring R is McCoy, hence so any ring R with Q(R) a VR. However, Huckaba [88], p.191, Example 17, constructs a ring R such that R_{m} is a VD for all maximal ideals m, and R is not McCoy, hence Q(R) is not McCoy. This example defeated the “FP^{2}F conjecture” of the author [92b]. (Cf. Prüfer rings 9.24(3).)

statement.p: Huckaba-Keller Theorem [79] A reduced coherent commutative ring R is McCoy iff Q(R) is VNR.

sec.p: Cf. Huckaba’s book [88], p.20, Theorem 4.7.

sec.title: Elementary Equivalence

statement.label: 6.43. Definition.
statement.p: Two rings (resp. fields, modules, \cdots ) R and S are called elementarily equivalent (notation: R\equiv S) if R and S satisfy the same first order sentences in the corresponding language.

sec.p: By the upper Löwenheim-Skolem theorem one gets an explicit criterion for elementary equivalence of algebraically closed fields:

statement.label: 6.44. Theorem.
statement.p: Two algebraically closed fields K and L are elementarily equivalent if and only if char(K) =char(L).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See, e.g. Jensen-Lenzing [89], Theorem 1.13, p. 5.

sec.p: A field K is real closed if K is formally real and K[\sqrt {-1}] is algebraically closed. See 1.29Bf.

statement.label: 6.45A. Theorem
statement.p: Any two real closed fields are elementarily equivalent.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Jensen-Lenzing ibid. p.9.

statement.label: 6.45B. Theorem
statement.p: The theory of algebraically closed fields is not finitely axiomatizable.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Bell and Slomson [71], p.101 (and p.106) for proofs of more general statements (and remarks).

sec.title: Pure-Injective Envelopes
sec.p: For the definition of a pure-injective (= algebraically compact) module, see 1.25As or 6.Af.

statement.label: 6.46. Theorem
statement.p: Each R-module M has a pure-injective envelope

i.e., M embeds as a pure suhmodule into a pure-injective module R-module A(M) such that—for each R-module X—an R-linear map f:A(M)\rightarrow X is a pure monomorphism if and only if its restriction f|_{M}:M\rightarrow X to M is a pure monomorphism. A(M) is the smallest pure suhmodule of E(M) which is pure-injective and contains M.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Jensen-Lenzing [89], p. 128.

def.p: Fuchs, Salce and Zanardo [98/99] point out that pure-essential extensions over a Prüfer domain R are transitive iff R is a discrete valuation domain (= DVD). This is a corollary to ibid. Theorem 6 that states that “RD-essential” is transitive over a domain R iff R is a DVD. Cf. 1.17 and 6.46A. See Warfield [69a] who proved that RD-purity and Cohn purity coincide for a domain R iff R is Prüfer.

Gómez Pardo and Guil Asensio [97c] point out that Stenström’s proof of Theorem 6.46 cannot work for the reason given in (1), and that the cardinality argument by transfinite induction given in Kiełpiński [67] suffices, as in the case of injective hulls.

Gómez Pardo and Guil Asensio also point out in [97c] that a finitely presented pure-injective module M has an indecomposable decomposition iff it is quotient pure-injective (= all its pure factor modules are pure-injective). Furthermore, then \mathrm{End}M_{R} is semiperfect. Cf. 6.49–59 below.

statement.label: 6.47. Example
statement.title: (Jensen-Lenzing, Ibid.).
statement.p: (1) If R is a von Neumann regular ring, the pure-injective envelope A(M) of an R-module M coincides with its injective envelope E(M). More generally, if R denotes an arbitrary ring, we have A(M)=E(M) exactly for the FP-injective R-modules (Cf. 6.B.);

(2) If R is a commutative local Noetherian ring with maximal ideal m then the m-adic completion \widetilde{R}_{m} of R, viewed as an R-module, serves as the pure-injective envelope of R with respect to the natural embedding R\rightarrow \widetilde{R}_{m};
(3) The pure-injective envelope A(\mathbb{Z}) of the \mathbb{Z}-module \mathbb{Z} can be obtained as the direct product

(with respect to the diagonal embedding of \mathbb{Z} into \prod _{p\in P}J_{p},x\mapsto (x/1)). Here P is the set of prime numbers and, for each prime number p,J_{p}=\mathbb{Z}_{(p)} is the ring of p-adic integers viewed as a \mathbb{Z}-module.

statement.label: 6.48. Theorem
statement.p: Every R-module M is elementarily equivalent to a pure-injective R-module, actually to its pure-injective envelope A(M).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Ibid. Theorem 7.51, p. 158.

sec.title: Ziegler’s Theorem

statement.label: 6.49. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be any ring. Each left R-module M is elementarily equivalent to a direct sum of indecomposable pure-injective modules.

statement.label: 6.50. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be an Abelian VNR. The following conditions on an R-module M are equivalent:

def.p: M is simple.
M is indecomposable \Sigma -injective.
M is indecomposable pure-injective.
M is indecomposable.

statement.label: 6.51. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is an Abelian VNR, then each R-module M is elementarily equivalent to a semisimple R-module.

sec.p: For proofs, see op. cit., p.181. Regarding 6.50, Cf. also the author’s paper [72b]. Also see Trlifaj [96] where a problem of Ziegler is reduced to this question: Does there exist a simple non-Artinian VNR ring R having a unique indecomposable injective R-module?
A ring R is F-semiperfect if \overline{R}=R/\mathrm{rad}R is VNR and idempotents lift.

statement.label: 6.52. Theorem.
statement.p: For each pure-injective R-module M the factor ring
is von Neumann regular and right self-injective. Moreover, idempotents can be lifted modulo rad End_{R}(M). In particular End_{R}(M) is F-semiperfect.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Jensen-Lenzing [89], p.180.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This theorem generalizes Utumi’s Theorem 4.2, and the Faith-Utumi Theorem 4.2A.

statement.label: 6.53. Theorem.
statement.p: Each pure-injective R-module M admits a decomposition

where each M_{\alpha } is an indecomposable direct factor of M and M_{c} does not have any indecomposable direct factor. Moreover, M_{d} is uniquely determined by M, while M_{c} and the M_{\alpha } are uniquely determined up to isomorphism (and ordering).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Jensen-Lenzing [89], p.180 for proof.

sec.title: Noetherian Pure-injective Rings
sec.p: By Warfield’s Theorem 6.D, every linearly compact commutative ring is pure injective. The next theorem establishes the converse for Noetherian rings. (Cf. Maths’ theorem 5.4B.)

statement.label: 6.54. Theorem.
statement.p: A commutative Noetherian ring R is pure-injective (\mathbf{qua} R-module) iff R is a finite product of complete local rings.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See op.cit. 11.3, p.283.

sec.title: \Sigma -Pure-Injective Modules
sec.p: A pure-injective module M is \Sigma -pure-injective if every direct sum of copies of M is pure-injective. By Zimmermannn’s theorem 1.25, M is \Sigma -pure-injective iff every direct sum of copies of M splits off in the direct product.

statement.label: 6.55. Theorem
statement.p: If R is left perfect and right coherent, or pure-injective of cardinality <2^{\aleph _{0}}, then R is \Sigma -pure-injective. Any \Sigma -pure-injective ring is semiprimary.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Jensen-Lenzing, 11.1, p.281, for proof and attributions.

sec.p: Cf. Zimmermann’s Theorem 1.25, Lenzing’s Theorem 1.24A and Corollary 1.24B Cf. also Azumaya [96] who points out that if every projective left module is pure-injective, then R must be left perfect.

sec.title: Pure-Semisimple Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right pure-semisimple provided that every right R-module is pure-injective.

statement.label: 6.56. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right pure-semisimple iff every right R-module is a direct sum of f\cdot g modules.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: By Chase’s Theorem 3.4E, then R is right Artinian.
Fuller’s Theorem [76] can thus be expressed:

statement.label: 6.57. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right pure-semisimple iff every right R-module has a decomposition that complements direct summands. Cf.8.6s

statement.label: 6.58. Theorem
statement.p: Every f\cdot p left module over a right pure-semisimple ring has finite length over its endomorphism ring.

statement.label: 6.59. Remark.
statement.p: See Rings of Finite and Bounded Module Type, end of §8, for some connections with pure semisimple rings.

sec.title: \Pi -Coherent Rings
sec.p: R is right \Pi -coherent if an arbitrary product R^{\alpha } of copies of R is coherent, i.e., every f\cdot g submodule of R^{\alpha } is f\cdot p. A ring R is a left \star -ring if the R-dual functor \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(\, ,R) takes f\cdot g left modules M into f\cdot g right modules M^{\star }.

statement.p: Camillo’S Theorem [90]. For a ring R, the following are equivalent: (1) R is right \Pi -coherent; (2) R is left \star -ring; (3) For each matrix ring R_{n}, all right annihilators are f\cdot g.

statement.label: 6.61. Theorem
statement.title: (ibid.).
statement.p: If R is a two-sided Noetherian ring, and if R is either semiprime, or is an algebra over a non-denumerable field, then R[X] is right \Pi -coherent for any set X of variables.

sec.p: Cf. Finkel Jones [82] and the author’s papers [90a] and [02a].

sec.label: Chapter 7
sec.title: Direct Decompositions and Dual Generalizations of Noetherian Rings
sec.p: If every factor M/S of a module M modulo an essential submodule S has property P, then M is said to satisfy “restricted P.”

statement.label: 7.1. Theorem
statement.title: (Webber [70], Chatters [71]).
statement.p: Over a hereditary Noetherian ring, every f\cdot g module is restricted Artinian. (Cf. 5.3A.)

sec.p: Cf. Ornstein [68] for related results for restricted Artinian. Cf. 2.19B.

statement.label: 7.2. Theorem
statement.title: (Chatters ([72]).
statement.p: A Noetherian hereditary ring is a finite product of rings that are either Artinian or prime rings.

sec.title: PP Rings and Finitely Generated Flat Ideals
sec.p: A ring R is right PP (or pp) if every principal right ideal pR is projective, equivalently, the canonical map R\rightarrow pR splits, equivalently p^{\perp }=eR for an idempotent e. Integral domains and right semihereditary rings are trivially right PP.

def.p: If R is commutative, then R is pp iff the polynomial ring R[x] is pp. Moreover, all ideals are flat iff the 2-generated ideals are,
“n-generated left ideals are flat” is a right left symmetric property.

statement.label: 7.3B. Theorem
statement.p: A right Goldie right PP ring is a finite product of prime right Goldie PP rings. Moreover, the prime direct factors are the minimal annihilator ideals of R.

sec.p: Cf. Koifman [71a].

statement.label: 7.4. Theorem
statement.title: (Robson ([74]).
statement.p: A Noetherian ring R with prime radical N (=the maximal nilpotent ideal) is a product of an Artinian ring and a semiprime ring iff
for every c\in R such that \overline{c} is a regular element of \overline{R}=R/N.

sec.p: This can be used to give another proof of Chatters’ theorem. Cf. Asano’s theorem 3.12A.

statement.label: 7.5A. Theorem
statement.title: (Krull [24], Asano [38, 49], Goldie [62]).
statement.p: A left Noetherian principal right ideal ring R is a finite product of prime rings and primary Artinian rings.

sec.title: Right Bezout Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right Bezout if all f\cdot g right ideals are principal, e.g. any VNR is right and left Bezout. Any semilocal Arithmetic ring is Bezout (Cf. sup. 5.4B).

statement.label: 7.5B. Theorem
statement.p: A semiprime right Bezout ring R is right semi-hereditary and a finite product of prime right Bezout rings each isomorphic to a full n\times n matrix ring F_{n} over a right Ore domain F, for various integers n\geq 1.

sec.p: Goldie’s Theorem [62] is for R a principal right ideal ring (PRIR). Swan [62] showed that F need not be right Bezout in 7.5B. For the next theorem, cf. Ore domains 6.26f.

statement.label: 7.5C. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right Bezout (=f\cdot g right ideals are principal) and R/N is right Goldie, where N=N(R) is the prime radical (= the intersection of all prime ideals), then R=R_{1}\times R_{2}\times \cdots \times R_{t}, where R_{i}/N(R_{i}) is prime, and R_{i} is a full matrix ring over a ring D_{i} such that D_{i}/N(D_{i}) is an Ore domain \forall i.

statement.label: 7.5D. Corollary
statement.title: (op.cit.).
statement.p: If R is semilocal and R/N(R) is right Goldie, then R is right Bezout iff R=R_{1}\times R_{2}\times \ldots \times R_{t} is a finite product of full matrix rings over semilocal right Bezout rings D_{i} such that D_{i}/N(D_{i}) is an Ore domain, i=1,\ldots ,t.

sec.title: Faith-Utumi Theorem

statement.label: 7.6A. Theorem
statement.title: (Faith-Utumi Structure Th. [65]).
statement.p: A semiprime ring R is right Goldie iff R contains a finite product P of full n_{i}\times n_{i} matrix rings (F_{i})_{n_{i}} over right Ore domains F_{i} (not necessarily having unit element but) having right quotient sfields D_{i},i=1,\ldots ,n such that Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R)= \prod _{i=1}^{n}(D_{i})_{n_{i}}.

sec.p: Expressed otherwise, R is an essential extension of P as a right P-module.

statement.label: 7.6B.
statement.p: Faith-Utumi Theorem For Semilocal Rings. If Q=Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R) exists and Q=D_{n} is a full n\times n matrix semilocal ring over a ring D, then (after a possible change of matrix units) R contains the ring F_{n} of n\times n matrixes over a subring F of D (which may not have a unit element) such that Q_{c\ell }^{r}(F)=D, hence Q_{cl}^{r}(F_{n})=D_{n}.

sec.p: The caveat about the change of matrices does not apply if Q is also the left quotient ring of R. The bit about not having a unit may be illustrated: let R be the ring of all 2\times 2 integer-valued matrices whose diagonal entries are divisible by 2. Thus, R\supseteq (2\mathbb{Z})_{2} and Q_{c\ell }(R)=\mathbb{Q}_{2}.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: As remarked in [72a] (p.411,Prop. 10.19) the original proof of 7.6A suffices for 7.6B and obviated the case of Artinian Q of Robson [67] (p.607,3.3).

statement.label: 7.7. Theorem
statement.p: A right hereditary ring R of finite right Goldie dimension is Noetherian. A right semihereditary ring of finite Goldie dimension is left semihereditary. Cf.13.45(3).

statement.label: 7.7A. Theorem
statement.title: (Cozzens and Faith [75], p.138).
statement.p: Any right ideal of a right Noetherian simple right hereditary ring can be generated by 2 elements.

statement.label: 7.7B. Remark.
statement.p: See ibid., p. 33, Lemma 2.24 for a short proof of the first statement of Theorem 7.7. Also see theorem 7.12 below.

sec.title: Finitely Embedded Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right finitely embedded (= f.e.) if R has finite essential right socle (= an essential f\cdot g semisimple right ideal).

statement.label: 7.8. Theorem
statement.p: A two-sided Noetherian ring is two-sided Artinian iff R is right f.e.

statement.label: 7.8A. Theorem
statement.p: Over a (two-sided) fully bounded Noetherian ring R any f.e. module M is Artinian, and if M is also f.g., then M has finite length.

statement.label: 7.8B. Remark.
statement.p: For a commutative Noetherian ring this is a theorem of Matlis [58].

statement.label: 7.9. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right Artinian iff every cyclic right module is f.e.

statement.label: 7.9A. Theorem
statement.p: If _{R}M_{S} is a bimodule such that _{R}M has finite length, and M_{S} is Noetherian, then M_{S} has finite length.

sec.p: The next theorem was inspired by Shizhong’s theorem which follows.

statement.label: 7.10. Theorem
statement.p: Any f.e. commutative acc\!\perp ring is Artinian.

statement.label: 7.11. Corollary
statement.p: Any commutative subdirectly irreducible acc\!\perp ring is QF.

def.p: Regarding 7.10, see Nicholson and Yousif [00], and Mezzetti [02] for two different generalizations to noncommutative rings.
Regarding 7.11, see 13.26 for a generalization to uniform acc\perp rings.

sec.title: Simple Noetherian Rings
sec.p: A problem raised by the author in [64], [71b], and by Cozzens-Faith [75] is: 1) is every simple Noetherian ring R Morita equivalent to a domain; and a related problem: 2) is R a domain or does it have nontrivial idempotents; indeed 3) is it a full matrix ring over a domain? 4) if R has finite global dimension, does 1) hold? (Global dimension is taken up in Chapter 14.)

Zalesski and Neroslavski [77] gave negative answers to 2) and 3). Both Goodearl [78] and Stafford [78] showed that the same example also gave a negative answer to 1). However, this left 4) still open.
Cozzens and the author proved

statement.label: 7.12. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a simple right Noetherian ring of global dimension \leq 2, then R is Morita equivalent to a domain A. Any right Goldie simple ring R of gl. dim not exceeding 2 is right Noetherian (Ibid., Theorem 2.25, Proposition 2.38 and Theorem 2.40.)

sec.p: Thus, the domain A is also simple, and gl.dimA\leq 2.

statement.label: 7.13. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a simple Noetherian ring of finite left global dimension, and if R has left Krull dimension n<\infty , then R has Goldie dimension \leq n. Furthermore if n=1, then R is Morita equivalent to a domain, and has an idempotent e\neq 0,1 if R is not a domain.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) For the concept of left Krull dimension, see 14.26ff; (2) Question of Camillo-Krause: If R is a simple ring of left Krull dimension 1, is R left Noetherian? Cf. Shamsuddin [98]; (3) In [71b], the author characterized the situation that a simple Noetherian ring R is isomorphic to the endomorphism ring of a f\cdot g projective module over a simple domain A. See also Cozzens and Faith [75], p.2.29ff., Theorem 2.20.

sec.title: Simple Differential Polynomial Rings
sec.p: Let A be a ring, and let \varphi :A\rightarrow A be a ring monomorphism. Then a \varphi -derivation of A is a mapping D:A\rightarrow A such that
\forall a, b\in A. If \varphi =\mathrm{identity}, then D is called an (ordinary) derivation. For each element x\in A, there is a derivation
\forall a\in A, called the inner derivation defined by x. A derivation is outer if it is not inner.

statement.label: 7.14. Examples.
statement.p: 1) If R is a ring, and if A=R[x] is the polynomial ring, then the usual derivation D, defined by
where a_{i}\in R, i=1, \ldots , n, is a derivation of A.

2) Let A\supseteq k be sfields such that \dim _{k}A=2. (We do not require that \dim A_{k}=2.) Then A=k+kx for any x\in A, x\not \in k. If a\in k, then there exist unique elements \varphi (a) and D(a)\in k such that
This defines a ring monic \varphi of A and a \varphi -derivation D.
Let D be a \varphi -derivation of a ring A, and let A[y] be the polynomial ring. Then A[y] is a ring under addition of polynomials and multiplication defined by the rule
and its consequences; this ring is called the ring of \varphi -differential polynomials in D and is denoted A[y,D,\varphi ].

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: In his pioneering papers Ore [31,33a,b] studied R=A[y,D,\varphi ] for a sfield A. Then R is a left Ore domain, which is a right Ore domain iff \varphi is an automorphism. Furthermore, given polynomials f, g\in R there exist q, r\in R with \deg r<\deg g and such that f=qg+r (= division algorithm). Thus, R is a left Euclidean domain, hence a left principal ideal domain. See Ore [33a], p.483ff., esp. 487 where the left quotient field Q of R is constructed. Cf. also 7.20.1 below.

sec.p: Let D be any ordinary derivation of A. Thus, \varphi =1 and A is said to be an ordinary differential ring. Then (1) implies
and

statement.p: Hilbert Basis Theorem for Differential Polynomials. If A is a left Noetherian ring with an ordinary derivation D, then the differential polynomial ring A[y,D] is left Noetherian.

sec.p: The proof of the Hilbert Basis Theorem applies here mutatis mutandi.
An ordinary differential ring A is a Ritt Algebra if A is an algebra over \mathbb{Q}. Thus, any simple ordinary differential ring of characteristic 0 is a Ritt Algebra.

statement.label: 7.16. Theorem.
statement.p: If A is a Ritt algebra with derivation D, then the differential polynomial ring R=A[y,d] is simple iff D is outer and A has no non-trivial D-invariant ideals.

sec.p: See Cozzens-Faith [75], p.43ff.
The next theorem is a corollary of 7.16.

statement.label: 7.17. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a simple ring with characteristic 0 and an outer derivation D, then the differential polynomial ring R=A[y,D] is simple.

sec.p: Cf. Hauger [77] for a generalization to n commuting derivations.
The ring of D-constants of a differential ring A is the set \{a\in A\,|\,D(a)=0\}.

statement.label: 7.18. Theorem.
statement.p: If A is a commutative ordinary differential domain of characteristic p\neq 0, then A[y,D] is simple iff A is a field of infinite dimension over the subfield k of D-constants.

sec.title: The Weyl Algebra
sec.p: The case where A is a field, and D(y)=1 is called the Weyl Algebra A_{1}. See Rinehart [62] and Webber [60] for some important examples and counterexamples. Also, see Björk [72], Roos [72] and Goodearl [74]. (Cf. 14.15, esp. (8)–(10).)

statement.label: 7.19. Proposition.
statement.p: Let S be a simple ring of characteristic 0, and let A=S[x] be the ordinary polynomial ring. Let R=A[y,^{\prime }] be the ring of differential polynomials such that \phi =1. Then R is a simple ring.

sec.p: See the author’s Algebra I for a proof, Proposition 7.30, p.354.

statement.label: 7.20. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) If A is a field, and if D is a derivation, then R=A[y,D] has a left and right division algorithm; for example, if f and g are elements of R, then there exist elements q and r in A such that
\deg r<\deg g. This implies that R is a principal left and right ideal domain;
2. If A is not a field, then A[y,D] is not necessarily a principal ideal ring (for example, if A=k[x] is the polynomial ring over a field k, and if Dx=1. Cf. 7.19);

3. Every right and left ideal of R=k[x][y,D], where Dx=1, is projective if the field k has characteristic 0. In this case, every maximal right (left) ideal is principal and R is hereditary. (If k has characteristic \neq 0, then R has gl. dim=2. Cf. §14);
4. (a) If D is a derivation of A, then the inner derivation D_{y} of A[y,D] induces D.
(b) The center of A[y,D] is isomorphic to the polynomial ring T[y], where T is the subring of center A consisting of all a such that D(a)=ay-ya=0.
(c) Amitsur [56] shows that the units of A[y,D]\subseteq A. Conclude that x^{-1}Ax\subseteq A for all units x of A[y,D], but that A is not contained in the center of A[y,D] when D\neq 0. Cf. 2.16A.

sec.title: When Modules Are Direct Sums of a Projective and a Noetherian Module
sec.p: A right R-module M is a Chatters module if M is a direct sum of a projective module P and a Noetherian module N, with P or N possibly zero.

statement.label: 7.21. Theorem
