statement.p: A ring R is right Noetherian iff each cyclic right R-module is a Chatters module.

sec.p: The necessity is of course trivial.

sec.title: When Modules Are Direct Sums of an Injective and a Noetherian Module

statement.label: 7.22. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right Noetherian iff every right R-module is a direct sum of an injective module and a (locally) Noetherian module.

statement.label: 7.23. Remarks.

def.p: Locally Noetherian means every f\cdot g submodule is Noetherian;

statement.p: A right R-module M is said to be a special if M is an injective but not Noetherian uniserial module such that any nonmaximal proper submodule S is Noetherian and M/S is injective.

statement.label: 7.24. Lemma
statement.p: If R is a ring, then R is never a special right (or left) R-module.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: For suppose R is right special, and let J be the unique maximal right ideal. Then J is not f\cdot g. If J were, then J\supset J^{2} by Nakayama’s Lemma, and |J/J^{2}|<\infty by the fact that J is f\cdot g, so J whence R would be Noetherian since J^{2} is.

So J is not f\cdot g, hence if 0\neq r\in J, then J\supset rR, so rR\approx R/r^{\perp } is Noetherian. Furthermore, since R is not Noetherian, then r^{\perp } is not Noetherian so r^{\perp }=J. Then rR is simple \forall r\in R, hence R is semisimple. But then R has Jordan-Hölder length 2, a contradiction.

statement.label: 7.25. Lemma
statement.p: If R is a ring, and every cyclic right R-module is the direct sum of an injective module and a Noetherian module, then every cyclic indecomposable injective right R-module is either Noetherian or special.

statement.label: 7.26. Theorem
statement.p: The following statements are equivalent for a ring R.

def.p: Every cyclic right R-module is the direct sum of an injective module and a Noetherian module.
Every finitely generated right R-module is the direct sum of an injective module and a Noetherian module.
R is a finite direct sum of special (injective) right ideals and Noetherian right ideals.
There exist a positive integer n and right ideals A_{i}(1\leq i\leq n) such that R=A_{1}+\cdots +A_{n} and every homomorphic image of A_{i} is injective or Noetherian for each 1\leq i\leq n.

sec.title: Dual Generalizations of Artinian and Noetherian Modules
sec.p: Following Shock [74], an R-module M is a max module if every nonzero submodule has a maximal submodule. We say that M is a Shock module if every factor module M/K\neq 0 is a \max module. Thus, a module M is a Shock module if for every submodule K, every submodule S\supset K has a maximal submodule containing K.

statement.label: 7.27. Theorem
statement.p: For a right R-module M the following are equivalent:

def.p: M is Noetherian
M is a q.f.d. (quotient finite dimensional) Shock module
M is a Shock module and all factor modules have f\cdot g socles (possible =0).
Every factor module of M has f\cdot g radical and f\cdot g socle.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Shock [74], Theorem 3.7 and 3.8.

sec.p: Dual to \max module is the concept of a min module, i.e., every nonzero factor module contains a minimal submodule. By Theorem 3.33A, M is a \min module iff M is semi-Artinian, equivalently, a Loewy module.

statement.label: 7.28. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a right R-module

def.p: M is artinian
M is a q.f.d. min module
M is a min module and every factor module \neq 0 has f\cdot g socle

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Theorem 3.1 ibid.

statement.label: 7.29. Theorem
statement.p: (1) An Artinian module M is Noetherian iff M is a \max module; (2) Every Artinian submodule of a \max module is Noetherian.

def.p: Camillo’s Theorem 5.20B implies Shock’s theorem 7.28. See Camillo’s letters, end of chapter 16. The proof of the next theorem requires both;
3 of Theorem 7.28 is equivalent to the condition of the Beachy-Vámos theorem 3.61, that is, every factor module is finitely embedded.

statement.label: 7.31. Theorem
statement.p: A right R-module M is Noetherian iff M is q.f.d. and satisfies the acc on subdirectly irreducible submodules.

sec.title: Completely \Sigma -Injective Modules
sec.p:
A right R-module is said to be completely injective provided that every factor module is injective.⁠11
The results in this and the next two sections (specifically 7.32 to 7.44) first appeared in the author’s paper [76a]. The theorem of Cartan-Eilenberg 3.22A states that a ring R is right hereditary iff every injective right R-module is completely injective. For a right Noetherian ring R, we show that this criterion for a right hereditary ring can be reduced to the requirement of completely injective of a single module, namely injective hull \hat{R}=E(R) of R_{R}.

statement.label: 7.32. Proposition.
statement.p: In any ring R, any direct sum of injective right R-modules is an epic image of a direct sum of copies of the injective hull \hat{R} of R_{R}.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Since a direct sum of a direct sum is a direct sum, and any direct sum of epics is an epic, it suffices to show this for a single injective module M\neq 0. Then, M\approx \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(R,M)\neq 0, and any morphism f:R\rightarrow M extends by injectivity of M to a morphism \hat{R}\rightarrow M. Therefore, the so-called trace T of \hat{R} in M

statement.label: 7.33. Corollary.
statement.p: Assume R is a ring such that \hat{R} is \Sigma -completely injective. Then so is any injective R-module M, and R is then right Noetherian and right hereditary.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By 7.32, every direct sum of copies of M is an epic image of copies of \hat{R}. The rest follows from 3.4B and 3.22A.

statement.label: 7.34A. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be a right Noetherian ring R. If \{E_{i}\}_{i\in I} is a family of completely injective right R-modules then the direct sum of the family is completely injective.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Let E=\Sigma _{i\in I}\oplus E_{i} be the direct sum, and K a submodule \neq E, and for each submodule S of E, let \overline{S}=(S+K)/K. Choose a family \{F_{i}\}_{i\in J} of submodules of E such that \{\overline{F}_{i}\}_{i\in J} is a maximally independent family of submodules of \overline{E}= E/K, and let E^{\prime } be the sum \Sigma _{i\in J}\oplus \overline{F}_{i}. The F_{i} are completely injective so \overline{F}_{i} is injective for all i\in J. Since R is right Noetherian, then E^{\prime } is injective by 3.4B, hence

Furthermore: if E^{\prime }\neq E, then there is some i\in I such that \overline{E}_{i} is not contained in E^{\prime }. But, E^{\prime }, being injective, is a direct summand of the submodule H of \overline{E} generated by E^{\prime } and \overline{E}_{i}, say H=E^{\prime }\oplus F. But, then
is an epic image of \overline{E}_{i}, hence is injective, violating the maximality of \{\overline{F}_{i}\}_{i\in J}. Thus, \overline{E}=E^{\prime } is injective as required.

sec.p: Remark The same proof suffices to prove the following:

statement.label: 7.34B. Theorem.
statement.p: Any direct sum of completely \Sigma -injective modules is completely \Sigma -injective.

statement.label: 7.34C. Corollary.
statement.p: A right Noetherian ring R is right hereditary iff \hat{R} is completely injective, and also iff every indecomposable injective right module is completely injective.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By 7.34A, \hat{R} completely injective implies that \hat{R} is \Sigma -completely injective, so R is right hereditary by 7.33. Also, if every indecomposable injective is completely injective, then every injective module is by 3.4B and 7.34 so 3.22 applies.

sec.title: Ore Rings Revisited
sec.p: A ring R is right Ore if R has a classical right quotient ring Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R), denoted Q(R) for short.

statement.label: 7.35. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be any ring with right quotient ring Q=Q(R).

def.p: Then Q is a flat left R-module.
Every injective right Q-module is an injective right R-module.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: (1) In effect, if I is a right ideal, and if y=\Sigma _{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\otimes q_{i} lies in the kemel of the canonical map I\otimes _{R}Q\rightarrow IQ (sending y\mapsto \Sigma _{k=1}^{n}x_{i}q_{i}), there exists a regular element t\in R with q_{i}t\in R, i=1, \ldots , n. Thus,

and so y=0. This proves (1) since this implies that I\otimes _{R}Q\approx IQ canonically; (2) follows from the fact that the hypothesis implies that the inclusion functor mod- Q\hookrightarrow \mathrm{mod}{-}R has exact left adjoint \otimes _{R}Q. See Proposition 4.C.

statement.label: 7.36. Theorem.
statement.p: If R is right Goldie semiprime, then Q(R) coincides with \hat{R}.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Since Q=Q(R) is semisimple by 3.13, hence right self-injective, then Q is an injective R-module by 7.35(2) hence Q=\hat{R} as asserted.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: If R is right nonsingular, then \hat{R} is a right self-injective VNR ring. (See §12.) In this case, if R is right Goldie, then Q(R)=\hat{R} is semisimple Artinian.

statement.label: 7.37. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be a prime right Goldie ring with simple Artinian right quotient ring Q=D_{n}, and let F be a minimal right ideal of Q. Then every injective right R-module is an epic image of a direct sum of copies of F.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Apply 7.32, 7.36, and the fact Q\approx F^{n}.

sec.title: On Hereditary Rings and Boyle’s Conjecture
sec.p: A right R-module is quasi-injective iff M is fully invariant in its injective hull \hat{M}=E(M) (see sup. 3.9A).

A ring R is right QI if every quasi-injective module is injective. Any right QI ring R is right Noetherian (see 3.9A), and since each simple module is quasi-injective, R is also a right V-ring (see 3.19A).
Boyle’s Theorem 3.9B states that a ring R is right and left QI iff R is right and left hereditary Noetherian V-ring. Boyle conjectured:
(BC) Every right QI ring is right hereditary.
Theorem 3.20 reduces the question to the case of simple rings.
A theorem of Webber 7.1, as generalized by Chatters 7.2 states that any (2-sided) Noetherian hereditary ring satisfies the restricted right minimum conditions:
(RRM) R satisfies the d.c.c. on essential right ideals.
Hence, for right and left QI rings, RRM, and its left-right symmetry, RLM, are necessary conditions for the truth of BC.

A structure theorem of Michler and Villamayor [73] classifies right V-rings of right Krull dimension (K-dim) \leq 1 (see §14) as finite products of matrix rings over right Noetherian, right hereditary simple domains, each of which are restricted semisimple, i.e., R/I is semisimple for each essential right ideal I. These rings are thus right hereditary, verifying Boyle’s conjecture for these rings and in particular for RRM rings. We apply our criterion for right hereditary rings and verify Boyle’s conjecture for a class of rings satisfying the restricted right socle condition:
(RRS) If I is an essential right ideal \neq R, then R/I has socle \neq 0.

This condition is easily seen to be weaker than K-dim R\leq 1; however, it turns out to be equivalent for right QI rings insasmuch as RRS\Rightarrow RRM in Noetherian rings. (This follows because then R/I is semiArtinian and q.f.d. Cf. Shock’s Theorem 7.28.)
We begin with a lemma and theorem of general interest.

statement.label: 7.38. Lemma.
statement.p: Let I be a right ideal in a ring R which is maximal in the set of all right ideals K such that \widehat{R/K} is not semisimple. Then, I is an irreducible right ideal. Moreover, E=\widehat{R/I} is restricted semisimple provided that E has no nontrivial fully invariant submodules (=\mathbf{NFI}).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: A brief argument shows that I is irreducible, that is, R/I is uniform, hence E=\widehat{R/I} is indecomposable. Next assumming E is NFI, then E=DS, where S=R/I, and D= End E_{R}. Therefore, for any submodule K\neq 0,\, E/K is generated by the submodules \{[dS+K]\}_{d\in D}, where [dS+K]=(dS+K)/K is the submodule of E/K generated by the cosets \{[dS+K]\}_{s\in S}.

Now (dS+K)/K\approx dS/dS\cap K is an epic image of dS, and dS is an epic image of S. Moreover, dS\cap K\neq 0 since E is uniform, so that (dS+K)/K is a proper epic image of S=R/I, which, by the choice of I implies that (dS+K)/K is semisimple. Therefore, E/K, a sum of semisimple modules, is semisimple.

statement.label: 7.39. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be any right QI ring, which is not semisimple. Then, R has an indecomposable completely injective right module E which is restricted semisimple, but not semisimple.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: If every cyclic module R/I had semisimple injective hull \widehat{R/I} then every cyclic module, hence R, would be semisimple, contrary to hypothesis. Since R is right QI, then every indecomposable injective module is NFI. Inasmuch as every semisimple module in a QI ring is injective, then Lemma 7.38 supplies the module E we want.

statement.label: 7.40. Theorem.
statement.p: Any right QI ring R with restricted right socle condition is right hereditary.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By 3.20, we may assume R is simple and right Noetherian, hence by Goldie’s Theorem 3.13, R has a simple Artinian right quotient ring

where F is a minimal right ideal of Q. As outlined earlier, it suffices to prove that any injective right R-module M is completely injective. Thus, by Prop. 7.32, M is an epic image of a direct sum of copies of F. Hence, in order to prove that M is completely injective, it suffices to show that F is \Sigma -completely injective, and by Proposition 7.34A we need only show that F is completely injective.

Now if R is semisimple, there is nothing to prove. Otherwise by Theorem 7.39, there is an indecomposable completely injective right module E which is restricted semisimple but not semisimple. Now E=\widehat{R/I} for an irreducible right ideal I (= R/I is a uniform module), and I cannot be an essential right ideal, since if so, then by the RRS assumption, there is a right ideal J\subset I such that V=J/I is simple. But R right QI\Rightarrow V is injective, and then \hat{V}=E=V is simple. But E is not semisimple. Therefore I is not an essential right ideal, hence I has a nonzero relative complement right ideal K. Now K\hookrightarrow R/I canonically, so

But \hat{R}=Q by Theorem 7.36, and hence E is a direct summand of Q=F^{n}, so by the Krull-Schmidt Theorem (for direct sums of indecomposable modules with local endomorphism rings), it follows that E\approx F, so that F is completely injective too, which is what we wanted.

sec.p: As stated, Cozzens [70] constructed right QI rings R in which every indecomposable injective E either embeds in Q, or is simple. These rings were principal right ideal domains, hence right hereditary. The next corollary establishes a converse.

statement.label: 7.41. Corollary.
statement.p: Any right QI ring R such that every indecomposable injective right module either embeds in Q(R), or is simple, is necessarily right hereditary.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The point of the proof of Theorem 7.40 was to show that the module E given by Theorem 7.39 embeds in Q. As in the proof of Theorem 7.40, we may assume that R is not semisimple, and that E is not simple. Thus, E must embed in Q.

statement.label: 7.42. Remark.
statement.p: The next proposition shows that the conditions of Corollary 7.41 actually imply that R is right QI when R is right Noetherian semiprime, that is, one does not have to assume it.

sec.p: A consequence of the Matlis-Papp Theorem 3.4C and the Johnson-Wong theorem sup. 3.8s is that a ring R is right QI iff every R is right Noetherian and every indecomposable injective right R-module is NFI. For a right Noetherian semiprime ring this can be weakened to:

statement.label: 7.43. Proposition.
statement.p: Let R be a right Noetherian semiprime ring that every indecomposable injective right R-module either embeds in Q, or else if NFI. Then R is right QI.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: A result of Faith [72b], Prop. 35A, p.178, asserts that an indecomposable injective module E over a semiprime right Goldie ring R is NFI, provided that E embeds in Q. Thus, every indecomposable injective right module is NFI, so R is right QI.

sec.p: Finally, we make explicit a corollary of the proof of Theorem 7.43.

statement.label: 7.44. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is a right Noetherian V ring, and if every indecomposable injective right R-module is restricted semisimple, then R is right hereditary.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: For then every indecomposable injective right module is completely injective inasmuch as in a right Noetherian right V ring R, every semisimple module is injective. Then, Theorem 7.34C applies.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Huynh and Rizvi [97], p.272, Prop.4, elaborate on Theorem 7.40.

sec.title: \Delta -Injective Modules
sec.p:
The notation \mathcal{A}_{r}(M,R) for a right R-module M: each I\in \mathcal{A}_{r}(M,R) is the right annihilator r_{R}(X) of a subset X of M.⁠22
The results in this section first appeared in the author’s book [82a]. If M=R, then r_{R}(X)=X^{\perp }. An injective right R-module E is \Delta -injective provided \mathcal{A}_{r}(E,R) satisfies the dcc. (Cf. 3.10A.)

statement.label: 7.45A. Theorem.
statement.p: An injective right R-module E is \Delta -injective iff E is a countermodule of finite length.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This follows from Prop. 3.8(a), and the Teply-Miller Theorem 3.10. Cf. p.30 of the author’s lectures [82a], esp. Corollary 7.5.

sec.p: Below, we let \mathrm{soc}_{r}R denote the right socle of R.

statement.label: 7.45B. Theorem.
statement.p: Let E be a right \Delta -injective over R, and let Q=\mathrm{Biend}E_{R}. If Q is right Kasch, then Q is right Artinian. Necessary and sufficient conditions on J=rad\ Q for Q to be right Kasch right Artinian are the following:

def.p: J=rad\ Q\in \mathcal{A}_{r}(E, Q).
J\in \mathcal{A}_{r}(R,R).

statement.p: Moreover, the following five conditions are sufficient for Q to be right Kasch right Artinian.

def.p: r_{Q}(soc_{r}Q)=J.
J=Z_{\ell }(Q), the left singular ideal of Q.
J=r_{Q}(soc_{\ell }R).
soc_{r}Q is an essential left ideal.
soc_{r}Q\supseteq soc_{\ell }Q.

statement.p: Furthermore, the following conditions imply that Q is right Artinian:

def.p: J^{2}\in \mathcal{A}_{r}(Q,Q).
J^{2}\in \mathcal{A}_{r}(E,Q).
J/J^{2} is finitely generated (Examples: |J/J^{2}|<\infty , or Q/J^{2} is right Goldie).
R is commutative.
Q is primary-decomposable.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See the author’s Lectures [82a], Part 1, p.39, Theorem 9.5.

statement.label: 7.46. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) By Hansen’s Theorem 13.11A, Q is a semiprimary ring; (2) E is \Delta -injective over R iff E is \Delta -injective over Q; (3) A primary-decomposable ring R is a finite product of primary rings, that is, a finite product of full n\times n matrix rings over completely primary rings, that is, local rings with nilpotent radical. By a theorem of Asano [49] (Cf. 5.1A^{\prime }), this happens for a semiprimary ring R iff the prime ideals of R commute; (4) Any completely primary ring R is right and left Kasch.
To see (4), first note that if n is the index of nilpotency of J, then J^{n-1}\neq 0 and
so xJ=Jx=0 for any 0\neq x\in J, hence
so R/J embeds in R (either side).
Secondly, being a Kasch ring is a Morita invariant property: the n\times n matrix ring over a Kasch ring is Kasch; and remark (4) follows easily from this fact.

A ring R is a right \Sigma -ring (resp. \Delta -ring) provided that E(R_{R}) is \Sigma -injective (resp. \Delta -injective). Thus, any right \Delta -ring is a right \Sigma -ring, by the Teply-Miller Theorem 3.10.

statement.label: 7.47. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be a ring with maximal right quotient ring Q=Q_{\max }^{r}(R). Then:

def.p: R is a right \Sigma -ring (resp. \Delta -ring) iff Q is a right \Sigma -(resp. \Delta )-ring.
R is a right \Delta -ring iff R is a right \Sigma -ring and Q is semiprimary.

If R is a right \Delta -ring, then Q is right Artinian under any of the following conditions:(A)
Q is primary decomposable(B)
The prime ideals of Q are commutative(C)
R is commutative
Conversely, if Q is right Artinian then R is a right \Delta -ring.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This follows easily from 7.45. Cf. the author’s [82b], p.45, Theorem 10.18, for additional results and proofs.

statement.label: 7.48. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Any right uniform right \Delta -ring R has local right Artinian Q (ibid., p.42, Corollary 9.22).
(2) If R is right nonsingular, then the f.a.e.c.’s: (1) R is a right \Sigma -ring; (2) R is a right \Delta -ring; (3) Q is semisimple (ibid., p.58, Theorem 11.4.9).

sec.title: Co-Noetherian Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right co-Noetherian provided that every finitely embedded (=f.e.) right R-module is Artinian.

statement.label: 7.49. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right Noetherian and right co-Noetherian, then \bigcap _{n=1}^{\infty }J^{n}=0, where J=rad\ R.

sec.p: Cf. Mueller [69].

statement.label: 7.50. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is co-Noetherian iff R_{m} is Noetherian for all maximal ideals m.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Vámos (ibid.) proved a companion piece: Every f.e. R-module is f\cdot g iff R_{m} is Artinian for all maximal ideals m. Since every submodule of an f.e. module is f.e., this and Theorem 7.50 imply:

statement.label: 7.51. Theorem
statement.title: (Vámos, ibid).
statement.p: Every finitely embedded module M over a commutative ring R is Noetherian iff R_{m} is Artinian for all maximal ideals m. In this case M has finite length.

sec.label: Chapter 8
sec.title: Completely Decomposable Modules and the Krull-Schmidt-Azumaya Theorem
sec.p: If M is a direct sum of indecomposable modules, then M is said to be completely decomposable. (Thus: an indecomposable module is an example!)
Any semisimple module is completely decomposable, and any module of finite length is another example; in fact, any Artinian or Noetherian module is completely decomposable. If
the sum of indecomposable R-modules M_{i}, and also if

is another decomposition of M into a direct sum of indecomposable modules, then the decomposition (1) is said to be unique if for every decomposition (2) there is a bijection \pi :I\rightarrow J and a set of isomorphisms \varphi _{i}:M_{i}\rightarrow N_{\pi (i)} of R-modules. If it holds for finite sets I, then R is said to satisfy the Krull-Schmidt theorem. If this holds for all sets I, then R is said to satisfy the Azumaya-Krull-Schmidt theorem. This holds whenever End(M_{i})_{R} is a local ring \forall i\in I (Krull [25, 26]-Schmidt [28]-Azumaya [48, 50]). In this case we say that M has an Azumaya diagram (=\mathbf{AD}); when I is finite, then we say M has a finite AD.

statement.label: 8.A. Theorem.
statement.p: A right R-module M has a finite AD iff A=End\, M_{R} is semiperfect, equivalently, A is semilocal and idempotents modulo the Jacobson radical of A lift.

sec.p: In part, this theorem dates back to Remak-Krull-Schmidt, and Jordan-Hölder. Cf. Faith [76], p.45, 18.26, which is stated for an object M in an Abelian category (Cf. Swan [68]). Also see Osofsky [70] for a bit of pathology regarding completely decomposable rings.

statement.label: 8B. Theorem
statement.p: Any right linearly com pact ring R is semiperfect.

sec.title: Herbera-Shamsuddin and Camps-Dicks Theorems
sec.p: The next theorem is a grand generalization of Schur’s lemma.

statement.label: 8.C. Theorem
statement.p: If M has finite Goldie and finite dual Goldie dimension, e.g., if M is a linearly compact (=l.c.) right module over a ring, then M has semilocal endomorphism ring.

sec.p: The proof uses results of Camps and Dicks [93], especially their characterization of semilocal rings.

statement.label: 8.D. Theorem
statement.p: An Artinian module M over any ring R has semilocal endomorphism ring. Furthermore, M cancels from direct sums: M\oplus A\approx M\oplus B\Rightarrow A\approx B, for R-modules A and B.

sec.p: For the last part of 8.D, see Evans’ theorems 6.3F–G. Cf. 8.8ff.

statement.label: 8.E. Theorem.
statement.p: Any l.c. R-module M over a commutative ring has semiperfect endomorphism ring, hence M has a finite AD (Cf. 8A).

sec.p: The proof of 8.E given in Herbera-Shamsuddin (following Corollary 7 on p.3597) is due to 8.C and a theorem that states that pure-injective (e.g. l.c.) modules have F-semiperfect endomorphism rings (Jensen-Lenzing [89], p.180, Corollary 8.27). See 6.52.

sec.title: Swan’s Theorem
sec.p: Unless otherwise noted, the Krull-Schmidt theorem is stated for finite direct sums of f\cdot g indecomposable modules. The next theorem is a corollary of Theorem 8E.

statement.label: 8.F. Theorem
statement.p: Any Noetherian complete local commutative ring satisfies the Krull-Schmidt theorem, in fact, every f\cdot g module has an AD.

sec.p: Cf. Wiegand [98].

sec.title: Evans’ Theorem
sec.p: A commutative local ring R with residue field \overline{R} is Henselian provided that for any monic polynomial f(x), any factorization of \bar{f}(x) in \overline{R}[x] into a product of relatively prime monies lifts to one in R[x].
Swan gave an example of a non-Henselian local ring over which Krull-Schmidt fails. In this sense Evans’ theorem is definitive:

statement.label: 8.G. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative local ring R is Henselian iff every local ring A that is a module-finite R-algebra, i.e., A=Ra_{1}+\cdots +Ra_{n} for a_{1},\ldots ,a_{n}\in A, satisfies Krull-Schmidt.

sec.p: Evans’ theorem is used in the proof of:

statement.label: 8.H. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a non-Henselian discrete valuation ring whose completion \hat{R} is not algebraic over R, then the Krull-Schmidt theorem fails for torsion-free R-modules of finite rank.

sec.title: Matlis’ Problem
sec.p: (MP): If module E is a direct sum of indecomposable injectives, is every direct summand M of E completely decomposable?

statement.p: Matlis-Papp Theorem. If R is right Noetherian, then MP has an affirmative answer.

sec.p: Since M is itself injective, this follows from the Matlis-Papp theorem 3.4C: If R is right Noetherian, every injective right R-module M is completely decomposable.

statement.label: 8.2A. Theorem
statement.p: If E is a completely decomposable injective (or quasi-injective) module over a ring R, then MP has an affirmative answer.

statement.label: 8.2B. Theorem
statement.p: If E is a completely decomposable module, E=\bigoplus _{i\in I}E_{i}, where E_{i} is countably generated indecomposable with local endomorphism ring (e.g. if E_{i} is injective), then each direct summand of E has the same property, so MP has an affirmative answer.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Anderson-Fuller [92], p. 298, Theorem 26.5.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This follows from the Crawley-Jónsson theorem (see 8.4) as Warfield pointed out (loc.cit.).

sec.title: The Exchange Property and Direct Sums of Indecomposable Injective Modules
sec.p: A module M has the exchange property (Crawley-Jónsson [64]) if for any module A and any two direct sum decompositions
with M^{\prime }\approx M, there exist submodules A_{i}^{\prime }\subseteq A, such that

The module M has the finite exchange property if this holds whenever the index set I is finite. Examples of modules which have the exchange property are quasi injective modules and modules whose endomorphism rings are semi-perfect (see Examples 8.4G).

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: A direct summand M of a module A has the exchange property in A if for any direct sum decomposition A=\bigoplus _{i\in I}A_{i}, there exist submodules A_{i}^{\prime }\subseteq A_{i}, such that A=M\oplus (\bigoplus _{i\in I}A_{i}^{\prime }).

statement.label: 8.3. Theorem.
statement.p: Matlis’ problem (MP) has an affirmative answer for any direct summand M^{\prime } with the exchange property in a direct sum of indecomposable injectives.

sec.p: As Warfield pointed out, this follows trivially inasmuch as each A_{i}^{\prime } is necessarily indecomposable injective, hence A_{i}^{\prime }=A_{i} or A_{i}^{\prime }=0, so then M^{\prime }=\bigoplus _{j\in J}A_{j}, where J=\{i\in I\,|\,A_{i}^{\prime }\neq 0\}.

sec.title: Crawley-Jónsson Theorem
sec.p: Two direct sum decompositions
of a right R-module A are said to have isomorphic refinements provided that there exist submodules \{C_{ij}\,|\,i\in I,j\in J\}
Obviously two direct sum decompositions of A into indecomposable modules \{A_{i}\}_{i\in I} and \{B_{j}\}_{j\in J} have isomorphic refinements iff the decomposition is unique.

statement.label: 8.4. Theorem
statement.p: Any two direct sum decompositions of a right R-module M have isomorphic refinements if M=\oplus _{i\in I}\,M_{i} is a direct sum of any number of countably generated modules \{M_{i}\}_{i\in I} with the exchange property.

sec.title: Warfield, Nicholson and Monk Theorems
sec.p: A (finite) exchange module is one with the (finite) exchange property. An exchange ring R is one such that R_{R} is an exchange module. This is right-left symmetric by Warfield [72b], who proved the following theorem: (Nicholson [97] has given an elementary proof of this.)

statement.label: 8.4A.
statement.p: Warfield’s Theorem [72b].

def.p: A right R-module M is a finite exchange module iff End M_{R} is an exchange ring; in particular finite exchange rings are exchange rings.
If R is an exchange ring, then any projective left (right) R-module is a direct sum of left (right) ideals generated by idempotents.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: In connection with (1) of 8.4A, see 8.4B. (2) of 8.4A generalizes Kaplansky’s theorem for local rings and VNR rings. See for example 3.21 and the remark following 3.23A.

sec.p: A ring R is a lift/rad ring provided that all idempotents of R/\mathrm{rad}R lift, e.g. any ring with nil Jacobson radical (Jacobson [56,64]), or any semiperfect ring. See 3.30ff.

A ring R is (left) suitable (Nicholson [77]) if idempotents of R/I lift for any left ideal I. (Thus, if x^{2}-x\in I for x\in R, there exists an idemipotent e\in R so that x-e\in I.) A ring R is (left) suitable iff R/\mathrm{rad}R is (left) suitable and R is a lift/rad ring (loc. cit.).
The endomorphism ring of a quasi-injective R-module is suitable by Theorem 4.2A. The next theorem shows suitable is right-left symmetric:

statement.label: 8.4B. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a right R-module M:

def.p: End M_{R} is right suitable,
End M_{R} is left suitable,
M is a finite exchange module.
End M_{R} is an exchange ring (Cf. 8.4A).

sec.p: Combined with another theorem of Nicholson [75], Theorem 4.3, one has:

statement.label: 8.4C. Corollary.
statement.p: A ring R is semiperfect iff R is an exchange ring with no infinite set of orthogonal idempotents.

statement.label: 8.4D. Corollary
statement.p: An indecomposable right R-module M is an exchange module iff End M_{R} is a local ring.

sec.p: Monk’s theorem is also obtained by Nicholson as a corollary of 8.4B.

statement.label: 8.4E. Theorem
statement.p: A right R-module M is an exchange module iff given \alpha \in A=EndM_{R} there exists \gamma and \sigma in A such that

sec.title: \pi -Regular Rings
sec.p: A ring R is \boldsymbol{\pi }-regular if for each a\in R there exists n=n(a) and x\in R such that a^{n}xa^{n} =a^{n}. Strongly \pi -regular means R satisfies the dcc on the set \{a^{n}R\} for any a\in R. Any strongly \pi -regular ring is \pi -regular (Azumaya [54]). A ring R is semi-\pi -regular if R/\mathrm{rad}R is \pi -regular and R is suitable.

statement.label: 8.4F. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a \pi -regular ring of bounded index, then all primitive factor rings of R are Artinian.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See loc. cit., Theorem 2.3.

statement.label: 8.4F'. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a left self-injective strongly \pi -regular ring, then J(R) is nil and R/J(R) is a finite direct product of full matrix rings over self-injective strongly regular rings.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) A left self-injective algebraic algebra R over a field is strongly \pi -regular, and the structure of R/J(R) was more fully described by Menal [81], Proposition 2.3; (2) Theorem 8.4F' essentially follows from the Kaplansky-Armendariz Steinberg Theorem 4.5.

statement.label: 8.4G.
statement.p: Example 1. (Nicholson [77]–Stock [86]). Any semi-\pi -regular ring is an exchange ring.

Example 2. (Yu [97]). An exchange ring R with all prime factor rings Artinian is strongly \pi -regular. (Cf. 8.4F.) This theorem fails when “prime” is replaced by “primitive” (Yu, ibid.) (Yu [94] studied the countable exchange property.)
Example 3. Any semiperfect module is a finite exchange module (Nicholson, loc.cit.).

Example 4. (Lam) A Dedekind finite exchange ring R need not be semiperfect, e.g. any infinite product R of copies of any field: R is self injective hence suitable by 4.2A hence an exchange ring by 8.4B.

Example 5. By Theorems 4.2A, 8.4A and 8.4B, any quasi-injective module is an exchange module (Fuchs [69], Theorem 3, p.545, Kahlon [71], and Warfield [72b], who showed that any lift/rad ring R that is VNR modulo Jacobson radical, that is any F-semiperfect ring, is an exchange ring.)

statement.label: 8.4H. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a locally module finite algebra over a commutative zero-dimensional ring S, and let A be any finitely generated left R-module. Then A has the finite exchange property and any two direct sum decompositions of A have isomorphic refinements. More generally, if M is a left R-module which is a direct sum of finitely generated submodules, then any direct summand of M is again a direct sum of finitely generated modules, and any two direct sum decompositions of M have isomorphic refinements. In particular, any projective left R-module is a direct sum of left ideals generated by idempotents.

statement.label: 8.4I. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Examples due to Evans [73] show that in Theorem 8.4H one cannot replace the requirement that S is zero-dimensional with the requirement that S/J(S) is von Neumann regular, or even that R=S and S is a (Noetherian) local ring;

(2) The proof uses a characterization of exchange rings due to Goodearl (unpublished): E is an exchange ring if and only if for every pair of left ideals I and J such that I+J=E, there is an idempotent e\in I such that 1-e\in J.⁠11
This is essentially Prop. 1.1 of Nicholson [77]. See Theorem 5.4B above.

sec.title: Yamagata’s Theorem
sec.p: We recall that for a ring R a right ideal I is (meet) irreducible provided I\neq R and I=I_{1}\cap I_{2} implies I=I_{1} or I=I_{2} for all right ideals I_{1} and I_{2} of R, equivalently, R/I is uniform. Let A\subseteq ^{\prime }B denote that A is an essential submodule of B.

statement.label: 8.5A. Theorem
statement.p: The following conditions are equivalent:

def.p: A ring R satisfies the ascending chain condition for irreducible right ideals.
Any direct sum M of indecomposable injective modules has the exchange property.
Any direct sum M of indecomposable injective modules has the finite exchange property.
Any direct summand of the module M which is a direct sum of indecomposable injective modules has the exchange property in M.

statement.p: Moreover, (ii), (iii) and (v) are equivalent for any such M.

sec.p: The proof depends on work of Harada and Sai [70] and Harada [71].

statement.label: 8.5B. Corollary.
statement.p: If R has the acc on irreducible right ideals, then any direct summand M of a direct sum of indecomposable injectives is completely decomposable, i.e., MP holds. (Cf. 8.1s and 8.3.)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Various other conditions, e.g. when M is a nonsingular module, imply that MP holds true. (See, e.g. Kahlon [71], Harada [72], and Yamagata [73].)

sec.p: Cf. Ace on irreducible ideals, §16, esp. 6.39 – 16.43.

sec.title: Decompositions Complementing Direct Summands
sec.p: A decomposition
into a direct sum of a right R-modules A_{i} is said to complement direct summands (= cds) provided that each A_{i}\neq 0, and for any direct summand M there exists a subset J\subseteq I so that
In this case each A_{i} is necessarily indecomposable. The decomposition (1) complements maximal direct summands (= cmds) if for each direct sum decomposition
with N\neq 0 indecomposable, then there exists i_{0}\in I so that A=M\oplus A_{i_{0}}.

statement.label: 8.6. Theorem
statement.p: If the decomposition (1) complements direct summands (resp. cmds), then all decompositions of A into a direct sum of indecomposable modules cds (resp. cmds), and so does any direct summand of A. Moreover, if (1) cmds then the decomposition is unique.

sec.p: Cf. loc.cit. Lemma 1, Theorem 2 and Corollary 3.

statement.label: 8.7. Corollary.
statement.p: A right R-module A has a decomposition (1) that cds iff every direct summand of A has the exchange property in A.

sec.p: Cf. loc.cit., 152.

statement.label: 8.8. Theorem
statement.p: If an injective module A is completely decomposable, then that decomposition cds.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: By the Matlis-Papp theorem 3.4C, every injective right R-module A has a decomposition (1) that cds iff R is right Noetherian.

sec.title: Fitting’s Lemma and the Krull-Schmidt Theorem
sec.p: Fitting’s Lemma states that any indecomposable R-module M of finite length has local, in fact, completely primary, endomorphism ring, hence any direct sum of indecomposable modules of finite lengths satisfies the Krull-Schmidt-Azumaya theorem, e.g. any f\cdot g module over a right Artinian ring.

The corresponding question for an Artinian module was raised by Krull [32], and disproved by Facchini, Herbera, Levy and Vámos [95] (denoted FHLV below), employing results of Camps and Dicks [93], who also proved that any Artinian R-module over any ring R has semilocal endomorphism ring. Facchini [96] showed that Krull-Schmidt also fails for serial modules.⁠22
Also see Facchini’s book [98] and survey [01]. Camps and Menal [91] proved that any commutative semilocal Noetherian domain can be represented as the endomorphism ring of a necessarily indecomposable Artinian module. This was generalized in FHLV: if A is a module finite algebra over a semilocal Noetherian commutative ring, then A\approx EndM_{R} where M_{R} is Artinian, for some ring R. This is the key to disproving Krull-Schmidt for Artinian modules. Cedó’s theorem in Camps-Dicks [93] states that a ring R is semilocal if R satisfies the ace on left and right point annihilators, and every right or left regular element is a unit. Cedó’s theorem generalized Stafford’s theorem [82] for Noetherian quotient rings. A commutative \mathrm{acc}\perp ring R has semilocal Kasch quotient ring Q(R) (Faith [91b]).

sec.title: A Very General Schur Lemma
sec.p: As stated (8.C), Herbera and Shamsuddin [95] in a grand generalization of Schur’s lemma proved that any module M that is linearly compact in the discrete topology has semilocal endomorphism ring. While this generalized the Camps-Dicks theorem, the proof makes essential use of the Camps-Dicks characterizations of semilocal rings, and also the concept of dual Goldie dimension.

Faith and Herbera [97] conjectured that over a commutative linearly compact ring R every linearly compact R-module M has R-linearly compact endomorphism ring and prove it for Noetherian and valuation rings. Moreover, the question is equivalent to the condition that M\otimes _{R}\,N is linearly compact for any two linearly compact R-modules M and N. A necessary condition for the truth of the conjecture is that the center of A (= the biendomorphism ring of M) be linearly compact.

sec.title: Rings of Finite and Bounded Module Type
sec.p: A good deal of module theory is aimed at the description of the indecomposable finitely generated modules (at least over right Noetherian rings when every finitely generated module decomposes into a direct sum of indecomposable modules!) Let M be an indecomposable module over a right Noetherian ring R, assume that M is finitely generated, and let g(M) be the least cardinal of any set of generators of M. In general, there exist indecomposable modules M with ever larger g(M). Indeed, by Higman’s theorem [54], this happens whenever R is the group algebra in characteristic p with noncyclic p-Sylow subgroup G of finite order n; in particular, finite rings can have this property. (However, in the case of cyclic p-Sylow subgroup, n is a bound on the “number” of indecomposable modules (Kasch-Kneser-Kupisch [57]).)

Next assume a bound on the \{g(M)\}. This is a reasonable finiteness condition which one frequently encounters in classical algebra, for example, as we have seen, it holds over FGC rings. Such a ring is said to be right FBG, or bounded module type. A commutative local FBG ring R has linearly ordered ideals (Warfield [70]) (cf. 6.5), that is, R is a chain ring.

Another kind of finiteness condition that frequently occurs in the theory of finite dimensional algebras and Artinian rings: does right FBG imply finiteness of the isomorphism classes of indecomposable finitely generated right modules? A ring with the latter property is said to be right FFM, or finite module type. (Serial rings are right and left FFM rings.) In this notation the question just stated can be stated as the validity of the implication FBG\Rightarrow FFM. For algebras of finite dimension over a field this was called the Brauer-Thrall conjecture, and was proved by Roiter [68]. For Artinian rings, Auslander [74] proved the conjecture utilizing notably different methods. Any FFM algebra, in fact, FFM Artinian ring, has finite lattice of ideals (Jans [56], Tachikawa [60] and Colby [66]). By Yamagata [75], a semiperfect ring R has FFM (= finite representation type) iff every direct sum of indecomposable modules enjoys the exchange property.

Auslander ([74], Cor. 4.8) and Ringel and Tachikawa in Tachikawa [73, p.129, Cor. 9.5] prove: Let R be a right Artinian right FFM ring. Then, every indecomposable right R-module is finitely generated, and every right module is a direct sum of indecomposable modules. Then, by Zimmermann-Huisgen [79] (cf. Theorem 6.56 in the text) R is right pure-semisimple (cf. 6.57).
Herzog [96b] studies whether pure-semisimple implies FFM, and verifies this for PI-rings and Morita rings (see §13 for Morita rings).

Moreover, Tachikawa [73] also shows over a right FFM ring that all modules have decompositions which complement direct summands (cds), see §8, esp. 8.6ff. Fuller-Reiten [75] (Cf. Fuller [76]) prove a converse for rings over which right and left modules have decompositions which cds. Auslander [74] showed that Artin algebras are FFM provided only that every indecomposable left module is finitely generated. Moreover, the theorem of Faith-Walker [67] (cf. 3.5B) states that if every injective left module is a direct sum of finitely generated modules, then R must be left Artinian. This property characterizes commutative Artinian rings by the Morita Theorems [58]: every commutative Artinian ring R has a Morita duality and every indecomposable injective R-module is f\cdot g (Cf. 13.4B). As Rosenberg and Zelinsky [59] showed, in general the injective hull of a f\cdot g module (e.g. any indecomposable injective) need not be f\cdot g. For when injective hulls of cyclics are cyclic, see Faith [66b], Caldwell [67], and Osofsky [68b]; (they include Köthe’s uniserial rings–see Faith [66b]).

sec.label: Chapter 9
sec.title: Polynomial Rings over Vamosian and Kerr Rings, Valuation Rings and Prüfer Rings
sec.p: A commutative ring R is Vamosian if each finitely embedded R-module M (= has finite essential socle) is linearly compact. (See Vámos [75] where the rings are called “classical”.) Any linearly compact ring R is Vamosian, and so is any locally Noetherian ring (e.g. any VNR ring R). It can be shown, for any locally Noetherian ring R, that the polynomial ring R[x] is locally Noetherian (e.g. Faith [86b], where Vamosian rings were named, or Huckaba [88], p.73, Lemma 13.1). Vámos [75] showed that classical (= Vamosian rings) are SISI (= subdirectly irreducible factors are self-injective). (Cf. FSI rings, 5.9ff.) Faith [89a] showed that SISI rings are not preserved under polynomial extension, and asked the same question regarding Vamosian rings. Xue [96] has given a negative answer. Theorem 4.4 of the author’s paper ibid, also provides a negative answer since an AMVR is Vamosian.

statement.label: 9.1. Theorem
statement.p: For a commutative linearly compact ring R the following are equivalent:

def.p: R is Noetherian
R is locally Noetherian
R[X] is Vamosian
R[X] is co-Noetherian

sec.p: By Zelinsky’s theorem [53] (cf. Sandomierski [72]) R is a finite direct product of local rings, hence locally Noetherian implies Noetherian (cf. Xue [92]). Xue’s theorem shows that any non-Noetherian linearly compact ring R has non-Vamosian R[X].

sec.title: Kerr Rings and the Camillo-Guralnick-Roitman Theorem
sec.p: A ring R is a (right) Kerr ring provided that the polynomial ring R[X] satisfies the acc on annihilators, namely acc\perp (in which case R is an acc\perp ring). Any subring of a Noetherian ring is Kerr.

statement.label: 9.2. Theorem
statement.p: Not every commutative Goldie ring R has Goldie polynomial ring; in fact, not every Goldie ring R is a Kerr ring.

sec.p: The second statement followed from the first since a polynomial ring R[X] has \mathrm{acc}\oplus (= finite Goldie dimension) iff R does (Shock [72]).

statement.label: 9.2A. Remark.
statement.p: Kerr [79] showed that there exists a commutative Goldie Kerr ring whose 2\times 2 matrix ring isn’t Goldie. (In this example R has just two nontrivial annihilator ideals and R has Goldie dimension two. Cf. 9.4 and 9.5.)

statement.label: 9.3. Theorem
statement.p: If R is an \mathit{acc}\!\perp algebra over an uncountable field, then R is a Kerr ring and so is any polynomial ring over R in any number of variables.

sec.p: The trick in the proof is that any countably generated subring of R[X] embeds in R. (It is necessary and sufficient for acc \perp for any countably generated subring to have acc \perp .)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Roitman applied the coup de grace to Theorem 9.3 in the following:

statement.label: 9.3^{\prime }. Theorem.
statement.p: Over a countable field k there is an \mathit{acc}\!\perp algebra that is not Kerr.

sec.p: Noting that Roitman’s examples were not Goldie, Antoine and Cedó proved:

statement.label: 9.3^{\prime \prime }. Theorem
statement.p: For each finite field k there exists a commutative Goldie algebra R which is not Kerr.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: The construction follows Kerr [90].

sec.p: Notes: (1) The theorem is stated in both papers in greater generality: all that is needed is the existence of a set S in the center of R consisting of uncountably many elements, such that s-t is not a zero divisor for all s\neq t\in S. (2) A domain A is Mori if A satisfies the acc on integral divisorial ideals (= intersections of cyclic A-submodules of K=Q(A)), or equivalently, A/(a) has acc\perp for any nonzero a\in A (Roitman loc.cit., p.248, Theorem 2.2). Roitman applies 9.3 to obtain that for any Mori domain A over an uncountable field, a polynomial ring in any set of variables is also Mori.

statement.label: 9.4. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative acc\perp ring R is Kerr when R has Goldie dimension 1, or when R is Goldie and its classical quotient ring Q has nil Jacobson radical, or when R is reduced, or when Q is finitely embedded (=f.e.). Then, in all cases, Q is Artinian.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Actually a f.e. acc\perp ring is Artinian (See the author’s paper [91a].) (2) A reduced acc\perp ring has semisimple Q. (See the author’s paper [94], Theorem 3.3.) (3) Since Q in Theorem 9.4 is Artinian, then any n\times n matrix ring over R satisfies acc\perp , hence is Goldie.

statement.label: 9.5A. Corollary.
statement.p: (loc.cit.). If R is a Goldie commutative ring such that Q is an algebraic algebra over a field k or has dimension over k strictly less than the cardinality of k, then Q is Artinian hence R is a Kerr ring.

statement.label: 9.5B. Corollary.
statement.p: Any uniform commutative acc\perp ring R has QF quotient ring Q.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: For Q is Artinian and subdirectly irreducible, so Classical Ring Theory applies. Also Shizhong’s Theorem 7.11 and a theorem of Bass [63] apply. (See 13.21 for the latter. Also see the author’s paper [96b], Corollary 4.)

statement.label: 9.6. Theorem.
statement.p: If R is a commutative Goldie ring, and if the local ring of R at each associated prime ideal P is Noetherian, then R has a flat embeding in a Noetherian ring, hence R is Kerr, and so is any polynomial ring R[X] over R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Beck’s Theorem 3.16C. Also see theorem 16.33 and Remark 16.34. Apply the fact (16.18) that AssR is finite.

statement.label: 9.7. Theorem
statement.p: There exist a Kerr ring R such that for any integer n\geq 1, the polynomial ring R[X_{1},\ldots ,X_{n}] in n variables is Kerr, but that in n+1 variables is not Kerr.

statement.label: 9.8. Theorem.
statement.p: (Roitman [89, II]). There exists a Kerr ring R such that R[[x]] does not satisfy acc\perp .

sec.p: This was proved independently by Cedó [95].

sec.title: Rings with Few Zero Divisors Are Those with Semilocal Quotient Rings
sec.p: A commutative ring is said to have few zero divisors iff the set z(R) of zero divisors is a finite union of prime ideals. The concept originated in 1962 in a paper of E. Davis [64]. (Cf. Huckaba [88], p.49.)

statement.label: 9.9. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R has few zero divisors iff its classical quotient ring Q(R) is semilocal.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See loc.cit., p. 204, Remark 1. Also see Prop. 9.58 below.

sec.p: Note: Davis’ theorem corrects the author’s paper [96c], i.e., Q(R) is not necessarily Kasch. (I have T. Y. Lam [98] to thank for calling my attention to this.)

statement.label: 9.9A. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Any ring R with the acc on annihilator ideals has semilocal Kasch Q(R), hence few zero divisors (Faith [91b], Cor. 3.7), and also R[X] has few zero divisors, even though R[X] need not have acc on annihilators. (The latter result is a theorem of Kerr [90], see 9.2.); (2) R has semilocal Kasch Q(R) iff the same is true of the polynomial ring over R. (See Faith [91b]). Cf. 16.28-16.32, and 16.42, 16.42f.

sec.title: Heinzer-Ohm Theorem
sec.p: A ring R is said to be a ZD-ring (Heinzer-Ohm [72]) provided that R is commutative and the zero divisors of every factor ring is a finite union of primes. By Davis’ Theorem 9.9, R is ZD iff R is fractionally semilocal in the sense that Q(R/I) is semilocal for all ideals I\neq R. (Cf. 6.4).

statement.label: 9.9B. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a ZD-ring Then:

def.p: If R is locally Noetherian, then R is Noetherian.
If the polynomial ring R[X] is a ZD-ring then R is Noetherian.

statement.label: 9.9B^{\prime }. Corollary.
statement.p: A commutative ring R is Noetherian iff R is fractionally semilocal and locally Noetherian.

sec.title: Cedó’s Theorem on Semilocal Rings
sec.p: A right point or principal, annihilator has the form x^{\perp } for some element x in R.

statement.label: 9.9C. Theorem
statement.p: If R satisfies the acc on left and acc on right point annihilators, and if every right or left regular element is a unit then R is semilocal.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: A right Noetherian quotient ring R need not be semilocal by an example of Stafford [82].

statement.label: 9.9D. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is a commutative ring with acc on point annihilators, then Q(R) is semilocal.

sec.p: Cf. Theorem 16.40.

statement.label: Question.
statement.p: Is Q(R) Kasch in 9.9C? Cf. 9.9A(1).

sec.title: Manis Valuation Rings
sec.p: Griffin [70], p.56, defines a ring to have few zero divisors if it has just “finitely many maximal prime ideals of 0” and remarks that the “principal property” of such a ring R is that for any element z\in Q(R), and for each regular element a\in R there exists u\in R such that z+au is regular, (“Choose u in all maximal 0-primes not containing z and in no 0-primes containing z”).
A Manis valuation v is an onto map v:K\rightarrow \Gamma \cup \{\infty \} of a ring K and a totally ordered group \Gamma , and symbol \infty , such that

A subring A is a Manis valuation ring if there is a valuation v of K such that A=\{x\in K\,|\,v(x)\geq 0\}. In this case P=\{x\in K\,|\,v(x)>0\} a prime ideal, and A is a maximal subring B of K containing A that has a prime ideal P^{\prime } that contracts to P. Then (A,P) is a called a max pair in K, and P is the valuation prime ideal. The converse also holds: any \max pair (A,P) defines a Manis valuation ring. For domains this is due to Krull [32]. (Cf. 9.10ff. Also see Manis [67] and Griffin [70]. See 9.11–12 and 19.18ff. below.)

Any subring A of K that is maximal with respect to excluding some unit x of K is a Manis valuation ring with valuation prime ideal P=\sqrt {x^{-1}A}. Then A is called a conch subring and is said to conch x in K (Faith [84b,86c]).
Conversely, if (A,P) is a \max pair in K and if P=\sqrt {x^{-1}A} for a unit x of K, then A conches x in K (Faith [86c], p.40, Theorem 2.1).

Davis [64] defines a subring B of K to be a quasi-valuation ring provided that for each regular element x of K either x or x^{-1} belongs to B. Furthermore, if A has few zero divisors, then A is a quasi-valuation ring iff A is a Manis valuation ring (Griffin [70], Lemma 2). By Davis’ Theorem 9.9, we have then the:

statement.label: 9.10. Corollary.
statement.p: If A has semilocal quotient ring K, then A is a Manis valuation ring iff A is a quasi-valuation ring.

sec.p: In this case, any two ideals I and J of A, one of which contains a regular element, are comparable. In the classical case where A is a domain then any two ideals are comparable, i.e.., A is a valuation domain in the classical sense (cf. Krull [32], where the subject may be said to have originated. Also see 9.11 and 9.19 (1)).

sec.title: Integrally Closed Rings
sec.p: A ring A is integrally closed in Q=Q(A) if every q\in Q that satisfies a monic polynomial in A[x] belongs to A.

statement.label: 9.11. Theorem
statement.p: Any integrally closed domain A is the intersection of valuation overrings.

statement.label: 9.11^{\prime }. Theorem
statement.p: An integral domain A is integrally closed iff every nonconstant monic polynomial over A has a unique factorization as a product of nonconstant monic polyomials over A.

sec.p: A ring A is a paravaluation ring if it is a valuation ring of Q=Q(A) for a Manis valuation v of Q in which v:Q\rightarrow \Gamma \cup \{\infty \} need not be onto (as required in the definition).

statement.label: 9.12. Theorem

title.sc: M. Griffin; see Huckaba [88], p.54, Corollary 9.2

statement.p: A ring R is integrally closed in Q=Q(R) iff R is the intersection of paravaluation rings of Q.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Cf. the author’s paper [84b], and Review [90b] of Huckaba’s book [88],

statement.label: 9.13. Theorem
statement.p: Any commutative FPF ring R is integrally closed.

sec.title: Kaplansky’s Question
sec.p: (K) If A is a chain ring, is A\approx R/I where I is an ideal, and R is a chain domain?
Fuchs and Salce [85] gave a counter-example. (Cf. Osofsky’s counter-example [91].)
Hungerford [68] and MacLean [73] gave affirmative answers for A with Noetherian quotient ring Q(A). Also see Fuchs and Shelah [89].

sec.title: Local Manis Valuation Rings
sec.p: A Manis valuation ring A of K=Q(A) need not be a local ring, hence need not be a chain ring. A sandwich subring of K is a subring that contains the Jacobson radical J=\mathrm{rad}\,K of K.

statement.label: 9.14. Theorem
statement.p: If a Manis valuation ring A of K=Q(A) is a local ring then A is a sandwich ring, and conversely if A is a local ring.

sec.p: See op.cit., pp.20–21, for this and the next theorem.

statement.label: 9.15A.
statement.p: Local Conch Ring Theorem. Let A conch x in K=Q(A). Then A is a local ring with maximal ideal \sqrt {x^{-1}A} iff K is a local ring and A is a sandwich ring.

statement.label: 9.15B. Corollary.
statement.p: For a Manis valuation ring A of a chain ring K=Q(A), the following are equivalent:

def.p: A is a local ring,
A is a sandwich subring of K,
A is a chain ring (= classical valuation ring).

sec.p: See the author’s op.cit., p.25; and Froeschl’s theorem:

statement.label: 9.15C. Theorem
statement.p: If K=Q(A) is a chain ring, and A is a valuation ring of K, then A is chained iff A\supseteq the set z(K) of zero divisors of K. Otherwise A has exactly two maximal ideals, one of which is z(A).

def.p: Any chain ring A is a Manis valuation ring for K=Q(A) (see the author’s op.cit., p. 22,§14).

If A conches x in K, then A is a maximal subring of K iff K=A[x]. If K is a field, this happens iff A is a rank 1 classical valuation ring. If A is Noetherian, then by the Principal Ideal Theorem 2.22, A is conch in K iff A has dimension 1.
Froeschl’s Theorem yields (2) \Leftrightarrow (3) of 9.15B.

statement.label: 9.16. Theorem.
statement.p: If A is a local FPF ring, then A is a Manis valuation ring for Q(A), and conversely if Q(A) is self-injective.

sec.p: See the author’s op.cit., pp.20 and 24.

statement.label: 9.17. Example

title.sc: Valente [87], Communicated to the author by Vitulli

statement.p: In general, a Manis valuation v is defined on a ring K not necessarily a quotient ring (Manis [67]), and furthermore v is not necessarily extendable to Q(K). First consider the \mathbb{Z}-adic valuation w:\mathbb{Q}\rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_{\infty }=\mathbb{Z}\cup \{\infty \} (e.g. w(a) is the max n so that 2^{n}\,|\, a for all 0\neq a\in \mathbb{Z}, and w(a/b)=w(a)-w(b).) Then a Manis valuation v:\mathbb{Q}[x]\rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_{\infty } assigns v(f) the value w(f(0)), and the core (or infinite prime ideal) is:

Then, v extends to \mathbb{Q}[x]_{H} but no further. In general, a Manis valuation v of a ring K extends to \mathbb{Q}(K) iff the core H consists entirely of zero divisors. (This corrects a misstatement in the author’s paper [86c].)

sec.title: Domination of Local Rings

statement.label: 9.18. Definition.
statement.p: If (R,m) is a local ring, then a local ring (5,n) dominates (R,m) in case S\supseteq R, and n\cap R=m, equivalently m\subseteq n.

def.p: (Krull [32]) Every local domain is dominated by a valuation domain.
If (R,m) is a local domain and F is a subfield of Q(R), then R\cap F is a local ring dominated by R.
Every Noetherian local ring is dominated by a complete local ring.
(Chevalley [54]) Every Noetherian local domain is dominated by a rank-1 discrete valuation domain.

(Gilmer-Heinzer [97]) Every Noetherian local ring R is dominated by a 1-dimensional Noetherian local ring S so that regular elements of R are regular in S, and each associated prime of S contracts to an associate prime of R.

sec.p: See Gilmer-Heinzer for references and proofs.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) is the key result in the proof of Krull’s Theorem 9.11^{\prime }. Also see Nagata [62], (11.9); (2) See Nagata, (17.6) for the proof of (3); (3) See Cahen-Houston-Lucas [96] for a generalization of (4).

sec.title: Marot Rings
sec.p: A Marot ring R is a commutative ring such that every regular ideal (= one containing a regular element) is generated by regular elements. (Named by Huckaba [88], p.31. We also refer to Huckaba, sections 7–9, for historical background and proofs of this and the following section on Krull rings).

statement.label: 9.20. Example.
statement.p: Any ring R with few zero divisors, equivalently by 9.9, any ring R with semilocal quotient ring Q(R), is a Marot ring, e.g., if R has acc\perp . (See Remark following 9.9; also see Huckaba, op.cit., p.32, Theorem 7.2.)

sec.title: Krull Rings
sec.p: A commutative ring R is a Krull ring if R is Marot and either R=Q_{c\ell }(R) or else there exists a family \{v_{i}\}_{i\in I} of discrete rank 1 valuations of R such that:

def.p: R=\bigcap _{i\in I}V_{i} of the corresponding valuation rings \{V_{i}\}_{i\in I}.
For each regular element x\in Q(R), v_{i}(x)=0 for just finitely many i, equivalently x is a unit in all but finitely many of the V_{i}.

sec.p: Cf. Ratliff [98] (also Fossum [73]) for other possible generalizations of Krull domains. Also see Osmanagic [99] for a general approximation theorem for “non-Marot Krull rings.”

statement.label: 9.21. Theorem.
statement.p: If R is Marot, then R is integrally closed iff R is the intersection of the valuation overrings of R.

sec.p: See Huckaba [88], p.54, Theorem 9.2. Cf. Griffith Theorem 9.12.

statement.label: 9.22. Theorem
statement.p: The integral closure of a Noetherian ring R is a Krull ring.

statement.label: 9.23. Theorem.
statement.p: The polynomial ring R[X] over a commutative Marot ring is a Krull ring iff R is a finite product of Krull domains.

sec.p: See Fossum [73]. Also see 9.26Aff.

statement.p: Related Results.

def.p: (Nagata [62], Theorem 33.2 and 33.12) If D is a Noetherian domain of dimension 2, then the integral closure D^{\prime } of D is Noetherian;
(Huckaba [88],§11,esp. 11.6) (1) fails if D is an arbitrary Noetherian ring of dimension \leq 2, but in this case every regular ideal of D^{\prime } is f\cdot g;
(Akiba [80]], Theorem 13.11 in Huckaba, op.cit.) If R is an integrally closed reduced McCoy ring, then so is the polynomial ring R[X];
(Endo [61]) If Q(R) is a VNR ring, then R is integrally closed iff R_{m} is an integral closed domain for all m\in \max R;
(Quentel [72]) If R has compact min spec, then R[X] is integrally closed iff Q(R) is VNR.

statement.label: 9.25A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a Noetherian commutative ring, then R[X]_{W} is Noetherian for any set X of variables, where R[X]_{W} is R[X] localized at the set W of polynomials of unit content.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) This answered a question of R. Heitman. (2) Thus, for an infinite set X,R[X] is a non-Goldie subring of the Noetherian ring R[X]_{W}. Furthermore, R[X] is an acc\perp ring, in fact, Kerr (cf. 9.2ff); (3) 9.25 is a remark of D. D. Anderson in Camillo [90], p.75, who kindly supplied the reference to Gilmer and Henzer, who also prove that certain quotient rings of R[X] with respect to multiplicative systems of monic polynomials are Noetherian. In this regard, see the following theorem 9.25B.

statement.label: 9.25B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative Noetherian ring, then the ring R[X]_{S} is Jacobson-Hilbert, where S is the set of monic polynomials of the polynomial ring R[X].

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The proof loc.cit., is long and non-trivial. In a note added in the proof, the authors state that “an elegant yet elementary proof” was sent to them by J.T. Stafford.

statement.label: 9.25C. Remark.
statement.p: If R is not Noetherian, then R[X]_{S} need not be Jacobson-Hilbert, even when R is. This, and the counter-example, is pointed out, loc.cit., p.208.

sec.title: Rings with Krull Domain Centers: Bergman and Cohn Theorems

statement.label: 9.26A. Theorem
statement.p: Any right Noetherian right hereditary ring R is a finite product of indecomposable rings each having a Krull domain as center.

statement.label: 9.26B. Remark.
statement.p: Small and Wadsworth [81] show that the centers in Bergman’s theorem need not be Noetherian even for a PI-ring R.

statement.label: 9.26C. Theorem
statement.p: Any Krull domain R is isomorphic to the center of some right and left principal ideal domain.

statement.label: 9.26D. Remark.
statement.p: Herbera and Menal [89] pointed out that this provided new examples showing that the center of an FPF ring need not be FPF.

statement.label: 9.26E. Theorem
statement.p: Any commutative Krull domain A arises as the center of a right hereditary right Noetherian PI-ring,

statement.label: 9.26F. Remark.
statement.p: The example has the form
where B is a PID with quotient field k(X), the field of rational functions in the variable X over k=Q(A), the quotient field of A, such that B\cap k=A.

sec.title: The Maximal Quotient Ring of a Commutative Ring
sec.p: Let R be a commutative ring, with quotient ring Q(R). An ideal I of R is dense if I is faithful, i.e., I^{\perp }=0.

Let J_{1} and J_{2} be (finitely generated) dense ideals of R and let f_{1}\in \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(J_{1},R) and f_{2}\in \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(J_{2},R). Then J_{1}J_{2} is a (finitely generated) dense ideal so that we may define both f_{1}+f_{2} and f_{1}f_{2} as homomorphisms on J_{2}J_{2}. Define f_{1} and f_{2} to be equivalent if they agree on a dense ideal of J of R. From Lambek [66] (13, Lemma 1, p.38) one sees that f_{1} and f_{2} agree on a dense ideal J if and only if they agree on J_{1}\cap J_{2} and hence if and only if they agree on J_{1}J_{2}. The elements of the maximal quotient ring Q_{\max }(R) are defined to be equivalence classes of the homomorphisms \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(J,R) for dense ideals J. (Cf. §12 for the maximal quotient rings of noncommutative R, which may be constructed as equivalence classes of homomorphisms defined via “dense” right ideals J.)
Since J=xR is dense for each regular element x\in R, then one sees that canonically
Furthermore, if E=E(R) is the injective hull of R, and S=\mathrm{End}E_{R}, then Q_{2}= Q_{\max }(R) can be identified with
(Lambek [63]), and also
(Findlay-Lambek [58]. See Lambek [66], and also §12, sup. 12.A).

statement.label: 9.27. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) If R is Kasch, then R is the only dense ideal, hence R= Q_{\max }(R) in this case; (2) As an exercise in Noetherian ideal theory, one shows that Q(R) is Kasch for a Noetherian (more generally any acc\perp ) commutative ring R hence Q(R)=Q_{\max }(R) in this case (see 16.31).

sec.title: The Ring of Finite Fractions
sec.p: If we restrict the above construction for Q_{\max }(R) to homomorphisms f\in \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(J,R) for f\cdot g dense ideals J, then we obtain the ring Q_{0}(R) of finite fractions of R, and
canonically.

The name “ring of finite fractions” comes from the fact that each element of Q_{0}(R) can be identified with an element of Q(R[X]), the classical quotient ring of the polynomial ring R[X]. For f\in Q_{0}(R) let J=(b_{0},\ldots ,b_{n}) be a dense ideal of R such that f\in \mathrm{Hom}(J,R). Let b(X)=b_{n}X^{n}+\cdots +b_{n} and a(X)= a_{n}X^{n}+\cdots +a_{0}, where f(b_{i})=a_{i} for each i. Then since b_{j}f(b_{i})=f(b_{j}b_{i})=b_{i}f(b_{j}), [a(X)/b(X)]b_{i}=a_{i} for each i. Whence f can be identified with multiplication by a(X)/b(X). Since J is dense, b(X) is a regular element of R[X]. Even though b(X) is a regular element of R[X],\,J need not contain a regular element of R. When J does contain a regular element r of R, then f ‘reduces’ to the element s/r\in Q(R) where fr=s. For integral domains and Noetherian rings such a reduction always occurs since in both cases an ideal either has a nonzero annihilator or contains a regular element. However, there are many examples where Q_{0}(R) properly contains Q(R) (see, for example, Lucas [93]).

An ideal I of R is said to be regular if it contains a regular element and semiregular if it contains a finitely generated dense ideal. If the only semi-regular ideals of R are the regular ones, then R is McCoy, in which case b(X)=b_{n}X^{n}+\cdots +b_{0}\in R[X] is regular if and only if c(b)=(b_{0},\ldots ,b_{n}) is a regular ideal of R. This establishes the following:

statement.label: 9.28. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative McCoy ring, then the ring Q_{0}(R) of finite fractions coincides with the quotient ring Q(R).

sec.p: The converse is false (Lucas [93]).

sec.title: Prüfer Rings and the Davis, Griffin and Eggert Theorems
sec.p: An ideal I of a commutative ring R is invertible (in Q(R)) if IK=R for an R-submodule K of Q(R). This implies, e.g., that I is f\cdot g projective. An integral domain R is Prüfer iff R is semihereditary. (N.B.) Cf. 9.33.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: Let R be commutative.

def.p: By definition, R is semihereditary iff every f\cdot g ideal of R is projective. This is equivalent to the condition that R is locally a valuation domain (=VD), i.e., R_{m} is a VD for each maximal ideal m of R. Thus a domain R is Prüfer iff R is locally a VD.
An ideal I\neq 0 in a domain R is invertible iff I is f\cdot g projective.
A domain R is Prüfer iff each 2-generated ideal is invertible. (See, e.g., Gilmer [72], theorem 22.1).
Every ideal of a Dedekind domain is 2-generated, i.e., requires no more than two generators.
Schulting [79] constructed an example of a Prüfer domain R with an ideal requiring 3 generators. See Fontana et al [97], p.17ff, for a proof.

sec.p: A commutative ring R is Prüfer (Griffin [69]) if every f\cdot g regular ideal is invertible. An overring of R is a subring of Q(R) that contains R. A Dedekind ring R is a Noetherian Prüfer ring,

statement.label: Examples.
statement.p: (1) Any valuation ring R is Prüfer since if I is a f\cdot g regular ideal, then I=(a) for a regular element a of R, hence is invertible. (2) Any quotient ring R=Q(R) is Prüfer since any regular element is a unit, i.e., R is the only regular ideal. Thus every commutative ring R is contained in a Prüfer ring, namely Q(R).

sec.p: A discrete valuation domain (= DVD) is a Noetherian valuation domain. Any Noetherian valuation ring is a Dedekind ring, and is a principal ideal ring. (Cf. Hinohara’s theorem stated 6.3Af.)

statement.label: 9.29. Theorem
statement.p: An integral domain R is Prüfer iff every overring of R is integrally closed.

statement.label: 9.29B. Theorem
statement.p: An integral domain R is Prüfer iff every overring is flat (cf. 12.3).

statement.label: 9.30. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is Prüfer iff every overring of R is integrally closed.

sec.p: A commutative ring R is an I-ring if every subring of Q_{\max }(R) containing R is integrally closed.

statement.label: 9.31. Theorem
statement.p: A reduced ring R is an I-ring iff R is Prüfer and Q(R)=Q_{\max }(R).

statement.label: 9.32. Corollary.
statement.p: A reduced ring R is an I-ring iff R is semihereditary.

statement.label: 9.33. Theorem
statement.title: (Griffin [70]–[74]).
statement.p: A commutative ring R is semihereditary iff R is Prüfer and Q(R) is VNR. Every integrally closed subring R in a VNR quotient ring Q(R) is the intersection of semihereditary Manis valuation rings.

statement.label: 9.34A. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is FPF iff R is Prüfer and has self-injective quotient ring Q(R).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This is an easy consequence of the FPF Theorem 5.42 and the fact that f\cdot g faithful projective modules over R are invertibe, and conversely invertible ideals are f\cdot g projective generators.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Also see Faith-Pillay [90], p.46, Corollary 2.23.

statement.label: 9.34B. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative reduced ring R is FPF iff R is semihereditary and Q(R) is self-injective. Any Manis valuation ring R with VNR ring Q(R) is FPF.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: For connections between FPF and Prüfer noncommutative rings, see e.g. the author’s [77b,82b], and [84] (with Page).

sec.title: Strong Prüfer Rings
sec.p: A ring R is a strong Prüfer ring if every f\cdot g semiregular ideal is locally principal. A f\cdot g regular ideal is invertible iff it is locally principal, hence any McCoy Prüfer ring R is strong.

statement.label: 9.35. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is a strong Prüfer ring iff the ring Q_{0}(R) of finite fractions of R is McCoy and every ring between R and Q_{0}(R) is integrally closed in Q_{0}(R).

sec.title: Discrete Prüfer Domains
sec.p: A Prüfer domain R is discrete if every primary ideal of R is a power of its radical (Gilmer [72], p.295.) Moreover, a domain R is discrete iff R_{M} is a generalized discrete valuation domain for each m\in mspec R (op.cit.), that is H_{1}/H_{2}\approx \mathbb{Z} for any two consecutive groups H_{1} and H_{2} of the value group of R_{m}\,\forall m\in mspec R (op.cit., p.205), where mspec R is the set of maximal ideals.

sec.title: Strongly Discrete Domains
sec.p: A Prüfer domain is strongly discrete (=SD) if P\neq P^{2} for every prime ideal P\neq 0 (Popescu [84]). Moreover (op.cit.) a Prüfer domain R is SD iff R is Discrete and satisfies \mathrm{acc}P(= acc on prime ideals). Furthermore this, too, is a local property by Fontana-Popescu [95].

sec.title: Generalized Dedekind Rings
sec.p: An integral domain R is generalized Dedekind (= GD) iff R is SD and every prime ideal P is the radical of a finitely generated ideal (Popescu [84]), Theorem 2.5); equivalently, R is (i) locally a generalized discrete valuation domain; (ii) R has accP; and (iii) min spec R/I is finite for every ideal I.

sec.title: Facchini’s Theorems on Piecewise Noetherian Rings
sec.p: A commutative ring R is piecewise Noetherian (= PWN) iff R satisfies: (i) R has accP; (ii) R has acc on P-primary ideals for each prime ideal P; and (iii) minspecR/I is finite for every ideal I.

statement.label: 9.36. Theorem
statement.p: A Prüfer domain R is GD iff R is PWN. Furthermore, any Prüfer domain with Krull dimension is GD.

sec.p: See op.cit. 3.1 and 3.2.

statement.label: 9.37. Theorem
statement.title: (Facchini [94], p.163, sup. Prop.2.3).
statement.p: For a Prüfer domain R, the canonical correspondence P\rightarrow E(R/P) is 1-1 between prime ideals and isomorphism classes of indecomposable injectives iff R is strongly discrete.

sec.title: Weakley’s Theorems on Terse Modules
sec.p: An R-module M is said to be terse provided that any two distinct submodules are non-isomorphic, or equivalently (Weakley [87], Lemma 2), iff distinct cyclic submodules are non-isomorphic.

statement.label: 9.38. Example
statement.p: An Abelian group G is terse iff G embeds in \mathbb{Q}/\mathbb{Z}. Cf. Corollary 9.45 below.

statement.label: 9.39. Theorem.
statement.p: (Weakley [87, Prop.4]). If R is commutative, and if an R-module M localizes to a terse R_{m}-module for all maximal ideals m, then M is terse.

statement.label: 9.40. Remark.
statement.p: The converse fails by Example 7 of Weakley (ibid.) of a terse module over a Boolean ring R, where R is the subring of T=(\mathbb{Z}_{2})^{\omega } generated by the direct sum of \aleph _{0} copies of \mathbb{Z}_{2} and 1.

statement.label: 9.41. Theorem
statement.p: Any cyclic module over a commutative VNR ring R is terse.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This follows from Theorem 9.39. If R/I is cyclic, then R/I is a VNR ring, so it suffices to show that R is a terse R-module. But, by Kaplansky’s Theorem 3.19B, every local ring R_{m} of R is a field, hence terse, so Theorem 9.39 applies.

statement.label: 9.42. Theorem
statement.p: A uniform quasi-injective module M over a commutative ring R is terse iff every submodule of M is quasi-injective, equivalently for every x\in M, the ring R/x^{\perp } is self-injective, where x^{\perp }=ann_{R}x.

statement.label: 9.43. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative Noetherian ring then an R module M is terse iff M embeds in the minimal injective cogenerator E of R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This is Theorem 10, ibid, where E is called the universal injective R-module, namely, the direct sum E=\sum \nolimits _{\alpha }E(R/m_{\alpha }), where m_{\alpha } ranges over all maximal ideals. Note that R Noetherian implies E is injective. See Theorem 3.4B and Minimal Cogenerators preceding.

def.p: By an example of Osofsky [91], minimal cogenerators even over commutative rings need not be isomorphic, hence not terse.
The minimal injective cogenerator E over the ring R in Weakley’s Example 7 referred to in Remark 9.40 is not terse.

statement.label: 9.45. Corollary
statement.title: (Weakley [87], Corollary 11).
statement.p: If R is a Dedekind domain, then an R module M is terse iff M embeds in E=Q(R)/R, where Q(R) is the quotient field of R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: For E is the minimal injective cogenerator of R.

statement.label: 9.46. Remark.
statement.p: Weakley (ibid) characterizes Dedekind domains among Noetherian domains R by the equivalent properties:

def.p: Every finitely generated terse R-module is cyclic;
Every factor module of a terse R-module is terse.

sec.title: Anderson and Camillo on Armendariz and Gaussian Rings
sec.p: We start with some definitions.

def.p: The content C(f) of a polynomial f over a ring R is the ideal generated by the coefficients of f.
A ring R is Gaussian provided that C(fg)=C(f)C(g) for any two polynomials f and g over R.
A ring R is an Armendariz ring provided that a product of polynomials fg=0 implies that C(f)C(g)=0, i.e. that ab=0 for any coefficient a of f and b of g.

statement.label: 9.48. Remark.
statement.p: Obviously any Gaussian ring is Armendariz. Terminology (2) is due to Tsang [65], while that of (3) was coined by Rege and Chhawchharia [97] and inspired by the following theorem.

statement.label: 9.49. Theorem
statement.p: Any (commutative or non-commutative) reduced ring R is an Armendariz ring.

statement.label: 9.50. Theorem
statement.p: A not necessarily commutative ring R is Armendariz iff the contraction I\rightarrow I\cap R[X] is a bijection between annihilator ideals of R[X] and those of R.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: Anderson and Camillo [98], p.2269, point out that Theorem 9.49 was known for commutative R. On p.2268, they also point out the following:

statement.label: 9.51. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative domain R is Gaussian iff R is a Prüfer domain.

sec.p: PROOF, Loc. cit., or Gilmer [72], 28.5 and 28.6.

statement.label: 9.52. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a ring. Then:

def.p: R is Armendariz iff C(f_{1}f_{2}\cdots f_{n})=0 implies C(f_{i})C(f_{j})=0 for all polynomials f_{1},f_{2},\ldots ,f_{n} over R.
A ring R is Armendariz iff the polynomial ring R[X] is Armendariz.
If R is Armendariz, then so is any subring of the polynomial ring R[X] in any set X of commuting variables X over R.

statement.label: 9.53. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is Gaussian iff every factor ring of R is Armendariz.

statement.label: 9.54. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative Armendariz (Gaussian) ring, then so is every overring S between R and Q_{cl}(R).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This also holds for non-commutative R having a right quotient ring. See Huh et al [02].

statement.label: 9.55. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R is Armendariz iff the local ring at each maximal ideal of R is Armendariz.

statement.label: 9.56. Corollary.
statement.p: Any Arithmetic ring R is Armendariz.

sec.p: Cf. Theorem 9.51.

statement.label: 9.57. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative ring, then the polynomial R[X] is Gaussian iff R is von Neumann regular (VNR).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See Huh, Lee, and Smoktunowitz [02] for a number of additional results on non-commutative VNR rings, and reduced rings.

sec.title: Maximal Prime Ideals of Zero Divisors
sec.p: Let \mathcal{Z}(R)=zd(R) denote the set of zero divisors of a commutative ring R, and let Q=Q_{cl}(R) be the classical quotient ring. Any regular element q of Q is a unit, and any zero divisor is contained in a maximal ideal. (By an application of Zorn’s since qQ\neq Q, then q is contained in a maximal ideal.) Moreover, any maximal ideal of Q consists of zero divisors, hence contained in \mathcal{Z}(Q). This establishes that \mathcal{Z}(Q) is the union of maximal ideals, hence \mathcal{Z}(R) is a union of prime ideals.
