Since a union of a chain of prime ideals is a prime ideal, any prime ideal of \mathcal{Z}(R) is contained in a maximal prime ideal of \mathcal{Z}(R), called a maximal prime ideal of zero divisors. Thus, the set \mathcal{Z}(R) is the union of maximal prime ideals of zero divisors. Moreover:

statement.label: 9.58. Proposition.
statement.p: Let S denote the set of regular elements of a commutative ring R, and Q=Q_{cl}(R)=RS^{-1}. Then contraction defines a bijection \phi between the set \max Q of maximal ideals of Q, and the set \mathcal{P}(R) of maximal prime ideals of zero divisors of R. Furthermore, if P\in (R), then \phi ^{-1}(P)=PS^{-1} and Q_{cl}(R_{P}) is Q localized at \phi (P).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Exercise.
Corollary to Theorem 9.55. A commutative ring R is Armendariz iff the local ring of R at each maximal prime ideal of zero divisors is Armendariz.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This follows from Theorems 9.54–9.55, and Prop. 9.58.

statement.label: 9.60. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative, then the power series ring R[[X]] is Gaussian iff R is VNR and \aleph _{0}-algebraically compact (and iff R[[X]] is Bezout.)

sec.p: Cf. Theorem 6.14.

statement.label: 9.61. Theorem.
statement.p: If R is a commutative ring satisfying the acc on annihilator ideals (=acc\perp ), then Q=Q_{cl}(R) is a semilocal Kasch ring, hence R has just finitely many maximal primes of zero, and each is an associated prime ideal.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Proposition 9.58, Theorem 16.31.

def.p: If R is commutative and an R-module M has finite Goldie dimension d, then |\mathrm{Ass}\,M|\leq d by Corollary 16.18.
Also see Theorem 16.11B for the case M is a f\cdot g module over a commutative Noetherian ring R.
Also see Kaplansky [74], Theorems 80–85 for related theorems.

sec.label: Chapter 10
sec.title: Isomorphic Polynomial Rings and Matrix Rings
sec.p: Let R and S denote rings. Following Brewer and Rutter [72], one says that R is n-invariant if an isomorphism

of the polynomial rings in n-variables implies an isomorphism of R and S. If \sigma (R)=S, for any isomorphism \sigma , then R is strongly n-invariant. If R is (strongly) n-invariant for all n, then R is (strongly) invariant (e.g. \mathbb{Z} is strongly invariant).

sec.title: Hochster’s Example of a Non-unique Coefficient Ring

statement.label: 10.1. Theorem
statement.p: Not every commutative integral domain R is 1-invariant.

sec.p: The example is given by Hochster [72] who states that Murthy discovered a “similar example (unpublished).”

sec.title: Brewer-Rutter Theorems

statement.label: 10.2. Theorem
statement.p: If the center A of R has Krull dimension 0 (equivalently A/N(A) is a VNR ring) then R is invariant.

statement.label: 10.3. Corollary
statement.p: If R is a VNR ring, then R is invariant.

sec.p: The proof of the theorem uses a lemma that states that if R is commutative, and \sigma (R)\subseteq S then \sigma (R)=S (Lemma 2, loc. cit.). In general, if A/N(A) is strongly n-invariant, where A is the center of R, then R is n-invariant (loc. cit.) (Theorem 1, loc.cit.). Thus, the proof of the theorem reduces to the case where R is a commutative VNR.

statement.label: 10.4. Theorem
statement.p: If the center of R is a finite product of local rings, then R is invariant.

sec.title: The Theorems of Abhyankar, Heinzer and Eakin

statement.label: 10.5. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a domain of transcendence degree 1 over a field k, then A is invariant, and strongly invariant unless A is the polynomial ring k[X].

sec.p: If A=k[X], and B=k[Y], then A[Y]=B[X] for a variable Y, but the identity isomorphism does not carry A onto B, so A is not strongly invariant.

statement.label: 10.6. Example
statement.p: There exists an integral domain R such that R is strongly invariant; R[X] is invariant but not strongly invariant and R[X,Y] is not invariant.

statement.label: 10.7. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a not strongly invariant Dedekind domain, then there exists s\neq 0 in A so that A[1/s]\approx k[X] for some field k and variable X. Furthermore if A contains \mathbb{Q}, then A\approx k_{0}[Y] for some field k_{0} and variable Y.

statement.label: 10.8. Remark.
statement.p: Hochster’s examples in 10.1 are locally polynomial rings (see Eakin and Silver [72]; Cf. Eakin and Heinzer [73]).

sec.title: Isomorphic Matrix Rings
sec.p: Let n be an integer \geq 2. A ring R is said to have n-matrix cancellation provided that whenever R_{n}\approx S_{n} for a ring S, then R\approx S. Then R is said to be n-cancellable. If this holds for all n\geq 2, then R has matrix cancellation. According to Lam [98c], §8B, Cohn[66] gave the first example of a ring R that is not 2-cancellable. The construction is given by Lam, ibid., of a domain R with R^{2}\approx R^{4}. Thus, R^{2} fails to have a unique basis number. Moreover
yet R\not \approx R_{2}, since R is a domain (see Cohn, ibid.).

sec.title: Lam’s Survey
sec.p: Lam [95] cites a number of classes of matrix cancellable rings:

def.p: R commutative
R right Artinian
R is a right and left self-injective ring (Gentile [67]).

sec.p: Moreover, Lam [98c] cites:

def.p: R is a right self-injective VNR (Goodearl and Boyle)
R is semilocal
R is VNR of bounded index

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: The proofs of (5) and (6) depend on “(weak) cancellation” of f\cdot g projective modules (cancellation of f\cdot g projective modules implies the latter, ibid.).

sec.title: Three-Element Recognition of Matrix Rings
sec.p: As remarked at the beginning of Chapter 2, an endomorphism ring A=\mathrm{End}M_{R} of a right R-module is an n\times n matrix ring over a ring B when M\approx N^{n} for a right R-module N with B=\mathrm{End}N_{R}. Applied to M=R, one sees that if R is a direct sum of n isomorphic right ideals N, then R\approx B_{n}, where B\approx \mathrm{End}N_{R}. We now state a theorem that simplifies the recognition of matrix rings by a criterion involving just three elements of R.

statement.label: Theorem
statement.title: (Agnarson, Amitsur And Robson [96].).
statement.p: A ring R is a full n\times n matrix ring iff there exist three elements a,\,b and f in R such that f^{n}=0 and

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: If \{e_{ij}\} is a complete set of matrix units for R, then a=e_{1n},b=e_{12}+\cdots +e_{n,n-1}, and f=e_{21}+\cdots +e_{n,n-1} suffice. One verifies f^{n-1}=e_{n1},\,f^{n}=0, and (\star ) holds. Furthermore, R is a direct sum of the isomorphic right ideals generated by f^{i}af^{n-1},\,i=0,\ldots \,,n-1.
Conversely given (\star ), then the set
is a full set of n\times n matrix units in R (the proof is ingenious, and this paper is a joy to read.)

sec.p: A companion theorem is more symmetric in a and b.

statement.label: Theorem
statement.title: (Ibid.).
statement.p: For positive integers m and n we have that R is a full m+n-matrix ring iff there exist three elements a,\,b, and f in R such that f^{m+n}=0 and af^{m}+f^{n}b=1.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Also see Chatters [89, 92], Levy, Robson and Stafford [94] and Robson [91].

sec.label: Chapter 11
sec.title: Group Rings and Maschke’s Theorem Revisited
sec.p: In this chapter we revisit Maschke’s theorem, generalized in 11.10. The next theorem generalized the classical theorem that a group algebra kG of a finite group G over a field k is QF (see 11.4).

sec.title: Connell’s Theorems on Self-injective Group Rings

statement.label: 11.1. Theorem
statement.p: If G is finite, then the group ring AG over a ring A is right self-injective (= SI) iff A is right SI.

sec.p: Moreover:

statement.label: 11.2. Theorem
statement.title: (Connell [63], Farkas [73], Renault [70], Jain).
statement.p: If a group ring AG is right SI, then G is finite (and A is SI.)

sec.p: Note. In 11.2, then A is right SI by 11.1.

statement.label: 11.3. Theorem
statement.p: A group ring AG is right Artinian iff A is right Artinian and G is finite.

statement.label: 11.4. Corollary.
statement.p: A group ring AG is QF iff A is QF and G is finite. Thus, any group algebra kG of a finite group over a field k is QF.

statement.label: 11.5. Theorem.
statement.p: A group ring AG is right PF iff G is finite and A is right PF.

sec.p: This theorem follows from 11.1, 11.2 and a theorem of Louden [76].

statement.label: 11.6. Theorem
statement.p: A group ring AG is right perfect iff G is finite and A is right perfect.

statement.label: 11.7A. Theorem
statement.p: If a group algebra RG is semilocal, and k properly contains the algebraic closure of \mathbb{Z}_{p}, then G is a finite extension of a p-group.

statement.label: 11.7B. Theorem
statement.p: If k is a field of characteristic 0, then kG is semilocal only if G is finite.

statement.label: 11.8. Theorem
statement.p: A group ring RG is right pure-injective iff R is right pure-injective and G is finite.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: If R is left linearly compact (= l.l.c.) and G is finite, then RG is l.l.c. as an R-module, hence a l.l.c. ring. Conversely, if RG is l.l.c, then RG is right pure-injective (r.p.i.) by Zimmermann’s theorem 6.D^{\prime }, so G is finite and R is r.p.i. by 11.8.

sec.title: Von Neumann Regular Group Rings
sec.p: The orbit of a group is the set of orders of its elements.

statement.label: 11.9. Theorem
statement.title: (Auslander [57] - McLaughlin [58] - Connell [63]).
statement.p: A group ring AG is VNR iff A is VNR,\,G is locally finite and every n in the orbit of G is a unit of A.

statement.label: 11.9^{\prime }
statement.p: There exists a prime VNR group algebra kG over an arbitrary field k which is not primitive.

sec.p: The next corollary characterizes semisimple group rings:

statement.label: 11.10. Corollary
statement.p: A group ring AG is semisimple iff G is a finite group of unit order in A, and A is a semisimple ring.

sec.p: For when AG is a V-ring, see e.g. Hartley [77].

statement.label: 11.10B. Theorem
statement.p: A group ring RG is prime iff R is prime and G has no finite normal subgroups \neq 1.

sec.title: Jacobson’s Problem on Group Algebras
sec.p: If R=kG is a group algebra over a field k of characteristic 0, is the Jacobson radical \mathrm{rad}R=0? Amitsur’s theorem was reported on in Jacobson’s book [64], also see my book, vol. II, p. 260–265: the answer is “yes” if k is not algebraic over \mathbb{Q}, e.g. if k is non-denumerable. A large number of theorems state a positive result under various assumptions on G, e.g. for any ordered group, hence any Abelian group (Theorem of B. H. Neumann [49]. Cf. Amitsur [59], and Ribenboim [69], Theorems 23 and 24, p. 153ff).

sec.title: Isomorphism of Group Algebras: The Perlis-Walker Theorem
sec.p: If G and H are Abelian groups of the same finite order n over an algebraically closed field k of characteristic 0, then by Maschke’s theorem,

are isomorphic even though G and H need not be. Thus, the group algebra kG of a finite Abelian group G over the field k does not determine the group. The beauty of the following Perlis-Walker theorem is that the rational group algebra \mathbb{Q}G does determine G.

statement.label: 11.11. Theorem
statement.p: If G and H are finite Abelian groups such that \mathbb{Q}G\approx \mathbb{Q}H, then G\approx H.

sec.p: See e.g. Passman [77], Theorem 1.2, p. 645.

sec.title: Dade’s Examples
sec.p: Dade [71] showed that there exist two non-isomorphic metabelian groups G and H such that kG\approx kH for every field k. As Dade (loc.cit.) remarks, the Whitcomb-Jackson theorem (see below) implies \mathbb{Z}G\not \approx \mathbb{Z}H for the groups in his example (see Passmann [77], p. 661. Also see Passman’s theorem on p. 658).

sec.title: Higman’s Problem
sec.p: A problem posed by Graham Higman in 1940 and later by Richard Brauer in 1963 (see Roggenkamp and Scott [87]): Does the integral group ring \mathbb{Z}G determine the group G? That is, if G and H are groups, does the following hold:

Hertzweck [01] showed the answer is negative in general. A. Whitcomb in 1967 (U. of Chicago Ph.D. thesis) and D. A. Jackson in 1969 independently verified HC assuming that one of the two groups is metabelian (= has Abelian derived group). See Passman [77], p.669. Roggenkamp and Scott [87] verified HC for: (1) finite p-groups G over \mathbb{Z} or \hat{\mathbb{Z}}_{(p)} (the ring of p-adic integers); (2) for nilpotent groups G.

sec.title: Theorems of Higman, Kasch-Kupisch-Kneser on Groups Rings of Finite Module Type
sec.p: A group ring kG of a finite group G over a field k is semisimple iff the characteristic p of k does not divide n=|G| (theorem of Maschke–see 11.10). When p\,|\,n, then a theorem of D.G. Higman [54] states that kG has finite representation type (= FFM) iff the p-subgroups of G are cyclic. Since the p-Sylow subgroups are conjugate, this holds iff G has a cyclic p-Sylow subgroup P. In this case, Higman found a bound b(n) on the number of isomorphism classes of indecomposable finitely generated modules independent of G, and Kasch-Kneser-Kupisch [57] sharpened this by showing that b(n)=n is an upper bound, and that b(n)=n iff G\triangleright P and G/P is Abelian of exponent m, and k contains all of the m^{\mathrm{th}} roots of unity. Janusz [69] constructed all of the indecomposable modules, and also showed that whenever kG is FFM, then every indecomposable module has squarefree socle.

sec.title: Janusz and Srinivasan Theorems
sec.p: Prime examples of FFM rings are serial rings. Janusz [69] characterized when kG is serial assuming that k is a splitting field for G. This happens iff the p-Sylow subgroup of G is cyclic, and every simple kG module F is the tensor k\otimes F^{\star }, for some R-module F^{\star }, where R is a complete local domain of characteristic 0 with residue field \approx k. (Cf. Srinivasan [60] who showed that every indecomposable module embeds in kG when G is p-solvable with cyclic p-Sylow subgroup. Also see Janusz [70,72a].)

sec.title: Morita’s Theorem
sec.p: Morita [56] determined necessary and sufficient conditions for the radical J of a left Artinian ring R to be a principal left, and a principal right, ideal J=Ra= bR. To wit: R is serial and quasi-primary-decomposable in the sense that R is a finite product of rings whose principal indecomposable left ideals have the same “multiplicity”. Let G be a finite group with p-Sylow subgroup P, and let H be the largest normal subgroup with order prime to p. Then the group algebra kG over an algebraically closed field k of characteristic p has the stated property iff HP is a normal subgroup of G and P is cyclic.

sec.title: Roseblade’s Theorems on Polycyclic-by-Finite Group Rings
sec.p: One of the most famous problems on group rings is the zero divisor question: if G is torsionfree, is KG an integral domain when K is? Yes, if G is supersolvable (Formanek), a result generalized by D. Farkas and R. Snider to G polycyclic-by-finite. (There is a vast literature on this subject–see Passman [77].)
A capital of a ring R is a factor ring R/A where A is a maximal ideal. (If R is commutative then R/A is a field.) A field K is absolute if K has prime characteristic and K is absolutely algebraic.

statement.label: 11.12. Theorem
statement.p: If K is any absolute field and G is polycyclic-by-finite, then any simple KG module is finite dimensional over K.

sec.title: A Weak Nullstellensatz

statement.label: 11.13. Remark.
statement.p: The “weak Nullstellensatz” states that every simple R-module of a polynomial ring R=K[x_{1},\ldots \,,x_{n}] over a field K is finite dimensional over K, so as Roseblade suggests (loc.cit., p.309) 11.12 is a weak Nullstellensatz for KG.

sec.p: This generalized a theorem of P. Hall for finitely generated nilpotent G. Moreover, by the work of Hall cited by Roseblade (loc.cit.), this implies that the simple modules of the integral group ring \mathbb{Z}G are all finite (Cf. Jategaonkar [74b] who proves residual nilpotence of the augmentation ideal.) Furthermore:

sec.title: Hilbert Group Rings

statement.label: 11.14. Corollary
statement.p: If R is any commutative Noetherian Hilbert ring all of whose capitals are absolute and if G is polycyclic-by-finite, then any simple RG module is finite dimensional over a capital of R.

sec.p: Roseblade also proved, for any ring R, that RG is a Noetherian Hilbert ring iff R is, generalizing various forms of the Hilbert Nullstellensatz (see Roseblade, loc.cit., p. 309).

sec.title: Classical Quotient Rings of Group Rings
sec.p: Among the myriad results on classical right quotient rings of groups rings, we cite:

statement.label: 11.15. Theorem
statement.p: If K is a field, and if a group ring R=KG has a classical quotient ring Q, then the quotient ring of the center of R is the center of Q.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This generalized a result of M. Smith and of Passman [71], p.27.

def.p: If a ring A has right Artinian classical right quotient ring, and if G is a polycyclic or polyfinite group, then R=AG has right Artinian classical right quotient ring Q.

If A is a commutative Noetherian ring, and G as in (1), then R=AG has semilocal Noetherian classical quotient ring Q that embeds in a right and left Artinian ring, and J=\mathit{rad}\,Q has the Artin-Rees property.

sec.label: Chapter 12
sec.title: Maximal Quotient Rings
sec.p:
A ring R is right nonsingular (= n.s.) if every essential right ideal I has zero left annihilator.⁠11
Many topics treated in §12 have been taken up in earlier chapters. Please consult the index. Nonsingular rings (but not the terminology) were introduced by R. E. Johnson in the early 1950’s (see below). The most important examples are (1) simple rings (with identity); (2) semihereditary rings (e.g. von Neumann regular ring); (3) commutative rings without nilpotent elements \neq 0; (4) integral domains (commutative or not, e.g. free algebras over a field), and (5) Goldie semiprime rings. The latter rings, by the theorems of A. W. Goldie and L. Lesieur-R. Croisot include: (5a) any right order in a semisimple Artinian ring, e.g. (5b) any semiprime (or prime) right Noetherian ring (see 3.13).
A remarkable fact about nonsingular rings is that these rings R are essential subrings of self-injective von Neumann regular rings.

The right singular ideal sing R of a ring R consists of all elements x\in R such that the right annihilator x^{\perp } is essential in R in the sense that x^{\perp }\cap I\neq 0 for all right ideals I\neq 0. This is a 2-sided ideal, and the left singular ideal may not equal the right singular ideal. The ring R is right nonsingular (n.s.) if sing R=0. (These are Johnson’s J_{r}=0, or J-rings.) A commutative ring R is n.s. if and only if R has no nilpotent elements except 0 ( = R is reduced). When R satisfies the acc on right annihilators (= \mathrm{acc}^{\perp }), or more generally, the acc on the set \{x^{\perp }|x\in \mathrm{sing}R\}, then sing R is nil (see 16.38), hence is contained in the Jacobson radical rad R. (From this one easily deduces that semiprime right Goldie rings are right non-singular.) Furthermore, if R is right self-injective (= the canonical right R-module R is injective), then Y. Utumi [56] proved that sing R coincides with the Jacobson radical and that R/\mathrm{sing}\, R is von Neumann regular, hence n.s. In 1964 Osofsky [Canad. J. Math. 20 (1968), 405–413] constructed the first semiprimitive ring R which is not n.s.; thus, sing R is not always contained in rad R. In 1974 J. Lawrence constructed a primitive ring R=\mathrm{sing}\,R and indicated that Osofsky’s original example was also primitive.

The complexity, depth, and extent of the structure theory of R. E. Johnson’s n.s. rings rivals, but naturally is unimaginable without, N. Jacobson’s structure theory of primitive and semiprimitive rings published in the mid-forties, and in N. Jacobson’s colloquium volume [56, 64]. The main point of similarity is between Johnson’s n.s. prime rings R with uniform right ideal U, and Jacobson’s primitive rings with linear transformations (l.t.’s) of finite rank. To wit, a theorem of Utumi (loc.cit.) states that the maximal right quotient ring \hat{R} of R is the full ring of l.t.’s of E(U) as a vector space over \Delta =\mathrm{End}_{R}E(U); and more to the point is Johnson’s transitivity theorem which generalizes the Chevalley-Jacobson density theorem (roughly) as follows: if x_{1},\ldots \,,x_{n}\in U are linearly independent over D=\mathrm{End}_{R}U, and if y_{1},\ldots \,,y_{n}\in U, then there exists k\in D,\,r\in R such that kx_{i}=y_{i}r,\,i=1,\ldots \,,n. In 1951 Johnson proved this under the added assumption of a uniform left ideal V\neq 0, and for D=VU \subset U\cap V. This theorem has now been put into a completely module-theoretic setting by J. Zelmanowitz [76-77] in a theorem which makes the analogy explicit, since it implies both Chevalley-Jacobson’s and Johnson’s theorems. An important ingredient of the proof of the transitivity-density and Zelmanowitz theorems (the latter not incidentally yielded a proof of Goldie’s theorem and the Faith-Utumi theorem simultaneously) is the Jacobson and Johnson-Wong double annihilator condition (d.a.c.) for quasi-injective M; namely, \mathrm{ann}_{M}\mathrm{ann}_{A}S=RS=\Sigma _{i=1}^{n}\,Rx_{i} for any finite subset S=\{x_{1},\ldots \,,x_{n}\} of M (see Prop. 3.8). This is the basis for the Johnson transitivity theorem, and the Johnson-Wong transitivity theorems which imply the Chevalley-Jacobson density theorem. Cf. also “weak primitivity” in Zelmanowitz [81] and [84].

The most significant and imaginative departure from the Jacobson structure theory is Johnson’s concept of the maximal quotient ring of an n.s. ring. In modern terminology, the injective hull E=E(R) of a right nonsingular R is a right self-injective von Neumann regular ring \hat{R} containing R as a subring, called the maximal right quotient ring of R. (In Johnson’s early papers, some of these concepts were not available.) That \hat{R} is right self-injective was proved by Johnson and Wong only in 1959, or several years after Utumi [op.cit., 1956] generalized Johnson’s concept of the maximal quotient ring of an n.s. ring to construct the maximal right quotient ring Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R) of any ring R (see below), containing the classical right quotient ring Q_{cl}^{r}(R) in the event R is a right Ore ring. As stated, the nice aspect of the Johnson theory is that any right n.s. R can be embedded as an essential R-submodule into a von Neumann regular (and right self-injective) ring. In honor of this fact, these rings were awarded various appellations such as “nice” or “neat”, but nonsingular seems to have won out.
We restate the:

statement.label: 12A.
statement.p:
Johnson-Wong Theorem [59]. The injective hull E=E(R) of a right nonsingular ring R is a right self-injective VNR ring containing R as a subring.⁠22
A change in the format, the numbering of this and a number of subsequent theorems is, to be kind, a bit bizarre. Mea culpa.

sec.title: The Maximal Quotient Ring
sec.p: In modern terminology, Utumi’s maximal right quotient ring Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r} of a ring R is the maximal rational extension \overline{R} of R. Here, the terminology and concept of a rational extension M of a submodule N is that defined by G. D. Findlay and J. Lambek [58], namely, that \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(S/N,M)=0 for all between modules S of M\supseteq N. This is equivalent to Utumi’s definition, namely for all x,y\in M, and y\neq 0 there corresponds r\in R with xr\in M and yr\neq 0. Thus, any rational extension is essential, that is, N is essential in M. In fact, in Utumi’s theorem, one can take Q_{\mathit{max}}=\mathrm{ann}_{E}\mathrm{ann}_{S}R, where S=\mathrm{End}_{R}E, and E=E(R) (and similarly for the maximal rational extension of any module). Furthermore, Lambek [63] showed that Q_{\mathit{max}} is canonically the biendomorphism ring of E, that is Q_{\mathit{max}}=\mathrm{End}_{S}E. In the special case that R is right n.s., we have that Q_{\mathit{max}}=\hat{R}. We restate this:

statement.label: 12B.
statement.p: Utumi [56]–Lambek [63] Theorem. Any ring R has a maximal rational extension Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R) contained in E=E(R_{R}). Moreover, Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R) is a ring canonically isomorphic to the biendomorphism ring Biend E_{R} containing R as a subring.

statement.label: 12C. Corollary.
statement.p: If R is right nonsingular, then Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R) is the injective hull E=E(R) of R, and is right self-injective and von Neumann regular.

statement.label: 12D. Proposition.
statement.p: If S is a right nonsingular prime ring, and if R is a subring that contains a nonzero left ideal of S, then R and S have the same maximal right quotient ring Q, and Q is VNR, right self-injective and injective over R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: By Faith [67], p.73, Corollary 7, S is a right (Johnson-Utumi) quotient ring of R, and since quotient ring is a transitive relation (e.g. ibid., p.66, Prop. D) then S and R have the same maximal right quotient ring Q=E(R_{R}), which is right self-injective and VNR (e.g. ibid. p.69, Theorem 1).

statement.label: 12E. Proposition.
statement.p: Let R=T_{n}(K) denote the ring of all upper triangular matrices over a field K. Then the ring Q=K_{n} of all n\times n matrices over K is both the left and right maximal quotient rings of R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This example is given explicitly on, loc.cit., p.74 for the ring T of all lower triangular n\times n matrices, in which case Q is the maximal right quotient ring of T, therefore it follows that Q is the maximal left quotient ring of R=T_{n}(K). However, the same argument shows that Q is the maximal right quotient ring of R, since R also contains a nonzero left ideal of Q, namely, the set Qe_{nn} of all n-th column matrices. Thus Proposition 12D applies in the case S=Q. (Note, Q is its own right and left maximal quotient ring.)

statement.label: 12F. Example.
statement.p: Let n=2 in Prop. 12E. Then both left and right singular ideals of R are nil (see, e.g. Prop. 16.38.), hence contained in the Jacobson radical J= \left(\begin{array}{ll} 0 & K\\0 & 0 \end{array}\right) of R=T_{2}(K). It is easily checked for any 0\neq x\in J, that ^{\perp }x=\left(\begin{array}{ll} 0 & K\\0 & K \end{array}\right) =Re_{22} is not an essential left ideal, and x^{\perp }=\left(\begin{array}{ll} K & K\\0 & 0 \end{array}\right) =e_{11}R is not an essential right ideal. Thus, \mathrm{sing}R_{R}=\mathrm{sing}_{R}R=0. (Note this also follows from Prop. 12E, and the fact that Q_{\mathit{max}}(R) is VNR iff R is nonsingular.) Since R is Artinian, then R coincides with its own classical quotient Q_{cl}(R) so Q_{cl}(R)\neq Q_{\mathit{max}}(R).

statement.label: 12G. Remark.
statement.p: That R in 12F is two-sided nonsingular corrects a statement on bottom of p.180 and top of p.181 of the first edition.

statement.label: 12H. Remark.
statement.p: Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R)=R for any right Kasch ring since \mathrm{Hom}(R/I,R)\neq 0 for any maximal right ideal I, hence the same is true for any right ideal I\neq R. Any \mathrm{acc}\!\perp commutative ring R has semilocal Kasch classical quotient ring (see theorem 16.31), hence Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R)=Q_{cl}^{r}(R), for any such ring, e.g. any commutative subring R of a Noetherian ring. Also see Armendariz and MacDonald [72] on rings with Kasch Q_{\mathit{max}}. (Kasch rings were called S (for skalar) rings by Kasch).

The fact that Q_{\mathit{max}} can be defined for any ring R, and includes as a special case the classical quotient ring Q_{cl}, means that the theory is applicable to arbitrary commutative rings inter alia. (Cf. sup 9.27.) Moreover, to a large extent, following Gabriel and Lambek, the emphasis after the mid-sixties has been on Q_{\mathit{max}}, and more general quotient rings, rather than on the restrictive class of n.s. rings. One reason for this is that after Goldie’s important break-through constructing Q_{cl} for right Noetherian semiprime rings, there naturally has been an impetus to extend the theory to rings more general than n.s. Goldie rings (i.e., drop the n.s.). This program has been carried out by Goldie himself, Lambek and Michler, Jategaonkar, Robson, Small and others, localizing e.g. in Noetherian or PI-rings at prime or semiprime ideals. B. Müller has given a summary of some of this in a McMaster Univ. Lecture Notes article. Also see F. L. Sandomierski [77], J. A. Beachy [76] and Jategaonkar’s book [86].

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: A ring R is right cononsingular provided that every right ideal I with ^{\perp } I=0 is essential. (Right nonsingular is, of course, the converse implication: ^{\perp }I=0 if I is essential.) A right nonsingular cononsingular ring is said to be right Utumi.

statement.label: 12.0A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right nonsingular, then R is right cononsingular iff every complement right ideal is an annihilator right ideal Moreover, if R is also left nonsingular, then

iff every right or left complement is an annihilator, equivalently, R is right and left cononsingular.⁠33
This corrects the result as stated in the first edition where complement and annihilator were reversed! Mea culpa!

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: In any right self-injective ring R, any complement right ideal I is an annihilator since I is a direct summand of R.

statement.label: Corollary.
statement.p: A right self-injective VNR ring is left self-injective iff every complement left ideal is an annihilator.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: R is right and left nonsingular and cononsingular.

statement.label: Corollary.
statement.p: A right and left nonsingular cononsingular ring R is Dedekind Finite.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: This follows from Utumi’s Theorem 4.7B. Since Q is right and left selfinjective, Q hence R is DF.

statement.label: Corollary.
statement.p: Any Abelian VNR ring R is right and left cononsingular, and Q is also Abelian.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Utumi, ibid. Cf. Goodearl [79], p.30, Theorem 3.8.

sec.title: Courter’s Theorem on When All Modules Are Rationally Complete
sec.p: A right R-module M is rationally complete provided that M is its maximal rational extension. (See the paragraph “Maximal Quotient Ring” above.)

statement.label: 12.0B. Theorem
statement.p: The following conditions on a ring R are equivalent.

def.p: Every right and left R-module is rationally complete.
R is a product of finitely many full matrix rings over right and left perfect local rings.
R is right perfect and every right R-module is rationally complete.
R is right and left perfect and every right and left R-module is co-rationally complete (in a sense dual to rationally complete).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See Lawrence and Louden [77] on rationaly closed group rings. Also see Formanek [74].

sec.title: Snider’s Theorem on Group Algebras of Characteristic 0

statement.label: 12.0C. Theorem
statement.p: If F is a field of characteristic zero, then any group algebra R=FG is right and left nonsingular.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The proof follows from the following three lemmas of Snider’s.

sec.p: Z(R) denotes the right singular ideal. Regarding the two lemmas below, compare the proof of Amitsur’s Theorem 2.40.

statement.label: 1. Lemma.
statement.p: Let R be a ring with involution. If xx^{\star }=0 implies x=0, then the singular ideal Z(R)=0.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: If 0\neq x in Z(R), then pick 0\neq x^{\star }r in x^{\perp }\cap x^{\star }R. We have r^{\star }xx^{\star }r= (r^{\star }x)(r^{\star }x)^{\star }=0 which implies r^{\star }x and x^{\star }r=0, a contradiction.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Cf. the proof of Amitsur’s Lemma 2.39.

statement.label: 2. Lemma.
statement.p: If K is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 then Z(KG)=0.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p:
By Artin-Schreier’s Theorem 1.30D, K has a real closed subfield P of codimension 2 which has a unique ordering by Theorem 1.30A, and which defines complex conjugation on K sending \alpha in K onto its conjuate \overline{\alpha }. Then KG has an involution defined by (\sum 
olimits _{i}\alpha _{i}g_{i})^{\star }=\sum 
olimits _{i}\overline{\alpha }_{i}g_{i}^{-1}. Also the coefficient of 1 in (\sum 
olimits _{i}\alpha _{i}g_{i})(\sum 
olimits _{i}\alpha _{i}g_{i})^{\star } is \sum \alpha _{i}\overline{\alpha }_{i}\geq 0. Therefore the above lemma is satisfied.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This modification of Snider’s lemma is due to Lam [01].

statement.label: 3. Lemma.
statement.p: If F and K are fields with F\subseteq K, then Z(F[G])\subseteq Z(K[G]).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Let [k_{i}]_{i\in I} be a basis for K over F. If I is an essential right ideal of F[G], then I^{\prime }=\sum \nolimits _{i}k_{i}I is an essential F[G]-submodule of K[G], hence an essential right ideal of K[G].

sec.p: The next result suffices for Snider’s Theorem.

statement.label: 4. Theorem.
statement.p: If F is a field of characteristic 0 and G is any group, then Z(FG)=0.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Let K be the algebraic closure of F, and let P be a real closed field inside of K such that K=P(i). Then lemmas 2 and 3 apply.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Snider, ibid, points out that if G is locally finite then Z(FG)=\mathrm{rad}(FG), for any field F. Furthermore, Snider ibid. and Brown [77] characterize when FG is nonsingular when F has characteristic p>0 and G is solvable. Also see Brown [78].

sec.p: This remark establishes Jacobson’s conjecture for locally finite G:

statement.label: 12.0D. Theorem.
statement.p: If G is locally finite, and F is a field of characteristic 0, then FG is semiprimitive.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: This was known to Jacobson. Also see Prop.2.40 and Cor.2.41.

sec.title: Kaplansky’s Theorem on Group Algebras of Characteristic 0
sec.p: The next theorem yields Kaplansky’s Theorem 4.6D.

statement.label: 12.0E. Theorem.
statement.p: If F is a field of characteristic 0, then the group ring R= FG of any group G is Utumi, hence Dedekind Finite.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: R is nonsingular by Snider’s Theorem 12.0C. Since R has an involution (see the proof of Lemma 2.39), then its maximal right and left quotient rings coincide (see Theorem 12A), hence R is Utumi, and DF by Theorem 4.7B.

statement.label: 12.0F. Theorem
statement.p: The group ring R=FG of a countable group G over a field F is its own maximal quotient ring iff G is finite.

statement.label: 12.0G. Theorem
statement.p: Let G be a locally finite group. Then the group ring R=FG of G over a field F is its own maximal quotient ring iff G is finite.

sec.title: Galois Subrings of Quotient Rings

statement.label: 12.1A. Theorem
statement.title: (Harčenko [74]-Cohen [75]).
statement.p: If R is a semiprime ring with a finite group G of automorphisms without |G|-torsion (= no elements of additive order dividing |G|), then R is right Goldie iff the Galois subring R^{G} is right Goldie.

sec.p: Cf. Tominaga [73] and Kitamura [76,77]; and Fisher-Osterburg [78], who reprove 12.1A.
The next theorem generalized the author’s theorem [72c] for Ore domains (see 6.30). Also see Kharchenko [00] for a survey.

statement.label: 12.1B. Theorem
statement.title: (Harčenko [74,75]).
statement.p: If G is a finite group of automorphisms of a ring R without nilpotent elements \neq 0, then R is right Goldie iff R^{G} is right Goldie.

statement.label: 12.1C. Theorem
statement.p: If G is a finite group of automorphisms of a semiprime ring R without |G|-torsion and if R^{G} is right Noetherian, then so is R; in fact, R is a f\cdot g right R^{G}-module.

statement.label: 12.1D_1. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a semiprime ring, and G a finite group of automorphisms of R. Then:

def.p: where G^{ex} is the canonical extension of G to Q_{c\ell }^{r}(R).
If R is right Noetherian, and |G|^{-1}\in R, then R^{G} is right Noetherian. (See Fisher-Osterburg, op.cit., p.488).

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) R semiprime is necessary for 12.1D_{1} even assuming |G| is a unit; (2) Similarly R^{G} right Noetherian does not imply R right Noetherian even assuming |G|^{-1} exists (ibid., p.492, Example 2).

statement.label: 12.1D_2. Theorem
statement.title: (Fisher-Osterburg, ibid.).
statement.p: If R^{G} has right Krull dimension (§14), then:

def.p: R satisfies acc on semiprime ideals,
Every semiprime factor ring of R is right Goldie,
Nil subrings of R are nilpotent,
Each ideal of R has just finitely minimal primes,
Every ideal of R contains a product of prime ideals.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: R need not have right Krull dimension even if R^{G} does (same example for Remark (2) above suffices).

statement.label: 12.1E. Theorem
statement.p: If G is a finite group of automorphisms of a right Artinian ring R, and if |G|^{-1}\in R, then R^{G} is right Artinian; if R is semisimple then so is R^{G}.

sec.p: The next theorem is a partial converse of the second part of 12.1E.

statement.label: 12.1F. Theorem
statement.p: If G is a finite group of automorphisms of a semisimple ring R without |G|-torsion, then R is semisimple Artinian if R^{G} is.

sec.p: A number of theorems relating chain conditions of a ring R and a subring S are given by Björk [73]. In particular the next theorem answers a question raised in that paper.

statement.label: 12.1G. Theorem
statement.p: If S is a subring of R such that R=\Sigma _{i=1}^{n}u_{i}S for finitely many elements u_{i} such that u_{i}S=Su_{i}\,\ \forall i, then a right R-module M is Noetherian (resp. has finite length as an R-module) iff the same is true as a right S-module. Moreover, every simple right R-module is semisimple of finite length over S.

sec.p: This generalized theorems of P. M. Eakin (1968) and D. Eisenbud (1970).

sec.title: Localizing Categories and Torsion Theories
sec.p: In another direction, by 1962 the work of A. Grothendieck [57], P. Gabriel, J.P. Serre and others on a general localization theory for Abelian categories with generators and exact direct limits (carried out in Gabriel’s thesis [62]) had given impetus to study localizations of the category mod-R of all right modules with respect to more general localizing subcategories.

In this direction, Gabriel showed that there is a one-to-one correspondence \mathcal{G}\Leftrightarrow \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{G}} between the localizing subcategories \mathcal{G} and the idempotent, topologizing filters \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{G}} of right ideals of R (l.c.). Moreover, there is a canonical localizing functor T: (\mathrm{mod}{-}R)/\mathcal{G}\rightsquigarrow \mathrm{mod}{-}R_{\mathcal{G}}, where R_{\mathcal{G}} is called the (usually less than maximal) quotient ring of the localization and in classical situations (e.g. when \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{G}} contains a cofinal set of finitely generated right ideals), T is an equivalence induced by \otimes _{R}R_{S}.

This emphasized the torsion theoretic aspect of localization foreshadowing the work in the subject by S. E. Dickson [66] and others. Thus there is a one-to-one correspondence between certain torsion theories T, called hereditary, and localizing subcategories \mathcal{G}_{T}, and \mathcal{G}_{T} is the localizing subcategory corresponding to the obvious filter \mathcal{F} defined by T. (Thus, I\in \mathcal{F} if and only if T(R/I)=R/I.)

In 1971 Lambek gave an elegant, elementary presentation of torsion theories and quotient rings, showing that in “nice” cases R_{\mathcal{G}} can be realized, as before, as the biendomorphism ring of an injective module. Moreover, Q_{\mathit{max}} appears as the R_{\mathcal{G}} with respect to the largest torsion theory with respect to which R is torsion free. Also see Walker and Walker [72] in this connection.

sec.title: Ring Epimorphisms and Localizations

statement.label: 12.2A. Theorem
statement.p: A ring homomorphism f:A\rightarrow B is an epimorphism in the category RINGS of rings iff the canonical map B\otimes _{A}B\rightarrow B is an isomorphism.

sec.p: This is also characterized in Stenström [75], p.226, via fullness of the canonical functor \mathrm{mod}{-}B\rightsquigarrow \mathrm{mod}{-}A Cf. Storrer [73]. The next theorem appears as Corollary 1.3, p.226 of the cited book.

statement.label: 12.2B. Theorem
statement.p: If f:A\rightarrow B is an epimorphism in RINGS, then any injective right A-module M is canonically an injective right B-module.

sec.p: Cf. Dade’s Theorem 3.17B where this fails for classical localizations. Cf. also Silver [67], pp. 48–49ff on localization theory.
A ring homomorphism f:A\rightarrow B is a right localization if f is a ring epimorphism, that is, B\otimes _{A}B\approx B canonically, and {}_{A}B is flat.

statement.label: 12.3. Theorem
statement.p: If A is a commutative domain, the localizations of A are the subrings B of K=Q(A) containing A such that B_{A} is flat (= B is a flat overring of A). (Cf. 9.29B.)

sec.p: Cf. Silver [67], p.47, where he also remarks that by a theorem of O. Goldman, every flat overring B of a Dedekind domain A is a partial quotient ring AS^{-1} for an m.c. subset S of A iff the ideal class group of A is torsion. Cf. Storrer [68].

statement.label: 12.3A. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right non-singular and right FPF iff R is right bounded, R\hookrightarrow Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R) is a right localization (Cf. 12.1, sup. 12.2), and R=Tr_{R}(I)\oplus I^{\perp } for any f\cdot g right ideal I, where Tr_{R}(I)=\sum \limits _{f\in I^{\star }}f(I) and I^{\star }=\mathit{Hom}_{R}(I,R).

sec.p: See Yoshimura [94,98] for a discussion of these results, and additional results and generalizations. See Remark 12.14.

sec.title: Continuous Regular Rings
sec.p: A lattice L is upper continuous if L is complete and

for all a\in L and all chains \{b_{i}\}_{i\in I} of subsets. Dually for lower continuous, and L is continuous if both upper and lower continuous. The term (upper, lower) \aleph _{0}-continuous applies if these conditions hold with the restriction that |I|\leq \aleph _{0}.

A VNR ring R is right continuous if the lattice L(R_{R}) of principal right ideals is upper continuous. R is continuous if R is both right and left continuous, equivalent, if L(R_{R}) is continuous. (Then L(_{R}R) is continuous.) Similarly for (right) \aleph _{0}-continuous.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: In a VNR ring, every f\cdot g right ideal is generated by an idempotent, hence is principal (sup. 4.A). See theorem 12.4A below for Utumi’s characterization of right continuous VNR rings.

sec.title: Complemented and Modular Lattices
sec.p: A lattice L is distributive provided that \forall a,b,c\in L
L is modular when the distributive law holds whenever a\geq b:

statement.label: Examples.
statement.p: (1) The lattice of subsets of a set S\neq \emptyset is distributive, as is any linearly ordered set; (2) The lattice L(M) of submodules of an R-module is modular. See Jacobson [51], pp.193–4.

sec.p: A lattice L is complemented provided that L has a greatest element 1 and at least element 0, and every a\in L has a complement a^{\prime }, that is, an element a^{\prime } with a\cup a^{\prime }=1 and a\cap a^{\prime }=0.
If L is a complemented modular lattice, and if a\in L, then
is also a complemented modular lattice under the induced order. Then any complement of b\in L_{a} is called a complement of b relative to a (see Jacobson [51], p.205, for these concepts).

A lattice L is self-dual in case there is a 1-1 order reversing mapping f:L\rightarrow L, also called an involution of L, and we write f(a)=a^{\star }\,\forall a\in L. In this case, L is orthocomplemented provided that a^{\star } is a complement of a\ \forall a\in L.

sec.title: Von Neumann’s Coordinatization Theorem
sec.p: A continuous geometry ( = CG) is a complemented modular lattice which is both upper and lower continuous. A CG is irreducible if 0 and 1 are the elements with unique relative complements.

statement.label: 12.4. Theorem
statement.title: (von Neumann [36A, B]).
statement.p: Every irreducible continuous geometry L with a homogeneous basis of order n\geq 4 is isomorphic to the lattice of right ideals of a (unique up to isomorphism) VNR ring \mathcal{R}(L).

statement.label: 12.4^{\prime }. Theorem
statement.p: Every orthocomplemented complete modular lattice is a continuous geometry.

statement.label: 12.4^{\prime \prime }. Theorem
statement.p: \mathcal{R}(L) is right self-injective.

statement.label: 12.4^{\prime \prime \prime }. Theorem
statement.p: \mathcal{R}(L) is also left self-injective, and, moreover, a simple ring. Conversely, any simple right and left self-injective VNR ring R\approx \mathcal{R}(L) for an irreducible continuous geometry L.

sec.title: Von Neumann’s Dimension Function
sec.p: Goodearl, ibid., p.84, points out that if L is a continuous Geometry, then by von Neumann [60], p.58, Corollary 1, p.60 and Theorem 7.3, there is a unique normalized dimension function D on L, and the range of D is either \{0,1/n,2/n,\ldots \,,1\} for some positive integer n, or else the entire unit interval [0,1]. The first case is referred to as Case n, the second as Case \infty . As shown, ibid., p.83, L falls into Case \infty if and only if the DCC fails in L, which yields a way to test for Case \infty without reference to the dimension function. We note that von Neumann used the term “continuous geometry” only to refer to an irreducible continuous geometry in Case \infty .

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) As stated in Theorem 12.4, any complemented modular lattice (or projective geometry) L with a “homogeneous basis of order \geq 4” is isomorphic to the lattice of principal right ideals of a (unique up to isomorphism) VNR ring \mathcal{R}(L). Cf. the theorems of Stephenson and Camillo, 3.51^{\prime } and 3.51^{\prime }\,f; (2) von Neumann [60], Theorem 18.1, p.237, characterized those VNR rings R for which the lattice of principal right ideals is an irreducible continuous geometry: this holds if and only if R is indecomposable as a ring and is complete with respect to a certain rank-metric. In case \infty , theorem 12.4^{\prime \prime \prime } shows that metric completeness may be replaced by self-injectivity, which is a type of algebraic completeness; (3) Let L be an irreducible continuous geometry in Case \infty . (Examples are constructed by von Neumann [36b].) Inasmuch as L has order n for any n>0 ([60],p.93), von Neumann’s coordinatization theorem 12.4 says that there exists a regular ring R whose lattice of principal right ideals is isomorphic to L. By Theorem 12.4^{\prime \prime \prime }, R is a simple, right and left self-injective ring which is not Artinian.

sec.p: L is irreducible iff L\not \approx L_{1}\times L_{2} for two nonzero modular lattices L_{1} and L_{2}. Furthermore, \mathcal{R}(L) is indecomposable qua ring iff L is irreducible.

sec.title: Utumi’s Characterization of Continuous VNR Rings
sec.p: The next two theorems relate to Utumi’s theorems 4.3A and B.

statement.label: 12.4A. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions for a VNR ring R.

def.p: R is right continuous.
R contains all idempotents of its maximal right quotient ring Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R).
Every right ideal of R is essential in a principal right ideal eR generated by an idempotent e.

statement.label: 12.4B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right continuous VNR ring, then R is right self-injective under any of the following assumptions:

def.p: R has no nonzero Abelian idempotents.
M_{n}(R) is right continuous for any n>1 (Utumi [60]).
R is directly indecomposable qua ring (e.g. R prime).
Every primitive factor ring is Artinian.
Let R be VNR. If R has no nonzero Abelian idempotents, then R is right continuous iff R is right self-injective. (This follows from Utumi’s Theorems 4.3A and B.)
A (directly) indecomposable VNR ring is right continuous iff R is right self-injective (ibid.)
Every (two-sided) continuous VNR is unit-regular (Utumi [65]. Cf Theorem 4.7B.)
Every indecomposable continuous VNR ring is simple. (Maeda [50]).

sec.p: Also see Goodearl [79,91], Chapter 13, esp. 13.12ff and his Chapter 13 Notes.

sec.title: Semi-continuous Rings and Modules
sec.p: A ring R is right semi-continuous if R satisfies the condition:

def.p: Every right ideal essentially generates an idempotent, i.e., 12.4A (3) holds.

sec.p: Moreover, R is right continuous if R is right semi-continuous and satisfies:

def.p: If a right ideal B is isomorphic to a right ideal eR, where e is an idempotent, then B is generated by an idempotent.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Continuous and semi-continuous rings are generalized to modules in a number of papers, where (C1), the condition that every submodule of M is essential in a direct summand, equivalently, every complement submodule is a direct summand, is also called an extending or CS module; (C2) is the condition that every submodule isomorphic to a direct summand is actually itself a direct summand; and a third condition (C3) is that if two submodules A and B are direct summands such that A\cap B=0, then A\oplus B is a direct summand.

sec.p: M is continuous if M satisfies (C1) and (C2), and quasi-continuous if M satisfies (C1) and (C3).

def.p: Any quasi-injective R-module is a CS module. (See Theorem 3.9D.) Also see Theorem 12.15.
Mohammed and Mueller [90] show that continuous modules have the exchange property. (Cf. Oshiro and Rizvi [96].) Also see 8.4G, Example 5.

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: Let \mathcal{P} be a property of modules. A right R-module M is quotient-\mathcal{P} if every factor module M/K has property \mathcal{P}.

statement.label: 12.4C. Theorem
statement.p: A quotient-CS cyclic right R-module is quotient finite dimensional (= q.f.d.).

statement.label: Corollary.
statement.p: If R is a ring, and if R_{R} is quotient-CS, then R is right q.f.d.

sec.p: The next theorem generalizes Osofsky’s Theorem 3.18A. Right duo means right ideals are ideals.

statement.label: 12.4C^{\prime }. Theorem
statement.p: Every cyclic right R-module is continuous iff R is a product of a semisimple ring S and a product of a finite number n of zero dimensional right duo right chain rings (where possibly S=0 or n=0).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Ibid. Corollary 9.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: A local ring R is zero dimensional iff J=\mathrm{rad}\,R is nil. Furthermore, by a remark of Osofsky-Smith, ibid., a right chain ring with nil radical is a right duo ring. They also show that the property in 12.4C^{\prime } is not right-left symmetric.

statement.label: Corollary
statement.p: If every cyclic right R-module is quasi-injective then R is a finite product as in Theorem 12.4C^{\prime }^{\prime }, where the n chain rings are right linearly compact.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See Osofsky-Smith, (loc.cit.).

statement.label: 12.4D. Theorem
statement.p: Consider the following conditions on a ring R: (1) Every f\cdot g right R-module is CS; (2) Every 2-generated right R-module is CS; (3) R is right Noetherian and (\mathit{rad}\,R)^{2}=0. Then (1)\Rightarrow (2)\Rightarrow (3). Furthermore, if R/{rad}\,R is VNR, then R is right Artinian.

sec.p: Cf. Dung-Smith [95], and Huynh-Dung-Wisbauer [91].

statement.label: 12.4E. Theorem
statement.p: If every cyclic singular right R-module is CS, and R is simple, then R is right Noetherian.

statement.label: 12.4F. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent for a ring R:

def.p: R has finite right Goldie dimension and every direct sum of an injective right module and a semisimple right module is CS.
R has finite right Goldie dimension and every direct sum of a continuous right module and a semisimple right module is CS.
R is right Noetherian and R/(\mathit{soc}\,R_{R}) is a right V-ring,

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: If every singular right R-module is injective (= R is right SI), then every direct sum of a CS-module and a semisimple module is CS (ibid.).

sec.p: Furthermore:

statement.label: 12.4G. Theorem
statement.title: (ibid.).
statement.p: If R is a right nonsingular ring, then every direct sum of an injective right module and a semisimple right module is CS iff R/(\mathit{soc}\,R_{R}) is a right Noetherian right V-ring.

statement.label: 12.4H. Theorem
statement.p: If R is semiprime right Goldie, and M is a nonsingular right CS-module, then M is a direct sum of an injective module and a finite direct sum of uniform modules. If R is commutative, and \overline{R}=R/N(R) is Goldie, then a nonsingular CS-module M is a direct sum of an injective \overline{R}-module and finitely many uniform modules, where N(R)=\mathit{prime\ rad}\,R.

sec.p: These theorems generalized some of the theorems of Kamal-Mueller [88a, b, c]. (Vide also Mohammed-Mueller [90].)
A ring R is top-regular if R/\mathrm{rad}R is VNR. A right self-injective ring is top-regular by Utumi’s Theorem 4.2.

statement.label: 12.5. Theorem
statement.p: If R is right continuous, then R is top-regular. Any right self-injective ring is right continuous.

def.p: As stated in Theorem 4.3B, Utumi [60] proved that a right continuous VNR ring R splits into a product R_{1}\times R_{2} where R_{1} is Abelian and R_{2} is right self-injective with no nonzero Abelian idempotents;
(Zimmermann-Huisgen and Zimmermann [78]) Any algebraically compact ring is top-regular. See Theorem 6.52.

sec.title: Chatters-Hajarnavis Theorems on CS-Rings
sec.p: The rings R that satisfy (C1), called semi-continuous rings in the author’s paper [85], have the characterizing property that every complement right ideal is generated by an idempotent. These rings are called CS-rings in Chatters and Hajarnavis [77], who explicitly characterize indecomposable right CS rings R which are either semi-primary or have semi-primary right quotient rings as certain triangular matrices over subrings of division rings. The case when R is right Artinian is then classified (Theorem 3.1 and 6.10.)

def.p: A twosided Noetherian CS ring R is a pp ring with twosided maximal quotient ring.
Any twosided Noetherian CS ring has a CS Artinian quotient ring (Corollary to Theorem 6.5; Cf. Example 6.6, loc.cit.)
A right Noetherian right nonsingular right CS ring has Artinian quotient ring (Prop. 6.7. loc.cit.)
An indecomposable twosided Noetherian right nonsingular right CS ring is either prime or Artinian.
A twosided Noetherian prime ring R is twosided CS iff R is a pp ring. (Theorem 6.8; Cf. Example 6.9, loc. cit.)
A left Noetherian right PIR is twosided CS. (Corollary to Theorem 6.8, loc. cit.)

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: The right CS property is not a Morita invariant property: there is a full 2\times 2 matrix ring over a right Noetherian right hereditary domain D that is not left Ore and is not right CS. (See Example 6.9, loc. cit.).

statement.label: 12.6. Theorem
statement.p: Every commutative FPF ring is CS.

statement.label: 12.7. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative and quotient finite dimensional, then every continuous module is quasi-injective iff Q(R/I) is self-injective for every irreducible ideal.

statement.label: 12.8. Theorem
statement.p: The following conditions are equivalent: (1) singular right R-modules are continuous; (2) R/I is semisimple for each essential right ideal I.

statement.label: 12.8A. Theorem

title.sc: Gómez Pardo and Guil Asensio [97d], generalized in [98a]

statement.p: Let R be a right CS-ring. Then:

def.p: If R is right Kasch, then R_{R} is finitely embedded;
If R is a right cogenerator, then R is right PF.

statement.label: 12.8B. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a prime ring. Then:

def.p: If R is right Goldie of Goldie dimension \geq 2, and if R is right CS, then R is left Goldie.
R is right Goldie left CS iff R is left Goldie right CS.

statement.label: 12.9. Theorem
statement.title: (Jøndrup [76], Lazard [74], Sahaev [77], Vasconcelos [69], Zöschinger [81]).
statement.p: Let R be an arbitrary ring with Jacobson radical J. The following are equivalent conditions, and are satisfied whenever R is commutative:

def.p: If M is a f\cdot g flat right R-module such that M/MJ is projective, then M is projective.
If M is a projective right R-module, such that M/MJ is f\cdot g, then M is f\cdot g.
If M is a projective right R-module, then every f\cdot g submodule S\neq M is contained in a maximal submodule.
If S is a submodule of a f\cdot g projective right R module P that is minimal with respect to S+T=P for some submodule T, then S (called a “complement submodule” ibid.) is a direct summand of P.
The condition (n) above for left R-modules, n=1,2,3,4.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: For commutative R, (1) is due to Vasconcelos [69]; (2) is due to Lazard [74]; for arbitrary R, (1)\Leftrightarrow (2)\Rightarrow (3) is due to Jøndrup [76]; and Zöschinger [81] proved that (1)\Leftrightarrow (2)\Leftrightarrow (3)\Leftrightarrow (4) and that (4) is right-left symmetric. See Mohammed-Sandomierski [89] for a discussion of all this, and the next theorem.

statement.label: 12.10. Theorem
statement.p: A projective right R-module M is a CS-module iff A=\mathit{End}M_{R} is a right CS-ring. Moreover, if M is free of infinite rank, this is equivalent to the condition that every f\cdot g projective right A-module is a CS-module

sec.title: Strongly Prime Rings
sec.p: A ring R is right strongly prime (= SP) if to each nonzero a\in R, there is a finite subset F of R so that (aF)^{\perp }=0. Thus all SP rings are prime. Domains, right Goldie prime rings, and simple rings are examples of SP Rings provided in the papers of Handelman and Lawrence [75], Rubin [73] and Viola-Prioli [75] (Cf. the latter’s Rutgers U. Ph.D., 1973). These rings are called Absolute Torsionfree (= ATF) by Rubin [R] and Viola-Prioli [VP].

statement.label: 12.11. Theorem
statement.p: If R is module finite over center, or right nonsingular and has finite right Goldie dimension, then R is right ATF iff R is prime. Any polynomial ring R[x] over a right ATF ring is right ATF.

statement.label: 12.12. Theorem
statement.p: A ring is right AFT iff for each f\cdot g projective module P, and nonzero submodule S, there is an embedding P\hookrightarrow S^{n} for some integer n>0.

statement.label: 12.13. Theorem
statement.p: (1) Any VNR SP ring is simple; (2) If R is right SP, then R is right nonsingular, Q_{\mathit{max}}^{r}(R) is simple, and there exists a group G so that the group ring RG is primitive. Furthermore, (3) if RG is right SP, then G has no nontrivial locally finite normal subgroups. Partial converse: (4) if R is right SP, and G is torsion-free abelian, then RG is right SP.

sec.p: Some of these results and those of Rubin [73] were obtained independently by Viola-Prioli (op.cit.).

statement.label: Example
statement.title: (Cedó [97]).
statement.p: There exists a ring R so that R[[x]] is right and left SP, but R is neither right nor left SP.

Remark on Flat Epimorphisms. Interalia Yoshimura [98] characterized a commutative ring R with the property that any overring R between R and Q_{\mathit{max}}(R) is a flat epimorphism of R by the property that every overmodule of R in Q_{\mathit{max}}(R) is projective, equivalently, every overring is integrally closed in Q_{\mathit{max}}(R). Cf. Griffin’s theorem 9.30 and Eggert’s theorem 9.31.

statement.label: 12.15. Theorem
statement.p: A CS module with acc (dcc) on essential submodules is a direct sum of a Noetherian (Artinian) and a semisimple module.

statement.label: 12.16. Remark.
statement.p: A result of Kasch-Sandomierski states that the socle soc M of an R-module M is the intersection of the essential submodules; consequently, M has acc (dcc) on essential submodules iff M/\mathrm{soc}\,M is Noetherian (Artinian). See Camillo-Yousif’s Lemma 4, ibid.

sec.label: Chapter 13
sec.title: Morita Duality and Dual Rings
sec.p: See e.g. Morita [58], Müller [69], Zelmanowitz and Jansen [88], Xue [92], or Faith [76], for the background and definitions of Morita duality, defined by an injective cogenerator E_{R} of mod-R such that _{S}E is an injective cogenerator for S-mod, the category of left S-modules, where S= \mathrm{End}E_{R}. A module M_{R} is E-reflexive if the canonical map M\rightarrow \mathrm{Hom}_{S}(\mathrm{Hom}_{R}(M,E)) is an isomorphism, and symmetrically for a left S-module N.
This functor defines a duality between the full subcategories consisting of the E-reflexive modules of mod-R and S-mod, and then R (resp.S) is said to be a right (left) Morita ring.

If the functor \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(-,E) is, or defines, a duality and \mathrm{Hom}_{S}(\ ,E) is the inverse, then we say E_{R} defines or induces a (Morita) duality, and \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(\ ,E) is the duality functor. If S\approx R, then E_{R} defines a Morita self-duality. A ring R with such a Morita duality is said to be a right Morita ring. See Arhangelskii, Goodearl, and Huisgen-Zimmermann [97] for connections with Pontryagin duality.

statement.label: Remarks.
statement.p: (1) If E induces a right Morita duality for R, and if I is an ideal of R, then F=\mathrm{ann}_{E}I induces a right Morita duality for R/I;(2) If S=\mathrm{End}E_{R} in (1), then center S\approx center R. (See the author’s Algebra II, Exercises 23.17(c) for (1), and 23.35 for(2).

statement.label: 13.1. Theorem
statement.p: A right R-module E defines a (Morita) duality iff R_{R} is linearly compact and E_{R} is a linearly compact and finitely embedded injective cogenerator. Moreover, then the E-reflexive modules are precisely the linearly compact modules.

sec.p: See Xue [92], pp.33–34.

statement.label: 13.2. Theorem
statement.p: Any ring R with Morita duality is semiperfect and, in fact, so is the endomorphism ring of any finitely embedded injective cogenerator.

sec.p: See, e.g. Xue, p.11, Proposition 1.19.

statement.label: 13.3. Theorem
statement.p: Any right linearly compact ring is semiperfect.

sec.p: See, e.g. Xue, p.29, Corollary 3.14

statement.label: 13.4A. Theorem
statement.p: Any Artinian commutative ring R has a self-duality.

sec.p: In this case, we may suppose R is a finite product R=\Pi _{i=1}^{n}R_{i} of Artinian local rings, hence suppose R is local with maximal ideal m. Then E=E(R/m) induces the Morita duality, and the E-reflexive modules are just the f\cdot g R modules.

statement.label: 13.4B. Remark.
statement.p: (1) By theorems of Azumaya [59] and Morita [58], this also holds true for any non-commutative Artinian Morita ring: all f\cdot g modules are E-reflexive and conversely. See Xue, p. 94, Theorem 1.11. (2) The duality for a finite dimensional algebra A over a field k, that sends any f\cdot g right A-module M onto its k-dual M^{\star }=\mathrm{Hom}_{R}(M,R), is a Morita duality induced by A^{\star }. Thus, A^{\star } is an injective cogenerator in both mod-A and A-mod, and
Cf. my Algebra II, p.198,23,32-33.

statement.label: 13.4C. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a commutative Noetherian ring, and P a prime ideal, and \hat{R}_{P} be the completion of R_{P} in the PR_{P}-adic topology. Then
has a Morita self-duality induced by E(R/P). Moreover, E(R/P) is an Artinian R_{P}-module with simple socle \approx R_{P}/PR_{P}\approx Q(R/P).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: See 5.4B: \hat{R}_{P} is linearly compact. Matlis proved this without recourse to Morita’s Theorem [58] (which of course implies 13.4C). Also 13.10 below implies 13.11A and B each of which implies 13.4C.

statement.label: 13.4D. Theorem.
statement.p: If R is a commutative ring, and if P is a prime ideal such that E(R/P) is \Sigma -injective then R_{P} is a Noetherian local ring, E(R/P) is canonically an injective cogenerator for R_{P} which induces a Morita duality for \hat{R}_{P}=End_{R}E(R/P).

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: Apply Corollary 3.15B and Theorem 13.4C in the case R=R_{p}.

sec.p: The concept of \Delta -injectives used below is defined in 3.10A.

statement.label: 13.4E. Theorem
statement.p: If a \Delta -injective right R-module E induces a right Morita duality for R, then (1) R is right Artinian, and (2) R=Q_{\max }^{r}(R) is its own maximal quotient ring.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: op.cit., p.47, Corollaries 10.14 and 10.15. Also see Theorem 7.45. ((1) follows essentially from Osofsky’s Theorem 4.22.)

sec.p: For a study of \Delta -injective modules see the author’s Lectures [82a], Part I. Also see Nastasescu [80], on Artinian objects in Grothendieck categories; also references in my Lectures [82a] and a discussion of them on pp.64–65. Cf. also Albu [80] on a related “dual” theorem.

statement.label: 13.5. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a commutative ring, and if R has a duality, then R is linear compact and has a self-duality.

statement.label: 13.6. Theorem
statement.title: (Ánh [90]).
statement.p: A commutative ring R has a duality iff R is linearly compact.

sec.p: This theorem answered a question dating back to Zelinsky [53] and Müller [69] on the structure of rings with duality. Cf. Orsatti and Roselli [81] and Dikranjan and Orsatti [84].

statement.label: 13.7. Theorem.
statement.p: (Nakayama [39, 40, 41], Azumaya [59, 66] and Morita [58]). Any PF (= right and left PF) ring R has a self-duality, in particular any QF ring has a self-duality, induced by Hom_{R}(,R).

sec.p: This follows from Theorem 4.20: R is a f.e. injective cogenerator (both sides). Cf. 13.13-14.

statement.label: 13.7A. Proposition
statement.p: If A is a ring which is completely right PF in the sense that every factor ring is right PF, then A is a primary-decomposable Artinian serial ring.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See the author’s Algebra II [76], p.238, Theorem 25.4.6A.

statement.label: 13.7B. Proposition
statement.p: A ring is a primary decomposable serial ring if and only if the following equivalent conditions hold

def.p: R is right and left Artinian principal ideal ring.
R is a serial Artinian right principal ideal ring.
R is a right principal ideal QF ring.
R is a principal right ideal ring, and every left prindec of R is serial of finite length.
Every factor ring of R is QF.
R is left or right artinian, and the injective hull of each cyclic right R-module is cyclic.
R is right Noetherian, and the injective hulls of cyclics are cyclic in mod-R.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: See the author’s Algebra II, p.238, Theorem 25.4.6B

statement.label: 13.8. Theorem
statement.p: Let S be a ring that is a linear compact module over a ring R contained in its center (e.g. if S_{R} is f\cdot g and R is l.c.). If E induces a self-duality for R, then Hom_{R}(S,E) induces a self-duality for S.

sec.p: See, e.g. Xue [92], p.57, Theorem, 7.6 and Chapter 2 (loc.cit.) for other duality theorems for ring extensions.

statement.label: 13.9. Theorem
statement.p: Any serial ring has a self-duality.

sec.p: Cf. Oshiro [87] for additional results and comments.

statement.label: 13.10. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative, and M a finitely embedded linearly compact R-module, then A=End_{R}M is a linearly compact R-module and has a self-duality.

statement.label: 13.11A. Corollary
statement.p: If M is an Artinian module over a commutative ring R, then A=End_{R}M is Noetherian and has a self-duality.

sec.p: Thus, in both 13.10 and 13.11, A is a semiperfect ring by 13.2.
Another corollary for 13.10:

statement.label: 13.11B. Theorem
statement.p: If R is commutative, and M is Artinian with simple socle, then A=End_{R}M is a complete local commutative Noetherian ring with a Morita duality induced by M.

sec.title: Dual Rings
sec.p: A ring R is a right dual (= right D) ring if every right ideal I is an annihilator right ideal, equivalently, R/I is a torsionless right R-module for all I (see 1.5). A dual ring (= D-ring) is one that is both left and right dual.

statement.label: 13.12. Example.
statement.p: If R is a cogenerator ring, e.g. a right PF ring (see 4.20), then every right R-module is torsionless, hence R is a right D-ring. If R is a right and left cogenerator ring, then R is a D-ring and in fact PF (see 13.14).

statement.label: 13.13. Theorem
statement.p: A ring R is right PF iff E(R_{R}) is torsionless and R is right and left Kasch.

sec.p: This implies the next theorem since any right cogenerating ring is right Kasch.

statement.label: 13.14A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right and left cogenerator, then R is PF, and conversely.

sec.p: By the Morita equivalence X\mapsto X^{n} between mod-R and mod-R_{n} which carries an R-module X generated by n elements onto a cyclic R_{n}-module X^{n}, one has the corollary of 4.23 (3):

statement.label: 13.14B. Corollary.
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions:

def.p: R is PF,
R_{n} is a D-ring for all n,
f\cdot g right or left R-modules are torsionless.

statement.label: 13.15A. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a ring for which the lattice of right ideals is anti-isomorphic (i.e., dual) to the lattice of left ideals by a mapping d. If R is right or left Artinian or Noetherian, then R is QF and d(I) is the left (right) annihilator for each right (left) ideal.

sec.p: Cf. Baer [43].

statement.label: 13.15B. Corollary
statement.title: (loc.cit.).
statement.p: If R is an algebra of finite dimension over a field, and every right ideal is an annihilator, then R is QF. (Cf. 13.18, 13.20 and 13.36)

sec.title: Skornyakov’s Theorem on Self-dual Lattices of Submodules

statement.label: 13.15C. Theorem
statement.p: If M is an R-module, and if the lattice L(M) of submodules of M is complemented and self-dual then M has finite Goldie and finite dual Goldie dimension.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: It follows that M in 13.15C is quotient finite dimensional. Cf. Theorem 16.50. It also follows that M has semilocal endomorphism ring. See Theorem 8.C. This implies that a D-ring is semilocal: see the next theorem.

sec.title: Hajarnavis-Norton Theorem

statement.label: 13.16. Theorem
statement.p: A D-ring R is semilocal, right and left f\cdot g injective, every f\cdot g R-module has finite Goldie dimension and R/J^{\omega } is Noetherian, where J is the Jacobson radical and J^{\omega }=\bigcap _{n\in \omega }J^{n}.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) Thus, any D-ring is quotient-finite dimensional, and quotient-finite-dual Goldie dimensional. Cf. 5.20B and 7.27ff. (2) Every D-ring is continuous (Yousif [97], Prop 1.9.) (3) The 2\times 2 matrix ring R_{2} over a ring R is a D-ring iff R is PF. (ibid.) Cf.13.14B. Also see Nicholson and Yousif [99], Prop. 2, and Faith and Dinh [02]
A right R-module M satisfies AB5^{\star } if

for all submodules N and inverse sets of submodules \{M_{i}\}_{i\in I}. (Lemonnier [79] simplified the proof of 13.16 using AB5^{\star }.) Any l.c. R-module M satisfies AB5^{\star } by a theorem of Leptin [55,57], Satz 1 (Cf. Xue [92], Cor.3.9).

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: (1) If M_{R} satisfies AB5^{\star }, and the set \mathcal{S}(M) of non-isomorphic simple images of M is finite, then \mathrm{End}\,M_{R} is semilocal. See Herbera and Shamsuddin [95], Corollary 7, for the proof. (2) If a ring R satisfies right AB5^{\star } (e.g. if R is right l.c.) then

def.p: R/J^{\omega } is right Noetherian,
J^{\omega }=0 if R is right and left Noetherian,
Every factor ring of R is a D ring iff R is uniserial (Hajarnavis and Norton (loc.cit.)
R is a dual ring if and only if R satisfies AB5^{\star } and is an essential extension of its socle on both sides and R-dual takes simple to simple,

A one-sided Noetherian ring R is a quasi-Frobenius ring if and only if it is an essential extension of its socle and satisfies AB5^{\star } on both sides and R-dual takes simple into simple. Any AB5^{\star } right R-module M over a right l.c. ring R is l.c.

sec.p: (1) (1) is due to Mueller [70], and
(2) (2) to Menini [86]. See Herbera and Shamsuddin (loc.cit.)
(3) (4) and (5) owe to Ánh-Herbera-Menini [97a].

statement.label: 13.17. Theorem
statement.p: A D-ring R is QF iff J is transfinitely nilpotent.

statement.label: 13.18. Example
statement.p: There exists a right Noetherian right D-ring (= right Johns ring) that is not Artinian: Let D be a countable EC sfield with center k (Cf. 6.24), and let A=D\otimes k(x), where k(x) is the field of rational functions over k. Then D is an A-bimodule that is simple as a right A-module, and the split-null extension R=A\ltimes D is a non-Artinian right Johns ring. As stated in our paper, the proof depends on the cited work of Cohn on EC fields, and also Resco [87] who proved that A is a non-Artinian V-domain, thereby solving a problem posed by Cozzens and Faith [75].

sec.title: Faith-Menal Theorem

statement.label: 13.19. Theorem
statement.p: A right Noetherian right D-ring R is right Artinian provided that either (1) R is semilocal, or (2) R has finite left Goldie dimension, or (3) if x\in R then x is a unit iff x^{\perp }=0 ,i.e. every right regular element is a unit.

sec.p: The proof of 13.19(2) employs Corollary 3.2, ibid., which we state here as:

statement.label: 13.19^{\prime }. Theorem.
statement.p: Any right Kasch ring of finite left Goldie dimension is semilocal.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Cf. 9.9A(1) and 9.9C, D. Also see Xue [98a].

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: As we pointed out (loc.cit.), (1) is immediate from the work of Johns [77] who made an error in his paper that, as pointed out by S. M. Ginn, resulted from using a false lemma of R. P. Kurshan (see loc.cit.); (2) can be weakened to “R has no infinite direct sum of minimal left annihilators” (ibid.).

statement.label: 13.20. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a right Noetherian ring in which principal right ideals are annihilators, and
for every pair of left ideals I_{1} and I_{2}, then R is QF.

sec.p: This was stated in Johns [77], but the theorem was in doubt in view of the remark above and the counter-example to one of Johns’ theorems (see 13.18).

sec.title: Commutative Rings with QF Quotient Rings
sec.p: In this paragraph R will denote a commutative ring.

statement.label: 13.21. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative Noetherian ring R has QF quotient ring Q iff the zero ideal is unmixed and all of its primary components are irreducible.

statement.label: Definition.
statement.p: A commutative ring R has the commutative endomorphism property (= CEP) if every ideal of R has commutative endomorphism ring.

statement.label: 13.22. Remarks.
statement.p: (1) Any faithful ideal I of a commutative ring R has CEP (see, e.g. Faith [82a,b], p.76).
(2) If R is reduced (=R has no nilpotents except 0), then R has CEP (Cox [73]).
(3) If R is self-injective, then R has CEP.
(4) (Alamelu [73], Remark 2, p.30) If S is a m.c. set of regular elements, then f\cdot g ideals of R has CEP iff the same is true of RS^{-1}.
(5) (Vasconcelos [73]) If M is any f\cdot g faithful module over a reduced ring R, and if \mathrm{End}_{R}M is a commutative reduced ring, then M\hookrightarrow R.

sec.title: On a Vasconcelos Conjecture

statement.label: 13.23. Theorem
statement.p: Let R be a commutative ring with Noetherian quotient ring Q. Then every ideal of R has commutative endomorphism ring iff Q is QF.

sec.p: This theorem verified a conjecture of Vasconcelos [70c].

statement.label: 13.24A. Theorem
statement.p: If R is a coherent commutative p-injective ring, then every ideal of R has commutative endomorphism ring.

statement.label: 13.24B. Proposition
statement.title: (loc.cit., Prop. 4).
statement.p: If R=Q(R) is coherent, and R induces End_{R}I for every (2-generated) ideal I, then I is self-injective (resp. p-injective).

statement.label: 13.25. Corollary.
statement.p: If R has IF quotient ring Q, then every f\cdot g ideal of R, and every ideal of Q has commutative endomorphism ring.

sec.p: This follows from 13.22.4, 13.24A and the fact that an IF ring is FP-injective, hence p-injective, and coherent (see Theorem 6.9).

statement.label: 13.26. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative ring R has local QF quotient ring Q(R) iff R is a uniform acc{\perp } ring.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: 13.26 generalizes Shizhong’s Theorem 7.11.

sec.title: Kasch-Mueller Quasi-Frobenius Extensions
sec.p: The next concept generalizes group rings R=SG for a finite group G.

statement.p: Definition And Theorem (Kasch [54,61] And Mueller [64,65]). A ring R is a \mathbf{left\ quasi-Frobenius\ extension} of a subring S provided that _{S}R is f\cdot g projective and the S-dual module R^{\star }=Hom_{S}(R,S) generates R-mod in such a way that R is an (R,S)-direct summand of copies of R^{\star }. Then R is a QF ring iff S is a QF ring.

statement.label: 13.28. Remark.
statement.p: Kasch (op.cit.) proved this for Frobenius extensions and rings (not discussed here, but see the author’s Algebra II ,pp.220–221ff).

sec.title: Balanced Rings and a Problem of Thrall
sec.p: Thrall [48] proposed the classification of finite dimensional algebras, called QF-1 algebras over which all f\cdot g faithful right R-modules are balanced. These properly contain the class of QF-algebras,
Camillo [70] generalized the property by asking when every right R-module is balanced, and called these balanced rings.

statement.p: Camillo’s Theorem [70] Let R be balanced. Then:

def.p: R is semiperfect with nil Jacobson radical.
If R is Noetherian (resp. commutative), then R is Artinian (resp. QF).

statement.p: Camillo-Fuller Theorem [72] Let R be an algebra of finite dimension over a field.

def.p: If R is local and QF-1, then R is QF.
If R is balanced, then R is uniserial.

statement.label: Remark.
statement.p: Dlab and Ringel independently obtained (2) of the theorem, according to the author’s note on p.376 of op.cit. See 13.30D below.

sec.p: A ring R is finitely right balanced if every f\cdot g right R-module is balanced (see “A general Wedderburn Theorem”, 3.52 ff., and also sup. 13.29).

statement.label: 13.30A. Theorem
statement.p: Every uniserial ring is balanced.

statement.label: 13.30B. Theorem
statement.p: The following are equivalent conditions on a ring R: (1) R is right balanced; (2) R is finitely right balanced; (3) R is a direct sum of uniserial rings and full matrix rings over “exceptional” rings (\mathbf{vide} op.cit.).

statement.label: 13.30C. Corollary.
statement.p: Any finitely right balanced ring is left balanced, and Artinian.

statement.label: 13.30D. Theorem
statement.p: A balanced ring R that is module-finite over center is uniserial.

statement.label: 13.30E. Theorem
statement.p: A commutative Noetherian QF-1 ring is QF.

statement.label: 13.30F. Theorem
statement.p: For a right linearly compact ring, the following conditions are equivalent:

def.p: Every (faithful) f\cdot g projective right module is balanced.
Every (faithful) finitely embedded injective right R-module is balanced.
Every (faithful) injective right R-module with essential socle is balanced.
Every (faithful) projective left R-module with superfluous (= the dual of essential) radical is balanced.

sec.title: When Finitely Generated Modules Embed in Free Modules
sec.p: R is right FGF (resp. CF) if all f\cdot g (resp. cyclic) right R-module embed in free modules. Any right CF ring R is right Kasch, hence R=Q_{\max }^{r}(R). By Theorem 3.5D, any right and left CF is QF, in which case, by Theorem 3.5B, every R-module embeds in a free module.
Recall from 6.8s that a ring R is right IF if every injective right R-module is flat.
A conjecture of the author’s is that FGF\Rightarrow QF. This has been verified in a number of special cases, and we propose to discuss some of these.

statement.label: 13.31. Theorem.
statement.p: Let R be right FGF ring. The following are equivalent:

def.p: R is QF,
R is a subring of a right Noetherian ring,
R is semilocal with essential right socle,
R has finite essential right socle,
R is right self-injective,
R is left CF,
R is left Kasch,
R satisfies acc{\perp },
R satisfies dcc{\perp }.
